</div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology_and_terminology">Etymology and terminology</span></h2>
<p><span class="anchor" id="Etymology"></span>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Britain_(place_name)" title="Britain (place name)">Britain (place name)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Terminology_of_the_British_Isles" title="Terminology of the British Isles">Terminology of the British Isles</a></div>
<p>In 43 AD, <i>Britannia</i> referred to the <a href="/wiki/Roman_province" title="Roman province">Roman province</a> that encompassed modern day <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales" title="England and Wales">England and Wales</a>. Great Britain encompassed the whole island, taking in the land north of the <a href="/wiki/River_Forth" title="River Forth">River Forth</a> known to the Romans as <a href="/wiki/Caledonia" title="Caledonia">Caledonia</a> in modern <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a> (i.e. "greater" Britain).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mcgill1_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-mcgill1-54">[41]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, the name "Britain" was also applied to a small part of France now known as <a href="/wiki/Brittany" title="Brittany">Brittany</a>. As a result, Great Britain (likely from the French "<span title="French-language text"><i lang="fr">Grande Bretagne</i></span>")<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mcgill1_54-1"><a href="#cite_note-mcgill1-54">[41]</a></sup> came into use to refer specifically to the island, with Brittany often referred to as "Little Britain".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-55"><a href="#cite_note-55">[42]</a></sup> However, that name had no official significance until 1707, when the island's kingdoms of England and Scotland were united as the Kingdom of Great Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-56"><a href="#cite_note-56">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707" title="Acts of Union 1707">Acts of Union 1707</a> declared that the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">Kingdom of England</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Scotland" title="Kingdom of Scotland">Kingdom of Scotland</a> were "United into One Kingdom by the Name of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">Great Britain</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[note 4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[45]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[46]</a></sup> The term "United Kingdom" has occasionally been used as a description for the former Kingdom of Great Britain, although its official name from 1707 to 1800 was simply "Great Britain".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-name_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-name-61">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-name2_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-name2-62">[48]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-name3_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-name3-63">[49]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[50]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1800" title="Acts of Union 1800">Acts of Union 1800</a> united the kingdoms of Great Britain and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Ireland" title="Kingdom of Ireland">Ireland</a> in 1801, forming the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland</a>. Following the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland" title="Partition of Ireland">partition of Ireland</a> and the independence of the <a href="/wiki/Irish_Free_State" title="Irish Free State">Irish Free State</a> in 1922, which left <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a> as the only part of the island of Ireland within the United Kingdom, the name was changed to the "United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although the United Kingdom is a sovereign country, England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are also widely referred to as countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alphabeticalNI1_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-alphabeticalNI1-66">[52]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[53]</a></sup> The UK Prime Minister's website has used the phrase "countries within a country" to describe the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-page823_32-1"><a href="#cite_note-page823-32">[21]</a></sup> Some statistical summaries, such as those for the twelve <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NUTS_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="NUTS of the United Kingdom">NUTS 1 regions of the United Kingdom</a> refer to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland as "regions".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-68"><a href="#cite_note-68">[54]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[55]</a></sup> Northern Ireland is also referred to as a "province".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alphabeticalNI2_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-alphabeticalNI2-70">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-placeApart_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-placeApart-71">[57]</a></sup> With regard to Northern Ireland, the descriptive name used "can be controversial, with the choice often revealing one's political preferences".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>The term "Great Britain" conventionally refers to the island of Great Britain, or politically to England, Scotland and Wales in combination.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[61]</a></sup> It is sometimes used as a loose synonym for the United Kingdom as a whole.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-76"><a href="#cite_note-76">[62]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Britain_(place_name)" title="Britain (place name)">term "Britain"</a> is used both as a synonym for Great Britain,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britain-CED_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britain-CED-77">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britain-OLD_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britain-OLD-78">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britain-Col_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britain-Col-79">[65]</a></sup> and as a synonym for the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britain-MW_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-Britain-MW-80">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Britain-Col_79-1"><a href="#cite_note-Britain-Col-79">[65]</a></sup> Usage is mixed: the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Government of the United Kingdom">UK Government</a> prefers to use the term "UK" rather than "Britain" or "British" on its own website (except when referring to embassies),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-style-guide-govuk_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-style-guide-govuk-81">[67]</a></sup> while acknowledging that both terms refer to the United Kingdom and that elsewhere "British government" is used at least as frequently as "United Kingdom government".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PCGN-uk-guide_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-PCGN-uk-guide-82">[68]</a></sup> The UK <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Permanent_Committee_on_Geographical_Names" title="Permanent Committee on Geographical Names">Permanent Committee on Geographical Names</a> recognises "United Kingdom", "UK" and "U.K." as shortened and abbreviated geopolitical terms for the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland in its toponymic guidelines; it does not list "Britain" but notes that "it is only the one specific nominal term 'Great Britain' which invariably excludes Northern Ireland".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PCGN-uk-guide_82-1"><a href="#cite_note-PCGN-uk-guide-82">[68]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> historically preferred to use "Britain" as shorthand only for Great Britain, though the present style guide does not take a position except that "Great Britain" excludes Northern Ireland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-checklist-bbc_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-checklist-bbc-84">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>The adjective "British" is commonly used to refer to matters relating to the United Kingdom and is used in law to refer to United Kingdom citizenship and <a href="/wiki/British_nationality_law" title="British nationality law">matters to do with nationality</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bradley_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bradley-85">[71]</a></sup> People of the United Kingdom use a number of different terms to describe their national identity and may identify themselves as being <a href="/wiki/British_people" title="British people">British</a>, <a href="/wiki/English_people" title="English people">English</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scottish_people" title="Scottish people">Scottish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Welsh_people" title="Welsh people">Welsh</a>, <a href="/wiki/People_of_Northern_Ireland" title="People of Northern Ireland">Northern Irish</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Irish_people" title="Irish people">Irish</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[72]</a></sup> or as having a combination of different national identities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[73]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[74]</a></sup> The official designation for a citizen of the United Kingdom is "British citizen".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PCGN-uk-guide_82-2"><a href="#cite_note-PCGN-uk-guide-82">[68]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prior_to_the_Treaty_of_Union">Prior to the Treaty of Union</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_England" title="History of England">History of England</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Wales" title="History of Wales">History of Wales</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Scotland" title="History of Scotland">History of Scotland</a>, <a href="/wiki/History_of_Ireland" title="History of Ireland">History of Ireland</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/History_of_the_formation_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="History of the formation of the United Kingdom">History of the formation of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_British_Isles" title="History of the British Isles">History of the British Isles</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stonehenge,_Condado_de_Wiltshire,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-12,_DD_18.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2786" data-file-width="5265" decoding="async" height="116" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Stonehenge%2C_Condado_de_Wiltshire%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-12%2C_DD_18.JPG/220px-Stonehenge%2C_Condado_de_Wiltshire%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-12%2C_DD_18.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Stonehenge%2C_Condado_de_Wiltshire%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-12%2C_DD_18.JPG/330px-Stonehenge%2C_Condado_de_Wiltshire%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-12%2C_DD_18.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Stonehenge%2C_Condado_de_Wiltshire%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-12%2C_DD_18.JPG/440px-Stonehenge%2C_Condado_de_Wiltshire%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-12%2C_DD_18.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stonehenge,_Condado_de_Wiltshire,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-12,_DD_18.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Stonehenge" title="Stonehenge">Stonehenge</a> in <a href="/wiki/Wiltshire" title="Wiltshire">Wiltshire</a> is a ring of stones, each about 4 m (13 ft) high, 2 m (7 ft) wide and 25 <a href="/wiki/Tonne" title="Tonne">tonnes</a>, erected 2400–2200 BC.</div></div></div>
<p>Settlement by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cro-Magnons" title="Cro-Magnons">anatomically modern humans</a> of what was to become the United Kingdom occurred in waves beginning by about 30,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[75]</a></sup> By the end of the <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Britain" title="Prehistoric Britain">region's prehistoric period</a>, the population is thought to have belonged, in the main, to a culture termed <a href="/wiki/Insular_Celts" title="Insular Celts">Insular Celtic</a>, comprising <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Britons_(historical)" title="Britons (historical)">Brittonic Britain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_Ireland" title="Gaelic Ireland">Gaelic Ireland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Roman_conquest_of_Britain" title="Roman conquest of Britain">Roman conquest</a>, beginning in 43 AD, and the 400-year <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">rule of southern Britain</a>, was followed by an invasion by <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon" title="Anglo-Saxon">Anglo-Saxon</a> settlers, reducing the Brittonic area mainly <a href="/wiki/Wales#Medieval_Wales" title="Wales">to what was to become Wales</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cornwall" title="Cornwall">Cornwall</a> and, until the latter stages of the Anglo-Saxon settlement, the <a href="/wiki/Hen_Ogledd" title="Hen Ogledd">Hen Ogledd</a> (northern England and parts of southern Scotland).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[77]</a></sup> Most of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_England" title="Anglo-Saxon England">region settled by the Anglo-Saxons</a> became unified as the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">Kingdom of England</a> in the 10th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Short_Athelstan_biography_on_the_BBC_History_website_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-Short_Athelstan_biography_on_the_BBC_History_website-92">[78]</a></sup> Meanwhile, <a href="/wiki/D%C3%A1l_Riata" title="Dál Riata">Gaelic-speakers in north-west Britain</a> (with connections to the north-east of Ireland and traditionally supposed to have migrated from there in the 5th century)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[79]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[80]</a></sup> united with the <a href="/wiki/Picts" title="Picts">Picts</a> to create the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Scotland" title="Kingdom of Scotland">Kingdom of Scotland</a> in the 9th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[81]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="291" data-file-width="401" decoding="async" height="160" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg/220px-Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg/330px-Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/96/Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bayeux_Tapestry_WillelmDux.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Bayeux_Tapestry" title="Bayeux Tapestry">Bayeux Tapestry</a> depicts the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Hastings" title="Battle of Hastings">Battle of Hastings</a>, 1066, and the events leading to it.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1066, the <a href="/wiki/Normans" title="Normans">Normans</a> invaded England from northern France. After <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norman_conquest_of_England" title="Norman conquest of England">conquering England</a>, they seized <a href="/wiki/Norman_invasion_of_Wales" title="Norman invasion of Wales">large parts of Wales</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norman_invasion_of_Ireland" title="Norman invasion of Ireland">conquered much of Ireland</a> and were invited to settle in Scotland, bringing to each country <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a> on the Northern French model and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norman-French" title="Norman-French">Norman-French</a> culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[82]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Normans" title="Anglo-Normans">Anglo-Norman</a> <a href="/wiki/Ruling_class" title="Ruling class">ruling class</a> greatly influenced, but eventually assimilated with, each of the local cultures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[83]</a></sup> Subsequent <a href="/wiki/House_of_Plantagenet" title="House of Plantagenet">medieval English kings</a> completed the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Conquest_of_Wales" title="Conquest of Wales">conquest of Wales</a> and made unsuccessful <a href="/wiki/Wars_of_Scottish_Independence" title="Wars of Scottish Independence">attempts to annex Scotland</a>. Asserting its independence in the 1320 <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_Arbroath" title="Declaration of Arbroath">Declaration of Arbroath</a>, Scotland maintained its independence thereafter, albeit in <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Scottish_Wars" title="Anglo-Scottish Wars">near-constant conflict with England</a>.
</p><p>The English monarchs, through inheritance of <a href="/wiki/Angevin_Empire" title="Angevin Empire">substantial territories in France</a> and claims to the French crown, were also heavily involved in conflicts in France, most notably the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hundred_Years_War" title="Hundred Years War">Hundred Years War</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Scottish_monarchs" title="List of Scottish monarchs">Kings of Scots</a> were in <a href="/wiki/Auld_Alliance" title="Auld Alliance">an alliance with the French</a> during this period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-98"><a href="#cite_note-98">[84]</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/Early_modern_Britain" title="Early modern Britain">Early modern Britain</a> saw religious conflict resulting from the <a href="/wiki/Reformation" title="Reformation">Reformation</a> and the introduction of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestant" title="Protestant">Protestant</a> state churches in each country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-99"><a href="#cite_note-99">[85]</a></sup> Wales was <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Laws_in_Wales_Acts_1535%E2%80%931542" title="Laws in Wales Acts 1535–1542">fully incorporated into the Kingdom of England</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Tudors_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Tudors-100">[86]</a></sup> and Ireland was constituted as a kingdom in personal union with the English crown.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[87]</a></sup> In what was to become Northern Ireland, the lands of the independent Catholic Gaelic nobility were confiscated and <a href="/wiki/Plantation_of_Ulster" title="Plantation of Ulster">given to Protestant settlers</a> from England and Scotland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1603, the kingdoms of England, Scotland and Ireland were united in a <a href="/wiki/Personal_union" title="Personal union">personal union</a> when <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_I_of_England" title="James I of England">James VI, King of Scots</a>, inherited the crowns of England and Ireland and moved his court from <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a> to London; each country nevertheless remained a separate political entity and retained its separate political, legal, and religious institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-D._Ross,_2002_p._56_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-D._Ross,_2002_p._56-103">[89]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-J._Hearn,_2002_p._104_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-J._Hearn,_2002_p._104-104">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the mid-17th century, all three kingdoms <a href="/wiki/Wars_of_the_Three_Kingdoms" title="Wars of the Three Kingdoms">were involved in a series of connected wars</a> (including the <a href="/wiki/English_Civil_War" title="English Civil War">English Civil War</a>) which led to the temporary overthrow of the monarchy, with the <a href="/wiki/Execution_of_Charles_I" title="Execution of Charles I">execution of King Charles I</a>, and the establishment of the short-lived <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unitary_republic" title="Unitary republic">unitary republic</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_England" title="Commonwealth of England">Commonwealth of England, Scotland and Ireland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[91]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[92]</a></sup> During the 17th and 18th centuries, British sailors were involved in acts of <a href="/wiki/Piracy" title="Piracy">piracy</a> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Privateering" title="Privateering">privateering</a>), attacking and stealing from ships off the coast of Europe and the Caribbean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Restoration_(1660)" title="Restoration (1660)">monarchy was restored</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Interregnum_(1649%E2%80%931660)" title="Interregnum (1649–1660)">Interregnum</a> (along with the <a href="/wiki/Glorious_Revolution" title="Glorious Revolution">Glorious Revolution</a> of 1688 and the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Bill_of_Rights_1689" title="Bill of Rights 1689">Bill of Rights 1689</a> in England and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Claim_of_Right_Act_1689" title="Claim of Right Act 1689">Claim of Right Act 1689</a> in Scotland ensured that, unlike much of the rest of Europe, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_absolutism" title="Royal absolutism">royal absolutism</a> would not prevail, and a professed Catholic could never accede to the throne. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_constitution" title="British constitution">British constitution</a> would develop on the basis of <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary system</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[94]</a></sup> With the founding of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Society" title="Royal Society">Royal Society</a> in 1660, science was greatly encouraged. During this period, particularly in England, the development of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/English_navy" title="English navy">naval power</a> and the interest in <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Discovery" title="Age of Discovery">voyages of discovery</a> led to the acquisition and settlement of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_British_Empire" title="First British Empire">overseas colonies</a>, particularly in North America and the Caribbean.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[95]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>Though previous attempts at uniting the two kingdoms within Great Britain in 1606, 1667, and 1689 had proved unsuccessful, the attempt initiated in 1705 led to the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Union" title="Treaty of Union">Treaty of Union</a> of 1706 being agreed and ratified by both parliaments.
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Kingdom_of_Great_Britain">Kingdom of Great Britain</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Great_Britain" title="Kingdom of Great Britain">Kingdom of Great Britain</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Union.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1225" data-file-width="1562" decoding="async" height="173" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Treaty_of_Union.jpg/220px-Treaty_of_Union.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Treaty_of_Union.jpg/330px-Treaty_of_Union.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Treaty_of_Union.jpg/440px-Treaty_of_Union.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Treaty_of_Union.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Union" title="Treaty of Union">Treaty of Union</a> led to a united kingdom of all of Great Britain.</div></div></div>
<p>On 1 May 1707, the Kingdom of Great Britain was formed, the result of <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707" title="Acts of Union 1707">Acts of Union</a> being passed by the parliaments of England and Scotland to ratify the 1706 <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Union" title="Treaty of Union">Treaty of Union</a> and so unite the two kingdoms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 18th century, cabinet government developed under <a href="/wiki/Robert_Walpole" title="Robert Walpole">Robert Walpole</a>, in practice the first prime minister (1721–1742). A series of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jacobite_Uprisings" title="Jacobite Uprisings">Jacobite Uprisings</a> sought to remove the Protestant <a href="/wiki/House_of_Hanover" title="House of Hanover">House of Hanover</a> from the British throne and restore the Catholic <a href="/wiki/House_of_Stuart" title="House of Stuart">House of Stuart</a>. The Jacobites were finally defeated at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Culloden" title="Battle of Culloden">Battle of Culloden</a> in 1746, after which the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlanders" title="Scottish Highlanders">Scottish Highlanders</a> were brutally suppressed. The British colonies in North America that broke away from Britain in the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American War of Independence</a> became the United States of America, recognised by Britain in 1783. British imperial ambition turned towards Asia, particularly to <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>Britain played a leading part in the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">Atlantic slave trade</a>, mainly between 1662 and 1807 when British or British-colonial <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slave_ships" title="Slave ships">Slave ships</a> transported nearly 3.3 million slaves from Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12Morgan2007_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-12Morgan2007-115">[101]</a></sup> The slaves were taken to work on <a href="/wiki/Plantation_economy" title="Plantation economy">plantations</a> in British possessions, principally in the <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_British_West_Indies" title="History of the British West Indies">Caribbean</a> but also <a href="/wiki/British_America" title="British America">North America</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15Morgan2007_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-15Morgan2007-116">[102]</a></sup> Slavery coupled with the <a href="/wiki/Sugar_plantations_in_the_Caribbean" title="Sugar plantations in the Caribbean">Caribbean sugar industry</a> had a significant role in strengthening and developing the British economy in the 18th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83Morgan2007_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-83Morgan2007-117">[103]</a></sup> However, Parliament banned the trade in 1807, banned slavery in the British Empire in 1833, and Britain took a leading role in the movement to abolish slavery worldwide through the <a href="/wiki/Blockade_of_Africa" title="Blockade of Africa">blockade of Africa</a> and pressing other nations to end their trade with a series of treaties. The world's oldest international human rights organisation, <a href="/wiki/Anti-Slavery_International" title="Anti-Slavery International">Anti-Slavery International</a>, was formed in London in 1839.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[104]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="From_the_union_with_Ireland_to_the_end_of_the_First_World_War">From the union with Ireland to the end of the First World War</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="History of the United Kingdom">History of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="846" data-file-width="1854" decoding="async" height="100" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG/220px-Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG/330px-Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG/440px-Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Waterloo_1815.PNG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>At the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Waterloo" title="Battle of Waterloo">Battle of Waterloo</a> in 1815, a British-led coalition under the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Duke_of_Wellington" title="Duke of Wellington">Duke of Wellington</a>, supported by <a href="/wiki/Gebhard_Leberecht_von_Bl%C3%BCcher" title="Gebhard Leberecht von Blücher">von Blücher</a>'s Prussian army, defeated the French, ending the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The term "United Kingdom" became official in 1801 when the parliaments of Great Britain and Ireland each passed an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_(1800)" title="Acts of Union (1800)">Act of Union</a>, uniting the two kingdoms and creating the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>After the defeat of France at the end of the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars" title="French Revolutionary Wars">French Revolutionary Wars</a> and <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> (1792–1815), the United Kingdom emerged as the principal naval and imperial power of the 19th century (with London the largest city in the world from about 1830).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[108]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy#1815–1914" title="Royal Navy">Unchallenged at sea</a>, British dominance was later described as <i><a href="/wiki/Pax_Britannica" title="Pax Britannica">Pax Britannica</a></i> ("British Peace"), a period of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_relations_of_the_Great_Powers_(1814%E2%80%931919)" title="International relations of the Great Powers (1814–1919)">relative peace among the Great Powers</a> (1815–1914) during which the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> became the global <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hegemon" title="Hegemon">hegemon</a> and adopted the role of global policeman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-123"><a href="#cite_note-123">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[110]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[111]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[112]</a></sup> By the time of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Great_Exhibition" title="The Great Exhibition">the Great Exhibition</a> of 1851, Britain was described as the "workshop of the world".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[113]</a></sup> From 1853 to 1856, Britain took part in the <a href="/wiki/Crimean_War" title="Crimean War">Crimean War</a>, allied with the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> in the fight against the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[114]</a></sup> participating in the naval battles of the <a href="/wiki/Baltic_Sea" title="Baltic Sea">Baltic Sea</a> known as the <a href="/wiki/%C3%85land_War" title="Åland War">Åland War</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Bothnia" title="Gulf of Bothnia">Gulf of Bothnia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Finland" title="Gulf of Finland">Gulf of Finland</a>, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[115]</a></sup> The British Empire was expanded to include <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">India</a>, large <a href="/wiki/British_Empire#Cape_to_Cairo" title="British Empire">parts of Africa</a> and many other territories throughout the world. Alongside the formal control it exerted over its own colonies, British dominance of much of world trade meant that it effectively <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Informal_Empire" title="Informal Empire">controlled the economies of many regions</a>, such as Asia and Latin America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[116]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-131"><a href="#cite_note-131">[117]</a></sup> Domestically, political attitudes favoured free trade and laissez-faire policies and a gradual widening of the voting franchise. During the century, the population increased at a dramatic rate, accompanied by rapid urbanisation, causing significant social and economic stresses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[118]</a></sup> To seek new markets and sources of raw materials, the <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)" title="Conservative Party (UK)">Conservative Party</a> under <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Disraeli" title="Benjamin Disraeli">Disraeli</a> launched a period of imperialist expansion in Egypt, South Africa, and elsewhere. Canada, Australia and New Zealand became self-governing dominions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[119]</a></sup> After the turn of the century, Britain's industrial dominance was challenged by Germany and the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[120]</a></sup> Social reform and home rule for Ireland were important domestic issues after 1900. The <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">Labour Party</a> emerged from an alliance of trade unions and small socialist groups in 1900, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Suffragettes" title="Suffragettes">suffragettes</a> campaigned from before 1914 for women's right to vote.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[121]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg"><img alt="Black-and-white photo of two dozen men in military uniforms and metal helmets sitting or standing in a muddy trench." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="671" data-file-width="949" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg/220px-Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg/330px-Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg/440px-Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Royal_Irish_Rifles_ration_party_Somme_July_1916.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Infantry of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Ulster_Rifles" title="Royal Ulster Rifles">Royal Irish Rifles</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Somme" title="Battle of the Somme">Battle of the Somme</a> in 1916.</div></div></div>
<p>Britain fought alongside France, Russia and (after 1917) the United States, against Germany and its allies in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War">First World War</a> (1914–1918).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[122]</a></sup> British armed forces were engaged across much of the British Empire and in several regions of Europe, particularly on the <a href="/wiki/Western_Front_(World_War_I)" title="Western Front (World War I)">Western front</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Westwell&amp;Cove_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-Westwell&amp;Cove-137">[123]</a></sup> The high fatalities of trench warfare caused the loss of much of a generation of men, with lasting social effects in the nation and a great disruption in the social order.
</p><p>After the war, Britain received the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> mandate over a number of former German and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman</a> colonies. The British Empire reached its greatest extent, covering a fifth of the world's land surface and a quarter of its population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[124]</a></sup> Britain had suffered 2.5 million casualties and finished the war with a huge national debt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Westwell&amp;Cove_137-1"><a href="#cite_note-Westwell&amp;Cove-137">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Interwar_years_and_the_Second_World_War">Interwar years and the Second World War</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Interwar_Britain" title="Interwar Britain">Interwar Britain</a>, <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_the_United_Kingdom_during_World_War_II" title="Military history of the United Kingdom during World War II">Military history of the United Kingdom during World War II</a>, and <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_home_front_during_World_War_II" title="United Kingdom home front during World War II">United Kingdom home front during World War II</a></div>
<p>By the mid-1920s most of the British population could listen to <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> radio programmes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[126]</a></sup> Experimental television broadcasts <a href="/wiki/History_of_television#United_Kingdom" title="History of television">began in 1929</a> and the <a href="/wiki/First_day_of_BBC_television" title="First day of BBC television">first scheduled BBC Television Service</a> commenced in 1936.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>The rise of <a href="/wiki/Irish_nationalism" title="Irish nationalism">Irish nationalism</a>, and disputes within Ireland over the terms of <a href="/wiki/Irish_Home_Rule_movement" title="Irish Home Rule movement">Irish Home Rule</a>, led eventually to the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland" title="Partition of Ireland">partition of the island</a> in 1921.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[128]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Irish_Free_State" title="Irish Free State">Irish Free State</a> became independent, initially with <a href="/wiki/Dominion" title="Dominion">Dominion</a> status in 1922, and <a href="/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_1931#Irish_Free_State" title="Statute of Westminster 1931">unambiguously independent in 1931</a>. Northern Ireland remained part of the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CAIN_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-CAIN-143">[129]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Representation_of_the_People_(Equal_Franchise)_Act_1928" title="Representation of the People (Equal Franchise) Act 1928">1928 Act</a> widened <a href="/wiki/Suffrage" title="Suffrage">suffrage</a> by giving women electoral equality with men. A wave of strikes in the mid-1920s culminated in the <a href="/wiki/1926_United_Kingdom_general_strike" title="1926 United Kingdom general strike">General Strike of 1926</a>. Britain had still not recovered from the effects of the war when the <a href="/wiki/Great_Depression_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Great Depression in the United Kingdom">Great Depression</a> (1929–1932) occurred. This led to considerable unemployment and hardship in the old industrial areas, as well as political and social unrest in the 1930s, with rising membership in communist and socialist parties. A coalition government was formed in 1931.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[130]</a></sup>
</p><p>Nonetheless, "Britain was a very wealthy country, formidable in arms, ruthless in pursuit of its interests and sitting at the heart of a global production system."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Edgerton2012_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-Edgerton2012-145">[131]</a></sup> After <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a> invaded Poland, Britain entered the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_World_War" title="Second World War">Second World War</a> by declaring war on Germany in 1939. <a href="/wiki/Winston_Churchill" title="Winston Churchill">Winston Churchill</a> became prime minister and head of a coalition government in 1940. Despite the defeat of its European allies in the first year of the war, Britain and its Empire continued the fight alone against Germany. Churchill engaged industry, scientists, and engineers to advise and support the government and the military in the prosecution of the war effort.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Edgerton2012_145-1"><a href="#cite_note-Edgerton2012-145">[131]</a></sup> In 1940, the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Air_Force" title="Royal Air Force">Royal Air Force</a> defeated the German <a href="/wiki/Luftwaffe" title="Luftwaffe">Luftwaffe</a> in a struggle for control of the skies in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Britain" title="Battle of Britain">Battle of Britain</a>. Urban areas suffered heavy bombing during <a href="/wiki/The_Blitz" title="The Blitz">the Blitz</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Alliance_(World_War_II)" title="Grand Alliance (World War II)">Grand Alliance</a> of Britain, the United States and the <a href="/wiki/Soviet_Union" title="Soviet Union">Soviet Union</a> formed in 1941 leading the <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allies</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis powers</a>. There were eventual hard-fought victories in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Atlantic" title="Battle of the Atlantic">Battle of the Atlantic</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North_Africa_campaign" title="North Africa campaign">North Africa campaign</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Italian_campaign_(World_War_II)" title="Italian campaign (World War II)">Italian campaign</a>. British forces played an important role in the <a href="/wiki/Normandy_landings" title="Normandy landings">Normandy landings</a> of 1944 and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Liberation_of_Europe" title="Liberation of Europe">liberation of Europe</a>, achieved with its allies the United States, the Soviet Union and other Allied countries. The British Army led the <a href="/wiki/Burma_campaign" title="Burma campaign">Burma campaign</a> against Japan and the <a href="/wiki/British_Pacific_Fleet" title="British Pacific Fleet">British Pacific Fleet</a> fought Japan at sea. British scientists <a href="/wiki/British_contribution_to_the_Manhattan_Project" title="British contribution to the Manhattan Project">contributed to the Manhattan Project</a> which led to the <a href="/wiki/Surrender_of_Japan" title="Surrender of Japan">surrender of Japan</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Postwar_20th_century">Postwar 20th century</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Postwar_Britain_(1945%E2%80%931979)" title="Postwar Britain (1945–1979)">Postwar Britain (1945–1979)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_history_of_Postwar_Britain_(1945%E2%80%931979)" title="Social history of Postwar Britain (1945–1979)">Social history of Postwar Britain (1945–1979)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:362px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_British_Empire.png"><img alt="Map of the world. Canada, the eastern United States, countries in East Africa, India, most of Australasia and some other countries are highlighted in pink." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1400" data-file-width="2753" decoding="async" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/The_British_Empire.png/360px-The_British_Empire.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/The_British_Empire.png/540px-The_British_Empire.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/The_British_Empire.png/720px-The_British_Empire.png 2x" width="360"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_British_Empire.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Territories once part of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>, with the United Kingdom and its current <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">Overseas Dependencies</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crown_Dependencies" title="Crown Dependencies">Crown Dependencies</a> underlined in red</div></div></div>
<p>During the Second World War, the UK was one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Big_Three_(World_War_II)" title="Big Three (World War II)">Big Three</a> powers (along with the U.S. and the Soviet Union) who met to plan the post-war world;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[132]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[133]</a></sup> it was an original signatory to the <a href="/wiki/Declaration_by_United_Nations" title="Declaration by United Nations">Declaration by United Nations</a>. After the war, the UK became one of the five permanent members of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a> and worked closely with the United States to establish the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IMF" title="IMF">IMF</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a> and <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[134]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[135]</a></sup> The war left the UK severely weakened and financially dependent on the <a href="/wiki/Marshall_Plan" title="Marshall Plan">Marshall Plan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[136]</a></sup> but it was spared the total war that devastated eastern Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[137]</a></sup> In the immediate post-war years, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Labour_Government_1945%E2%80%931951" title="Labour Government 1945–1951">Labour government</a> initiated a radical programme of reforms, which had a significant effect on British society in the following decades.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[138]</a></sup> Major industries and public utilities were <a href="/wiki/Nationalization" title="Nationalization">nationalised</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Welfare_state" title="Welfare state">welfare state</a> was established, and a comprehensive, publicly funded healthcare system, the <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Service" title="National Health Service">National Health Service</a>, was created.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[139]</a></sup> The rise of nationalism in the colonies coincided with Britain's now much-diminished economic position, so that a policy of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Decolonisation" title="Decolonisation">decolonisation</a> was unavoidable. Independence was granted to India and Pakistan in 1947.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[140]</a></sup> Over the next three decades, most colonies of the British Empire gained their independence, with all those that sought independence supported by the UK, during both the transition period and afterwards. Many became members of the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[141]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK was the third country to develop <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nuclear_weapons_and_the_United_Kingdom" title="Nuclear weapons and the United Kingdom">a nuclear weapons arsenal</a> (with its first atomic bomb test, <a href="/wiki/Operation_Hurricane" title="Operation Hurricane">Operation Hurricane</a>, in 1952), but the new post-war limits of Britain's international role were illustrated by the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">Suez Crisis</a> of 1956. The <a href="/wiki/English-speaking_world" title="English-speaking world">international spread of the English language</a> ensured the continuing international influence of its <a href="/wiki/British_literature" title="British literature">literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Culture of the United Kingdom">culture</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-culture-156">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sheridan_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-sheridan-157">[143]</a></sup> As a result of a shortage of workers in the 1950s, the government encouraged immigration from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commonwealth_countries" title="Commonwealth countries">Commonwealth countries</a>. In the following decades, the UK became a more multi-ethnic society than before.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[144]</a></sup> Despite rising living standards in the late 1950s and 1960s, the UK's economic performance was less successful than many of its main competitors such as France, <a href="/wiki/West_Germany" title="West Germany">West Germany</a> and Japan.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="310" data-file-width="521" decoding="async" height="131" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/220px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/330px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg/440px-Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_%28081%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tratado_de_Lisboa_13_12_2007_(081).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Leaders of <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">EU</a> states in 2007. The UK entered the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Community" title="European Economic Community">EEC</a> in 1973. In a <a href="/wiki/1975_United_Kingdom_European_Communities_membership_referendum" title="1975 United Kingdom European Communities membership referendum">1975 referendum</a> 67% voted to stay in it;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[145]</a></sup> in 2016 52% voted to leave the EU.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[146]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In the decades-long process of <a href="/wiki/European_integration" title="European integration">European integration</a>, the UK was a founding member of the alliance called the <a href="/wiki/Western_European_Union" title="Western European Union">Western European Union</a>, established with the <a href="/wiki/London_and_Paris_Conferences" title="London and Paris Conferences">London and Paris Conferences</a> in 1954. In 1960 the UK was one of the seven founding members of the <a href="/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association" title="European Free Trade Association">European Free Trade Association</a> (EFTA), but in 1973 it left to join the <a href="/wiki/European_Communities" title="European Communities">European Communities</a> (EC). When the EC became the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> (EU) in 1992, the UK was one of the 12 founding member states. The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Lisbon" title="Treaty of Lisbon">Treaty of Lisbon</a>, signed in 2007, forms the constitutional basis of the European Union since then.
</p><p>From the late 1960s, Northern Ireland suffered communal and paramilitary violence (sometimes affecting other parts of the UK) conventionally known as <a href="/wiki/The_Troubles" title="The Troubles">the Troubles</a>. It is usually considered to have ended with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Belfast_Agreement" title="Belfast Agreement">Belfast "Good Friday" Agreement</a> of 1998.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hope_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hope-162">[148]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following a period of widespread economic slowdown and industrial strife in the 1970s, the Conservative government of the 1980s under <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Thatcher" title="Margaret Thatcher">Margaret Thatcher</a> initiated a radical policy of <a href="/wiki/Monetarism" title="Monetarism">monetarism</a>, deregulation, particularly of the financial sector (for example, the <a href="/wiki/Big_Bang_(financial_markets)" title="Big Bang (financial markets)">Big Bang</a> in 1986) and labour markets, the sale of state-owned companies (privatisation), and the withdrawal of subsidies to others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[150]</a></sup> From 1984, the economy was helped by the inflow of substantial <a href="/wiki/North_Sea_oil" title="North Sea oil">North Sea oil</a> revenues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>Around the end of the 20th century, there were major changes to the governance of the UK with the establishment of <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolved</a> administrations for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[152]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Act_1998" title="Human Rights Act 1998">statutory incorporation</a> followed acceptance of the <a href="/wiki/European_Convention_on_Human_Rights" title="European Convention on Human Rights">European Convention on Human Rights</a>. The UK is still a key global player diplomatically and militarily. It plays leading roles in the UN and <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="21st_century">21st century</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Political_history_of_the_United_Kingdom_(1979%E2%80%93present)" title="Political history of the United Kingdom (1979–present)">Political history of the United Kingdom (1979–present)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_history_of_the_United_Kingdom_(1979%E2%80%93present)" title="Social history of the United Kingdom (1979–present)">Social history of the United Kingdom (1979–present)</a></div>
<p>The UK broadly supported the United States' approach to the <a href="/wiki/War_on_terror" title="War on terror">War on Terror</a> in the early years of the 21st century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[153]</a></sup> Controversy surrounded some of Britain's overseas military deployments, particularly in <a href="/wiki/War_in_Afghanistan_(2001%E2%80%932021)" title="War in Afghanistan (2001–2021)">Afghanistan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iraq_War" title="Iraq War">Iraq</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2008_global_financial_crisis" title="2008 global financial crisis">2008 global financial crisis</a> severely affected the UK economy. The <a href="/wiki/Cameron%E2%80%93Clegg_coalition" title="Cameron–Clegg coalition">Cameron–Clegg coalition</a> government of 2010 introduced <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_government_austerity_programme" title="United Kingdom government austerity programme">austerity</a> measures intended to tackle the substantial public deficits which resulted.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[155]</a></sup> The devolved <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">Scottish Government</a> and <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Government of the United Kingdom">UK government</a> agreed for a referendum to be held on <a href="/wiki/Scottish_independence" title="Scottish independence">Scottish independence</a> in 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[156]</a></sup> This referendum resulted in the electorate in Scotland <a href="/wiki/2014_Scottish_independence_referendum" title="2014 Scottish independence referendum">voting by 55.3 to 44.7%</a> for Scotland to remain part of the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2016, 51.9 per cent of voters in the United Kingdom <a href="/wiki/2016_United_Kingdom_European_Union_membership_referendum" title="2016 United Kingdom European Union membership referendum">voted to leave the European Union</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Washington_Post_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-Washington_Post-172">[158]</a></sup> The UK left the EU on 31 January 2020 and completed its withdrawal in full at the end of that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[159]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="COVID-19 pandemic in the United Kingdom">COVID-19 pandemic</a> had a major impact on the UK in 2020 and 2021.
</p><p>On 8 September 2022, <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_II" title="Elizabeth II">Elizabeth II</a>, the longest-living and <a href="/wiki/List_of_monarchs_in_Britain_by_length_of_reign" title="List of monarchs in Britain by length of reign">longest-reigning British monarch</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Death_of_Elizabeth_II" title="Death of Elizabeth II">died at the age of 96</a> at <a href="/wiki/Balmoral_Castle" title="Balmoral Castle">Balmoral Castle</a> in Scotland. The official announcement came at 18:30 BST. Earlier in the day, doctors reported that her health had been deteriorating rapidly and placed her under medical supervision.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBCNewsInfo_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBCNewsInfo-174">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Geography of the United Kingdom">Geography of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Uk_topo_en.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3089" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="371" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Uk_topo_en.jpg/240px-Uk_topo_en.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Uk_topo_en.jpg/360px-Uk_topo_en.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Uk_topo_en.jpg/480px-Uk_topo_en.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Uk_topo_en.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The United Kingdom showing hilly regions to north and west</div></div></div>
<p>The total area of the United Kingdom is approximately 244,820 square kilometres (94,530 sq mi). The country occupies the major part of the <a href="/wiki/British_Isles" title="British Isles">British Isles</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[161]</a></sup> archipelago and includes the island of Great Britain, the north-eastern one-sixth of the island of Ireland and some smaller surrounding islands. It lies between the North Atlantic Ocean and the North Sea with the southeast coast coming within 22 miles (35 km) of the coast of northern France, from which it is separated by the <a href="/wiki/English_Channel" title="English Channel">English Channel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-176">[162]</a></sup> In 1993 10 per cent of the UK was forested, 46 per cent used for pastures and 25 per cent cultivated for agriculture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-177">[163]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Observatory,_Greenwich" title="Royal Observatory, Greenwich">Royal Greenwich Observatory</a> in London was chosen as the defining point of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prime_Meridian" title="Prime Meridian">Prime Meridian</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[164]</a></sup> in <a href="/wiki/International_Meridian_Conference" title="International Meridian Conference">Washington, DC, in 1884</a>, although due to more accurate modern measurement the meridian actually lies 100 metres to the east of the observatory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[165]</a></sup>
</p><p>The United Kingdom lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/49th_parallel_north" title="49th parallel north">49°</a> and <a href="/wiki/61st_parallel_north" title="61st parallel north">61° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/9th_meridian_west" title="9th meridian west">9° W</a> and <a href="/wiki/2nd_meridian_east" title="2nd meridian east">2° E</a>. Northern Ireland shares a 224-mile (360 km) land boundary with the Republic of Ireland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_176-1"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-176">[162]</a></sup> The coastline of Great Britain is 11,073 miles (17,820 km) long.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UK_coastline_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-UK_coastline-180">[166]</a></sup> It is connected to continental Europe by the <a href="/wiki/Channel_Tunnel" title="Channel Tunnel">Channel Tunnel</a>, which at 31 miles (50 km) (24 miles (38 km) underwater) is the longest underwater tunnel in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-181"><a href="#cite_note-181">[167]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_England" title="Geography of England">England</a> accounts for just over half (53 per cent) of the total area of the UK, covering 130,395 square kilometres (50,350 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[168]</a></sup> Most of the country consists of lowland terrain,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_177-1"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-177">[163]</a></sup> with more upland and some mountainous terrain northwest of the <a href="/wiki/Tees-Exe_line" title="Tees-Exe line">Tees-Exe line</a>; including the <a href="/wiki/Lake_District" title="Lake District">Lake District</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pennines" title="Pennines">Pennines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Exmoor" title="Exmoor">Exmoor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dartmoor" title="Dartmoor">Dartmoor</a>. The main rivers and estuaries are the <a href="/wiki/River_Thames" title="River Thames">Thames</a>, <a href="/wiki/River_Severn" title="River Severn">Severn</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Humber" title="Humber">Humber</a>. England's highest mountain is <a href="/wiki/Scafell_Pike" title="Scafell Pike">Scafell Pike</a> (978 metres (3,209 ft)) in the <a href="/wiki/Lake_District" title="Lake District">Lake District</a>.
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:229px;max-width:229px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Keswick_Panorama_-_Oct_2009.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3822" data-file-width="10814" decoding="async" height="80"
