//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Keswick_Panorama_-_Oct_2009.jpg/450px-Keswick_Panorama_-_Oct_2009.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Skiddaw" title="Skiddaw">Skiddaw massif</a>, <a href="/wiki/Keswick,_Cumbria" title="Keswick, Cumbria">Keswick</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Derwent_Water" title="Derwent Water">Derwent Water</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Lake_District" title="Lake District">Lake District</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:227px;max-width:227px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2123" data-file-width="5596" decoding="async" height="85" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg/225px-Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg/338px-Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg/450px-Quiraing_Isle_of_Skye_Pano.jpg 2x" width="225"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Skye" title="Isle of Skye">Skye</a> is one of the major islands in the <a href="/wiki/Inner_Hebrides" title="Inner Hebrides">Inner Hebrides</a> and part of the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">Scottish Highlands</a>.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Scotland" title="Geography of Scotland">Scotland</a> accounts for just under one-third (32 per cent) of the total area of the UK, covering 78,772 square kilometres (30,410 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[169]</a></sup> This includes nearly 800 <a href="/wiki/List_of_islands_of_Scotland" title="List of islands of Scotland">islands</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[170]</a></sup> predominantly west and north of the mainland; notably the <a href="/wiki/Hebrides" title="Hebrides">Hebrides</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orkney" title="Orkney">Orkney Islands</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shetland" title="Shetland">Shetland Islands</a>. Scotland is the most mountainous country in the UK and its topography is distinguished by the <a href="/wiki/Highland_Boundary_Fault" title="Highland Boundary Fault">Highland Boundary Fault</a> – a <a href="/wiki/Fault_(geology)" title="Fault (geology)">geological rock fracture</a> – which traverses Scotland from <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Arran" title="Isle of Arran">Arran</a> in the west to <a href="/wiki/Stonehaven" title="Stonehaven">Stonehaven</a> in the east.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[171]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Fault_(geology)" title="Fault (geology)">fault</a> separates two distinctively different regions; namely the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">Highlands</a> to the north and west and the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Lowlands" title="Scottish Lowlands">Lowlands</a> to the south and east. The more rugged Highland region contains the majority of Scotland's mountainous land, including <a href="/wiki/Ben_Nevis" title="Ben Nevis">Ben Nevis</a> which at 1,345 metres (4,413 ft)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OS_revision_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-OS_revision-186">[172]</a></sup> is the highest point in the British Isles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[173]</a></sup> Lowland areas – especially the narrow waist of land between the <a href="/wiki/Firth_of_Clyde" title="Firth of Clyde">Firth of Clyde</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Firth_of_Forth" title="Firth of Forth">Firth of Forth</a> known as the <a href="/wiki/Central_Lowlands" title="Central Lowlands">Central Belt</a> – are flatter and home to most of the population including <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, Scotland's largest city, and <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh" title="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a>, its capital and political centre, although upland and mountainous terrain lies within the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Uplands" title="Southern Uplands">Southern Uplands</a>.
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:172px;max-width:172px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:170px;max-width:170px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:126px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wormshead_view_072006_rb.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Wormshead_view_072006_rb.jpg/168px-Wormshead_view_072006_rb.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Wormshead_view_072006_rb.jpg/252px-Wormshead_view_072006_rb.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9c/Wormshead_view_072006_rb.jpg/336px-Wormshead_view_072006_rb.jpg 2x" width="168"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Worm%27s_Head" title="Worm's Head">Worm's Head</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Gower_Peninsula" title="Gower Peninsula">Gower Peninsula</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:170px;max-width:170px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:102px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Giant%27s_Causeway_-_Bushmills,_Northern_Ireland,_UK_-_August_17,_2017_09.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="6518" data-file-width="10661" decoding="async" height="103" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Giant%27s_Causeway_-_Bushmills%2C_Northern_Ireland%2C_UK_-_August_17%2C_2017_09.jpg/168px-Giant%27s_Causeway_-_Bushmills%2C_Northern_Ireland%2C_UK_-_August_17%2C_2017_09.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Giant%27s_Causeway_-_Bushmills%2C_Northern_Ireland%2C_UK_-_August_17%2C_2017_09.jpg/252px-Giant%27s_Causeway_-_Bushmills%2C_Northern_Ireland%2C_UK_-_August_17%2C_2017_09.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Giant%27s_Causeway_-_Bushmills%2C_Northern_Ireland%2C_UK_-_August_17%2C_2017_09.jpg/336px-Giant%27s_Causeway_-_Bushmills%2C_Northern_Ireland%2C_UK_-_August_17%2C_2017_09.jpg 2x" width="168"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Giant%27s_Causeway" title="Giant's Causeway">Giant's Causeway</a> in <a href="/wiki/County_Antrim" title="County Antrim">County Antrim</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Wales" title="Geography of Wales">Wales</a> accounts for less than one-tenth (9 per cent) of the total area of the UK, covering 20,779 square kilometres (8,020 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[174]</a></sup> Wales is mostly mountainous, though <a href="/wiki/South_Wales" title="South Wales">South Wales</a> is less mountainous than <a href="/wiki/North_Wales" title="North Wales">North</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mid_Wales" title="Mid Wales">mid Wales</a>. The main population and industrial areas are in South Wales, consisting of the coastal cities of <a href="/wiki/Cardiff" title="Cardiff">Cardiff</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swansea" title="Swansea">Swansea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Newport,_Wales" title="Newport, Wales">Newport</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/South_Wales_Valleys" title="South Wales Valleys">South Wales Valleys</a> to their north. The highest mountains in Wales are in <a href="/wiki/Snowdonia" title="Snowdonia">Snowdonia</a> and include <a href="/wiki/Snowdon" title="Snowdon">Snowdon</a> (<a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a>: <i lang="cy">Yr Wyddfa</i>) which, at 1,085 metres (3,560 ft), is the highest peak in Wales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_177-2"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-177">[163]</a></sup> Wales has over 2,704 kilometres (1,680 miles) of coastline.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UK_coastline_180-1"><a href="#cite_note-UK_coastline-180">[166]</a></sup> Several islands lie off the Welsh mainland, the largest of which is <a href="/wiki/Anglesey" title="Anglesey">Anglesey</a> (<i>Ynys Môn</i>) in the north-west.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Ireland" title="Geography of Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>, separated from Great Britain by the <a href="/wiki/Irish_Sea" title="Irish Sea">Irish Sea</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Channel_(Great_Britain_and_Ireland)" title="North Channel (Great Britain and Ireland)">North Channel</a>, has an area of 14,160 square kilometres (5,470 sq mi) and is mostly hilly. It includes <a href="/wiki/Lough_Neagh" title="Lough Neagh">Lough Neagh</a> which, at 388 square kilometres (150 sq mi), is the largest lake in the British Isles by area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[175]</a></sup> The highest peak in Northern Ireland is <a href="/wiki/Slieve_Donard" title="Slieve Donard">Slieve Donard</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Mourne_Mountains" title="Mourne Mountains">Mourne Mountains</a> at 852 metres (2,795 ft).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Atlapedia_177-3"><a href="#cite_note-Atlapedia-177">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK contains four terrestrial ecoregions: <a href="/wiki/Celtic_broadleaf_forests" title="Celtic broadleaf forests">Celtic broadleaf forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/English_Lowlands_beech_forests" title="English Lowlands beech forests">English Lowlands beech forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_Atlantic_moist_mixed_forests" title="North Atlantic moist mixed forests">North Atlantic moist mixed forests</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Caledon_conifer_forests" title="Caledon conifer forests">Caledon conifer forests</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-190">[176]</a></sup> The country had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 1.65/10, ranking it 161th globally out of 172 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-191">[177]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Climate_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Climate of the United Kingdom">Climate of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UK_K%C3%B6ppen.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1620" data-file-width="765" decoding="async" height="318" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/UK_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/150px-UK_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/UK_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/225px-UK_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/UK_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/300px-UK_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UK_K%C3%B6ppen.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate types</a> of the UK</div></div></div>
<p>Most of the United Kingdom has a temperate climate, with generally cool temperatures and plentiful rainfall all year round.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_176-2"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-176">[162]</a></sup> The temperature varies with the seasons seldom dropping below 0 <a href="/wiki/Celsius" title="Celsius">°C</a> (32 <a href="/wiki/Fahrenheit" title="Fahrenheit">°F</a>) or rising above 30 °C (86 °F).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[178]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[179]</a></sup> Some parts, away from the coast, of upland England, Wales, Northern Ireland and most of Scotland, experience a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Subpolar_oceanic_climate" title="Subpolar oceanic climate">subpolar oceanic climate</a> (<i>Cfc</i>). Higher elevations in Scotland experience a <a href="/wiki/Subarctic_climate" title="Subarctic climate">continental subarctic climate</a> (<i>Dfc</i>) and the mountains experience a <a href="/wiki/Tundra_climate" title="Tundra climate">tundra climate</a> (<i>ET</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[180]</a></sup> The prevailing wind is from the southwest and bears frequent spells of mild and wet weather from the Atlantic Ocean,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_176-3"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-176">[162]</a></sup> although the eastern parts are mostly sheltered from this wind since the majority of the rain falls over the western regions the eastern parts are therefore the driest. Atlantic currents, warmed by the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_Stream" title="Gulf Stream">Gulf Stream</a>, bring mild winters;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[181]</a></sup> especially in the west where winters are wet and even more so over high ground. Summers are warmest in the southeast of England and coolest in the north. Heavy snowfall can occur in winter and early spring on high ground, and occasionally settles to great depth away from the hills.
</p><p>United Kingdom is ranked 4 out of 180 countries in the <a href="/wiki/Environmental_Performance_Index" title="Environmental Performance Index">Environmental Performance Index</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[182]</a></sup> A law has been passed that <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas_emissions_by_the_United_Kingdom" title="Greenhouse gas emissions by the United Kingdom">UK greenhouse gas emissions</a> will be <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Net_zero" title="Net zero">net zero</a> by 2050.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[183]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Government of the United Kingdom">Government of the United Kingdom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Politics of the United Kingdom">Politics of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tleft"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:150px;max-width:150px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:188px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Charles,_Prince_of_Wales_in_2021_(cropped)_(3).jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1159" data-file-width="915" decoding="async" height="187" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Charles%2C_Prince_of_Wales_in_2021_%28cropped%29_%283%29.jpg/148px-Charles%2C_Prince_of_Wales_in_2021_%28cropped%29_%283%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Charles%2C_Prince_of_Wales_in_2021_%28cropped%29_%283%29.jpg/222px-Charles%2C_Prince_of_Wales_in_2021_%28cropped%29_%283%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Charles%2C_Prince_of_Wales_in_2021_%28cropped%29_%283%29.jpg/296px-Charles%2C_Prince_of_Wales_in_2021_%28cropped%29_%283%29.jpg 2x" width="148"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Charles_III" title="Charles III">King Charles III</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">monarch</a> since 8 September 2022.</div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:138px;max-width:138px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:188px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Liz_Truss_official_portrait_(cropped)2.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3137" data-file-width="2260" decoding="async" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Liz_Truss_official_portrait_%28cropped%292.jpg/136px-Liz_Truss_official_portrait_%28cropped%292.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Liz_Truss_official_portrait_%28cropped%292.jpg/204px-Liz_Truss_official_portrait_%28cropped%292.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Liz_Truss_official_portrait_%28cropped%292.jpg/272px-Liz_Truss_official_portrait_%28cropped%292.jpg 2x" width="136"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Liz_Truss" title="Liz Truss">Liz Truss</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">prime minister</a> since 6 September 2022.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The United Kingdom is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a> under a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>. <a href="/wiki/Charles_III" title="Charles III">King Charles III</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">monarch</a> and head of state of the UK, as well as 14 other independent countries. These 15 countries are sometimes referred to as "<a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_realm" title="Commonwealth realm">Commonwealth realms</a>". The monarch has "the right to be consulted, the right to encourage, and the right to warn".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[184]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Constitution of the United Kingdom">Constitution of the United Kingdom</a> is <a href="/wiki/Uncodified_constitution" title="Uncodified constitution">uncodified</a> and consists mostly of a collection of disparate written sources, including <a href="/wiki/Statute" title="Statute">statutes</a>, judge-made <a href="/wiki/Case_law" title="Case law">case law</a> and international treaties, together with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Constitution#Conventions" title="British Constitution">constitutional conventions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[185]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UK_Parliament" title="UK Parliament">UK Parliament</a> can carry out constitutional reform by passing <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Parliament_(UK)" title="Act of Parliament (UK)">acts of parliament</a>, and thus has the political power to change or abolish almost any written or unwritten element of the constitution. No sitting parliament can pass laws that future parliaments cannot change.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[186]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg"><img alt="Large sand-coloured building of Gothic design beside brown river and road bridge. The building has several large towers, including large clock tower." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1826" data-file-width="5070" decoding="async" height="101" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg/280px-London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg/420px-London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg/560px-London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:London_Parliament_2007-1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Palace_of_Westminster" title="Palace of Westminster">Palace of Westminster</a>, seat of both houses of the Parliament of the United Kingdom</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:UK_Political_System.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="552" data-file-width="770" decoding="async" height="158" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/UK_Political_System.png/220px-UK_Political_System.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/UK_Political_System.png/330px-UK_Political_System.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/UK_Political_System.png/440px-UK_Political_System.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:UK_Political_System.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Organisational chart of the UK political system</div></div></div>
<p>The UK is a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary</a> <a href="/wiki/Democracy" title="Democracy">democracy</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[187]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">Parliament of the United Kingdom</a> is <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_sovereignty_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliamentary sovereignty in the United Kingdom">sovereign</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[188]</a></sup> It is made up of the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Commons_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="House of Commons of the United Kingdom">House of Commons</a>, the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Lords" title="House of Lords">House of Lords</a> and <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">the Crown</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-203">[189]</a></sup> The main business of parliament takes place in the two houses,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_203-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1-203">[189]</a></sup> but <a href="/wiki/Royal_assent" title="Royal assent">royal assent</a> is required for a bill to become an <a href="/wiki/Act_of_Parliament_(UK)" title="Act of Parliament (UK)">act of parliament</a> (law).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[190]</a></sup>
</p><p>For <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_elections_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="General elections in the United Kingdom">general elections</a> (elections to the House of Commons), the UK is divided into 650 <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_constituencies" title="United Kingdom constituencies">constituencies</a>, each of which is represented by a <a href="/wiki/Member_of_Parliament_(United_Kingdom)" title="Member of Parliament (United Kingdom)">member of Parliament</a> (MP).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-205">[191]</a></sup> MPs hold office for up to five years and are always up for re-election in general elections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_205-1"><a href="#cite_note-:2-205">[191]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Conservative_Party_(UK)" title="Conservative Party (UK)">Conservative Party</a>, <a href="/wiki/Labour_Party_(UK)" title="Labour Party (UK)">Labour Party</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scottish_National_Party" title="Scottish National Party">Scottish National Party</a> are, respectively, the current first, second and third largest parties (by number of MPs) in the House of Commons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[192]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Prime Minister of the United Kingdom">prime minister</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a> in the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[193]</a></sup> Nearly all prime ministers have served as <a href="/wiki/First_Lord_of_the_Treasury" title="First Lord of the Treasury">First Lord of the Treasury</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[194]</a></sup> and all prime ministers have continuously served as First Lord of the Treasury since 1905,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[195]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_the_Civil_Service" title="Minister for the Civil Service">Minister for the Civil Service</a> since 1968<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[196]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Minister_for_the_Union" title="Minister for the Union">Minister for the Union</a> since 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[197]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[198]</a></sup> In modern times, the prime minister is, by <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_conventions_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Constitutional conventions of the United Kingdom">constitutional convention</a>, an MP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-:3-213">[199]</a></sup> The prime minister is appointed by the monarch<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[200]</a></sup> and their appointment is governed by constitutional conventions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_205-2"><a href="#cite_note-:2-205">[191]</a></sup> However, they are normally the leader of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Political_Parties_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Political Parties of the United Kingdom">political party</a> with the most seats in the House of Commons<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[201]</a></sup> and hold office by virtue of their ability to command the confidence of the House of Commons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_213-1"><a href="#cite_note-:3-213">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>The prime minister not only has statutory functions (alongside other ministers),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[202]</a></sup> but is the monarch's principal adviser<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[203]</a></sup> and it is for them to advise the monarch on the exercise of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_prerogative_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Royal prerogative in the United Kingdom">royal prerogative</a> in relation to government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_213-2"><a href="#cite_note-:3-213">[199]</a></sup> In particular, the prime minister recommends the appointment of <a href="/wiki/List_of_government_ministers_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of government ministers of the United Kingdom">ministers</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_213-3"><a href="#cite_note-:3-213">[199]</a></sup> and chairs the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Cabinet of the United Kingdom">Cabinet</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[204]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_geography_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Administrative geography of the United Kingdom">Administrative geography of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright" style=""><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px"><div class="thumbimage noresize" style="width:250px;">
<div style="text-align: center;"><div class="noresize" role="img" style="width: 250px; line-height: 1; text-align: center; background-color: #ffffff; position: relative;"><img alt="" data-file-height="1313" data-file-width="759" decoding="async" height="432" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/United_Kingdom_countries.svg/250px-United_Kingdom_countries.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/United_Kingdom_countries.svg/375px-United_Kingdom_countries.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/United_Kingdom_countries.svg/500px-United_Kingdom_countries.svg.png 2x" width="250"/>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:150.25px; top:292px"><big>England</big></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:87.75px; top:167px"><big>Scotland</big></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:94px; top:317px"><big><a href="/wiki/Wales" title="Wales">Wales</a></big></div>
<div style="position:absolute; font-size:85%; left:31.5px; top:229.5px"><big><a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland" title="Northern Ireland">Northern<br/>Ireland</a></big></div>
</div></div></div><div class="thumbcaption">The four <a href="/wiki/Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Countries of the United Kingdom">countries of the United Kingdom</a></div></div></div>
<p>The geographical division of the United Kingdom into <a href="/wiki/Counties_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Counties of the United Kingdom">counties</a> or shires began in England and Scotland in the early Middle Ages and was complete throughout Great Britain and Ireland by the early Modern Period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[205]</a></sup> Administrative arrangements were developed separately in each country of the United Kingdom, with origins which often predated the formation of the United Kingdom. Modern local government by elected councils, partly based on the ancient counties, was introduced separately: in England and Wales in a <a href="/wiki/Local_Government_Act_1888" title="Local Government Act 1888">1888 act</a>, Scotland in a <a href="/wiki/Local_Government_(Scotland)_Act_1889" title="Local Government (Scotland) Act 1889">1889 act</a> and Ireland in a <a href="/wiki/Local_Government_(Ireland)_Act_1898" title="Local Government (Ireland) Act 1898">1898 act</a>, meaning there is no consistent system of administrative or geographic demarcation across the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN-220">[206]</a></sup>
Until the 19th century there was little change to those arrangements, but there has since been a constant evolution of role and function.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-barlow_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-barlow-221">[207]</a></sup>
</p><p>The organisation of <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_England" title="Local government in England">local government in England</a> is complex, with the distribution of functions varying according to local arrangements. The upper-tier <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_England" title="Subdivisions of England">subdivisions of England</a> are the nine <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_England" title="Regions of England">regions</a>, now used primarily for statistical purposes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[208]</a></sup> One region, <a href="/wiki/Greater_London_Authority" title="Greater London Authority">Greater London</a>, has had a directly elected assembly and mayor since 2000 following popular support for the proposal in a <a href="/wiki/1998_Greater_London_Authority_referendum" title="1998 Greater London Authority referendum">referendum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[209]</a></sup> It was intended that other regions would also be given their own elected <a href="/wiki/Regional_assembly_(England)" title="Regional assembly (England)">regional assemblies</a>, but a proposed assembly in the <a href="/wiki/North_East_England" title="North East England">North East</a> region was rejected by a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2004_Northern_England_devolution_referendums" title="2004 Northern England devolution referendums">referendum in 2004</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[210]</a></sup> Since 2011, ten <a href="/wiki/Combined_authority" title="Combined authority">combined authorities</a> have been established in England. Eight of these have <a href="/wiki/Directly_elected_mayors_in_England_and_Wales" title="Directly elected mayors in England and Wales">elected mayors</a>, the first elections for which took place on 4 May 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[211]</a></sup> Below the regional tier, some parts of England have <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_and_non-metropolitan_counties_of_England" title="Metropolitan and non-metropolitan counties of England">county councils</a> and district councils and others have <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unitary_authorities" title="Unitary authorities">unitary authorities</a>, while London consists of 32 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_borough" title="London borough">London boroughs</a> and the <a href="/wiki/City_of_London" title="City of London">City of London</a>. Councillors are elected by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plurality_voting_system" title="Plurality voting system">first-past-the-post</a> system in single-member wards or by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Plurality-at-large_voting" title="Plurality-at-large voting">multi-member plurality system</a> in multi-member wards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[212]</a></sup>
</p><p>For <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Scotland" title="Local government in Scotland">local government purposes</a>, Scotland is divided into <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Scotland" title="Subdivisions of Scotland">32 council areas</a>, with wide variation in both size and population. The cities of <a href="/wiki/Glasgow" title="Glasgow">Glasgow</a>, Edinburgh, <a href="/wiki/Aberdeen" title="Aberdeen">Aberdeen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dundee" title="Dundee">Dundee</a> are separate council areas, as is the <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_Highland_council_area" title="Politics of the Highland council area">Highland Council</a>, which includes a third of Scotland's area but only just over 200,000 people. Local councils are made up of elected councillors, of whom there are 1,223;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[213]</a></sup> they are paid a part-time salary. Elections are conducted by <a href="/wiki/Single_transferable_vote" title="Single transferable vote">single transferable vote</a> in multi-member wards that elect either three or four councillors. Each council elects a <a href="/wiki/Provost_(civil)" title="Provost (civil)">Provost</a>, or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chairman" title="Chairman">Convenor</a>, to chair meetings of the council and to act as a figurehead for the area.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Wales" title="Local government in Wales">Local government in Wales</a> consists of 22 unitary authorities. All unitary authorities are led by a leader and cabinet elected by the council itself. These include the cities of Cardiff, Swansea and Newport, which are unitary authorities in their own right.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unitary_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-unitary-228">[214]</a></sup> Elections are held every four years under the first-past-the-post system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-unitary_228-1"><a href="#cite_note-unitary-228">[214]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Local government in Northern Ireland">Local government in Northern Ireland</a> has since 1973 been organised into 26 district councils, each elected by single transferable vote. Their powers are limited to services such as collecting waste, controlling dogs and maintaining parks and cemeteries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[215]</a></sup> In 2008 the executive agreed on proposals to create 11 new councils and replace the present system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[216]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Devolved_governments">Devolved governments</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Devolution_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Devolution in the United Kingdom">Devolution in the United Kingdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_current_heads_of_government_in_the_United_Kingdom_and_dependencies#Countries_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of current heads of government in the United Kingdom and dependencies">List of leaders of devolved administrations</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Executive" title="Northern Ireland Executive">Northern Ireland Executive</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">Scottish Government</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Government" title="Welsh Government">Welsh Government</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg"><img alt="Modern one-story building with grass on roof and large sculpted grass area in front. Behind are residential buildings in a mixture of styles." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3024" data-file-width="4544" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg/220px-Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg/330px-Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cc/Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg/440px-Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Scottish_Parliament_Debating_Chamber_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament_Building" title="Scottish Parliament Building">Scottish Parliament Building</a> in <a href="/wiki/Holyrood,_Edinburgh" title="Holyrood, Edinburgh">Holyrood</a> is the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">Scottish Parliament</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have their own <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">government or executive</a>, led by a <a href="/wiki/First_minister" title="First minister">first minister</a> (or, in the case of Northern Ireland, a diarchal <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_minister_and_deputy_first_minister" title="First minister and deputy first minister">first minister and deputy first minister</a>), and a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Devolved" title="Devolved">devolved</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Unicameral" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> legislature. England, the largest country of the United Kingdom, has no devolved executive or legislature and is administered and legislated for directly by the UK's government and parliament on all issues. This situation has given rise to the so-called <a href="/wiki/West_Lothian_question" title="West Lothian question">West Lothian question</a>, which concerns the fact that members of parliament from Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland can vote, sometimes decisively,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[217]</a></sup> on matters that affect only England.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[218]</a></sup> The 2013 <a href="/wiki/Commission_on_the_consequences_of_devolution_for_the_House_of_Commons" title="Commission on the consequences of devolution for the House of Commons">McKay Commission</a> on this recommended that laws affecting only England should need support from a majority of English members of parliament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbcnews250313_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbcnews250313-233">[219]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">Scottish Government</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Parliament" title="Scottish Parliament">Parliament</a> have wide-ranging powers over any matter that has not been specifically <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Reserved_and_excepted_matters" title="Reserved and excepted matters">reserved</a> to the UK Parliament, including <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Scotland" title="Education in Scotland">education</a>, <a href="/wiki/NHS_Scotland" title="NHS Scotland">healthcare</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scots_law" title="Scots law">Scots law</a> and <a href="/wiki/Local_government_in_Scotland" title="Local government in Scotland">local government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[220]</a></sup> Their power over economic issues is significantly constrained by an act of the UK parliament passed in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UKIM_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-UKIM-241">[227]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:British_Irish_Council_at_Stirling_Castle_(7420592874).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2061" data-file-width="4256" decoding="async" height="126" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/British_Irish_Council_at_Stirling_Castle_%287420592874%29.jpg/260px-British_Irish_Council_at_Stirling_Castle_%287420592874%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/British_Irish_Council_at_Stirling_Castle_%287420592874%29.jpg/390px-British_Irish_Council_at_Stirling_Castle_%287420592874%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/British_Irish_Council_at_Stirling_Castle_%287420592874%29.jpg/520px-British_Irish_Council_at_Stirling_Castle_%287420592874%29.jpg 2x" width="260"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:British_Irish_Council_at_Stirling_Castle_(7420592874).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British-Irish_Council" title="British-Irish Council">British-Irish Council</a> comprises the UK Government, the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ireland" title="Government of Ireland">Irish Government</a> and the governments of Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Government" title="Welsh Government">Welsh Government</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Senedd" title="Senedd">Senedd</a> (Welsh Parliament; formerly the National Assembly for Wales)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[228]</a></sup> have more limited powers than those devolved to Scotland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[229]</a></sup> The Senedd is able to legislate on any matter not specifically reserved to the UK Parliament through <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acts_of_Senedd_Cymru" title="Acts of Senedd Cymru">Acts of Senedd Cymru</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Executive" title="Northern Ireland Executive">Northern Ireland Executive</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Assembly" title="Northern Ireland Assembly">Assembly</a> have powers similar to those devolved to Scotland. The Executive is led by a <a href="/wiki/Diarchy" title="Diarchy">diarchy</a> representing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Designated_Unionist" title="Designated Unionist">unionist</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Designated_Nationalist" title="Designated Nationalist">nationalist</a> members of the Assembly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-northernireland1_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-northernireland1-244">[230]</a></sup> Devolution to Northern Ireland is contingent on participation by the Northern Ireland administration in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/North-South_Ministerial_Council" title="North-South Ministerial Council">North-South Ministerial Council</a>, where the Northern Ireland Executive cooperates and develops joint and shared policies with the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ireland" title="Government of Ireland">Government of Ireland</a>. The British and Irish governments co-operate on non-devolved matters affecting Northern Ireland through the <a href="/wiki/British%E2%80%93Irish_Intergovernmental_Conference" title="British–Irish Intergovernmental Conference">British–Irish Intergovernmental Conference</a>, which assumes the responsibilities of the Northern Ireland administration in the event of its non-operation.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The UK does not have a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Codified_constitution" title="Codified constitution">codified constitution</a> and constitutional matters are not among the powers devolved to Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland. Under the doctrine of <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_sovereignty_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliamentary sovereignty in the United Kingdom">parliamentary sovereignty</a>, the UK Parliament could, in theory, therefore, abolish the Scottish Parliament, Senedd or Northern Ireland Assembly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[231]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[232]</a></sup> Indeed, in 1972, the UK Parliament <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_(Temporary_Provisions)_Act_1972" title="Northern Ireland (Temporary Provisions) Act 1972">unilaterally prorogued</a> the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Northern_Ireland" title="Parliament of Northern Ireland">Parliament of Northern Ireland</a>, setting a precedent relevant to contemporary devolved institutions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[233]</a></sup> In practice, it would be politically difficult for the UK Parliament to abolish devolution to the Scottish Parliament and the Senedd, given the political entrenchment created by referendum decisions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[234]</a></sup> The political constraints placed upon the UK Parliament's power to interfere with devolution in Northern Ireland are even greater than in relation to Scotland and Wales, given that devolution in Northern Ireland rests upon an international agreement with the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ireland" title="Government of Ireland">Government of Ireland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[235]</a></sup> The UK Parliament restricts the three devolved parliaments' legislative competence in economic areas through an Act passed in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UKIM_241-1"><a href="#cite_note-UKIM-241">[227]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Dependencies">Dependencies</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">British Overseas Territories</a>, <a href="/wiki/Crown_Dependencies" title="Crown Dependencies">Crown Dependencies</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Islands" title="British Islands">British Islands</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_current_heads_of_government_in_the_United_Kingdom_and_dependencies#Crown_dependencies" title="List of current heads of government in the United Kingdom and dependencies">List of leaders of British dependencies</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="1600" decoding="async" height="188" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg/250px-Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg/375px-Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg/500px-Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cap_Juluca_-_Anguilla.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Anguilla" title="Anguilla">Anguilla</a>: Cap Juluca, Maundays Bay</div></div></div>
<p>The United Kingdom has responsibility for 17 territories that do not form part of the United Kingdom itself: 14 British Overseas Territories<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-overseasterrirories_47-1"><a href="#cite_note-overseasterrirories-47">[34]</a></sup> and three Crown Dependencies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-overseasterrirories_47-2"><a href="#cite_note-overseasterrirories-47">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[238]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 14 British Overseas Territories are remnants of the British Empire: <a href="/wiki/Anguilla" title="Anguilla">Anguilla</a>; <a href="/wiki/Bermuda" title="Bermuda">Bermuda</a>; the <a href="/wiki/British_Antarctic_Territory" title="British Antarctic Territory">British Antarctic Territory</a>; the <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Ocean_Territory" title="British Indian Ocean Territory">British Indian Ocean Territory</a>; the <a href="/wiki/British_Virgin_Islands" title="British Virgin Islands">British Virgin Islands</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Cayman_Islands" title="Cayman Islands">Cayman Islands</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands" title="Falkland Islands">Falkland Islands</a>; <a href="/wiki/Gibraltar" title="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>; <a href="/wiki/Montserrat" title="Montserrat">Montserrat</a>; <a href="/wiki/Saint_Helena,_Ascension_and_Tristan_da_Cunha" title="Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha">Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Turks_and_Caicos_Islands" title="Turks and Caicos Islands">Turks and Caicos Islands</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Pitcairn_Islands" title="Pitcairn Islands">Pitcairn Islands</a>; <a href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands" title="South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands">South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Akrotiri_and_Dhekelia" title="Akrotiri and Dhekelia">Akrotiri and Dhekelia</a> on the island of <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-253"><a href="#cite_note-253">[239]</a></sup> British claims in Antarctica have limited international recognition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[240]</a></sup> Collectively Britain's overseas territories encompass an approximate land area of 480,000 square nautical miles (640,000 sq mi; 1,600,000 km<sup>2</sup>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[241]</a></sup> with a total population of approximately 250,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[242]</a></sup> The overseas territories also give the UK the world's fifth largest <a href="/wiki/Exclusive_economic_zone_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Exclusive economic zone of the United Kingdom">exclusive economic zone</a> at 6,805,586 km<sup>2</sup> (2,627,651 sq mi).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[243]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (January 2021)">better source needed</span></a></i>]</sup> A 1999 UK government <a href="/wiki/White_paper" title="White paper">white paper</a> stated that: "[The] Overseas Territories are British for as long as they wish to remain British. Britain has willingly granted independence where it has been requested; and we will continue to do so where this is an option."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[244]</a></sup> Self-determination is also enshrined in the constitutions of several overseas territories and three have specifically voted to remain under British sovereignty (Bermuda in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1995_Bermudan_independence_referendum" title="1995 Bermudan independence referendum">1995</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Independent_results_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-Independent_results-259">[245]</a></sup> Gibraltar in <a href="/wiki/2002_Gibraltar_sovereignty_referendum" title="2002 Gibraltar sovereignty referendum">2002</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[246]</a></sup> and the Falkland Islands in <a href="/wiki/2013_Falkland_Islands_sovereignty_referendum" title="2013 Falkland Islands sovereignty referendum">2013</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[247]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Crown dependencies are possessions of <a href="/wiki/The_Crown" title="The Crown">the Crown</a>, as opposed to overseas territories of the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[248]</a></sup> They comprise three independently administered jurisdictions: the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Channel_Island" title="Channel Island">Channel Islands</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jersey" title="Jersey">Jersey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Guernsey" title="Guernsey">Guernsey</a> in the English Channel, and the <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" title="Isle of Man">Isle of Man</a> in the Irish Sea. By mutual agreement, the British Government manages the islands' foreign affairs and defence and the UK Parliament has the authority to legislate on their behalf. Internationally, they are regarded as "territories for which the United Kingdom is responsible".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-International_recognition_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-International_recognition-263">[249]</a></sup> The power to pass legislation affecting the islands ultimately rests with their own respective legislative assemblies, with the assent of the Crown (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Her_Majesty%27s_Most_Honourable_Privy_Council" title="Her Majesty's Most Honourable Privy Council">Privy Council</a> or, in the case of the Isle of Man, in certain circumstances the Lieutenant-Governor).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[250]</a></sup> Since 2005 each Crown dependency has had a <a href="/wiki/List_of_current_heads_of_government_in_the_United_Kingdom_and_dependencies#Crown_Dependencies" title="List of current heads of government in the United Kingdom and dependencies">Chief Minister</a> as its <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[251]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:802px;"><div class="noresize"><map name="ImageMap_cf0b272132ac6571"><area alt="Akrotiri and Dhekelia"
