<a href="/wiki/Falkland_Islands" title="Falkland Islands">Falkland Islands</a>; <b>14</b> <a href="/wiki/South_Georgia_and_the_South_Sandwich_Islands" title="South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands">South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands</a>; <b>(15)</b> <a href="/wiki/British_Antarctic_Territory" title="British Antarctic Territory">British Antarctic Territory</a></div></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_criminal_justice">Law and criminal justice</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Law of the United Kingdom">Law of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Royal_Courts_of_Justice_2019.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2764" data-file-width="4146" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Royal_Courts_of_Justice_2019.jpg/220px-Royal_Courts_of_Justice_2019.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Royal_Courts_of_Justice_2019.jpg/330px-Royal_Courts_of_Justice_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7c/Royal_Courts_of_Justice_2019.jpg/440px-Royal_Courts_of_Justice_2019.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Royal_Courts_of_Justice_2019.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Courts_of_Justice" title="Royal Courts of Justice">Royal Courts of Justice</a> of <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales" title="England and Wales">England and Wales</a></div></div></div>
<p>The United Kingdom does not have a single legal system as Article 19 of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Union" title="Treaty of Union">1706 Treaty of Union</a> provided for the continuation of Scotland's separate legal system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[252]</a></sup> Today the UK has three distinct <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legal_systems_of_the_world" title="Legal systems of the world">systems of law</a>: <a href="/wiki/English_law" title="English law">English law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Courts_of_Northern_Ireland" title="Courts of Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland law</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scots_law" title="Scots law">Scots law</a>. A new <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Supreme Court of the United Kingdom">Supreme Court of the United Kingdom</a> came into being in October 2009 to replace the <a href="/wiki/Judicial_functions_of_the_House_of_Lords" title="Judicial functions of the House of Lords">Appellate Committee of the House of Lords</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[254]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Judicial_Committee_of_the_Privy_Council" title="Judicial Committee of the Privy Council">Judicial Committee of the Privy Council</a>, including the same members as the Supreme Court, is the highest court of appeal for several independent Commonwealth countries, the <a href="/wiki/British_Overseas_Territories" title="British Overseas Territories">British Overseas Territories</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Crown_Dependencies" title="Crown Dependencies">Crown Dependencies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[255]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="267" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg/200px-High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg/300px-High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg/400px-High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:High_Court_of_Justiciary.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justiciary" title="High Court of Justiciary">High Court of Justiciary</a>, the <a href="/wiki/College_of_Justice" title="College of Justice">supreme</a> <a href="/wiki/Criminal_justice" title="Criminal justice">criminal court</a> of <a href="/wiki/Scotland" title="Scotland">Scotland</a></div></div></div>
<p>Both English law, which applies in <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales" title="England and Wales">England and Wales</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_law" title="Northern Ireland law">Northern Ireland law</a> are based on <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">common-law</a> principles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[256]</a></sup> The essence of common law is that, subject to statute, the law is developed by judges in courts, applying statute, <a href="/wiki/Precedent" title="Precedent">precedent</a> and common sense to the facts before them to give explanatory judgements of the relevant legal principles, which are reported and binding in future similar cases (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stare_decisis" title="Stare decisis">stare decisis</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[257]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Courts_of_England_and_Wales" title="Courts of England and Wales">courts of England and Wales</a> are headed by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senior_Courts_of_England_and_Wales" title="Senior Courts of England and Wales">Senior Courts of England and Wales</a>, consisting of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Court_of_Appeal_of_England_and_Wales" title="Court of Appeal of England and Wales">Court of Appeal</a>, the <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justice" title="High Court of Justice">High Court of Justice</a> (for civil cases) and the <a href="/wiki/Crown_Court" title="Crown Court">Crown Court</a> (for criminal cases). The Supreme Court is the highest court in the land for both criminal and civil appeal cases in England, Wales and Northern Ireland and any decision it makes is binding on every other court in the same jurisdiction, often having a persuasive effect in other jurisdictions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[258]</a></sup>
</p><p>Scots law is a hybrid system based on both common-law and <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil-law</a> principles. The chief courts are the <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Session" title="Court of Session">Court of Session</a>, for civil cases,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[259]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Justiciary" title="High Court of Justiciary">High Court of Justiciary</a>, for criminal cases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[260]</a></sup> The Supreme Court of the United Kingdom serves as the highest court of appeal for civil cases under Scots law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[261]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sheriff_Court" title="Sheriff Court">Sheriff courts</a> deal with most civil and criminal cases including conducting criminal trials with a jury, known as sheriff solemn court, or with a sheriff and no jury, known as sheriff summary Court.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[262]</a></sup> The Scots legal system is unique in having three possible <a href="/wiki/Verdict" title="Verdict">verdicts</a> for a criminal trial: "<a href="/wiki/Guilt_(law)" title="Guilt (law)">guilty</a>", "<a href="/wiki/Acquittal" title="Acquittal">not guilty</a>" and "<a href="/wiki/Not_proven" title="Not proven">not proven</a>". Both "not guilty" and "not proven" result in an acquittal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[263]</a></sup>
</p><p>Crime in England and Wales increased in the period between 1981 and 1995, though since that peak there has been an overall fall of 66 per cent in recorded crime from 1995 to 2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[264]</a></sup> according to <a href="/wiki/Crime_statistics_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Crime statistics in the United Kingdom">crime statistics</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prison_population_of_England_and_Wales" title="Prison population of England and Wales">prison population of England and Wales</a> has increased to 86,000, giving England and Wales the highest rate of incarceration in Western Europe at 148 per 100,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ICPS_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-ICPS-280">[266]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/His_Majesty%27s_Prison_Service" title="His Majesty's Prison Service">His Majesty's Prison Service</a>, which reports to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Justice_(United_Kingdom)" title="Ministry of Justice (United Kingdom)">Ministry of Justice</a>, manages most of the prisons within England and Wales. The murder rate in England and Wales has stabilised in the first half of the 2010s with a murder rate around 1 per 100,000 which is half the peak in 2002 and similar to the rate in the 1980s<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[267]</a></sup> Crime in Scotland fell slightly in 2014–2015 to its lowest level in 39 years in with 59 killings for a murder rate of 1.1 per 100,000. Scotland's prisons are overcrowded but the prison population is shrinking.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[268]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Foreign relations of the United Kingdom">Foreign relations of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<p>The UK is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Big_Five_(United_Nations)" title="Big Five (United Nations)">permanent member</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council" title="United Nations Security Council">United Nations Security Council</a>, a member of <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, <a href="/wiki/AUKUS" title="AUKUS">AUKUS</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G7_finance_ministers" title="G7 finance ministers">G7 finance ministers</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G7_forum" title="G7 forum">G7 forum</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/G-20_major_economies" title="G-20 major economies">G20</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">OECD</a>, the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[269]</a></sup> The UK is said to have a "<a href="/wiki/Special_Relationship" title="Special Relationship">Special Relationship</a>" with the United States and a close partnership with France – the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Entente_cordiale" title="Entente cordiale">Entente cordiale</a>" – and shares nuclear weapons technology with both countries;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[270]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[271]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Portuguese_Alliance" title="Anglo-Portuguese Alliance">Anglo-Portuguese Alliance</a> is considered to be the oldest binding military alliance in the world. The UK is also closely linked with the Republic of Ireland; the two countries share a <a href="/wiki/Common_Travel_Area" title="Common Travel Area">Common Travel Area</a> and co-operate through the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British-Irish_Intergovernmental_Conference" title="British-Irish Intergovernmental Conference">British-Irish Intergovernmental Conference</a> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British-Irish_Council" title="British-Irish Council">British-Irish Council</a>. Britain's global presence and influence is further amplified through its trading relations, foreign investments, <a href="/wiki/Official_development_assistance" title="Official development assistance">official development assistance</a> and military engagements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[272]</a></sup> Canada, Australia and New Zealand, all of which are former colonies of the British Empire which share King Charles as their head of state, are the most favourably viewed countries in the world by <a href="/wiki/British_people" title="British people">British people</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[273]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[274]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[275]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/British_Armed_Forces" title="British Armed Forces">British Armed Forces</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_and_HMS_Prince_of_Wales_meet_at_sea_for_the_first_time.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1000" data-file-width="1500" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_and_HMS_Prince_of_Wales_meet_at_sea_for_the_first_time.jpg/220px-HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_and_HMS_Prince_of_Wales_meet_at_sea_for_the_first_time.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_and_HMS_Prince_of_Wales_meet_at_sea_for_the_first_time.jpg/330px-HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_and_HMS_Prince_of_Wales_meet_at_sea_for_the_first_time.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_and_HMS_Prince_of_Wales_meet_at_sea_for_the_first_time.jpg/440px-HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_and_HMS_Prince_of_Wales_meet_at_sea_for_the_first_time.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_and_HMS_Prince_of_Wales_meet_at_sea_for_the_first_time.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/HMS_Queen_Elizabeth_(R08)" title="HMS Queen Elizabeth (R08)">HMS <i>Queen Elizabeth</i></a> and <a href="/wiki/HMS_Prince_of_Wales_(R09)" title="HMS Prince of Wales (R09)">HMS <i>Prince of Wales</i></a>, a pair of <a href="/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth-class_aircraft_carrier" title="Queen Elizabeth-class aircraft carrier"><i>Queen Elizabeth</i>-class aircraft carriers</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Trident_II_missile_image.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="2486" decoding="async" height="265" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Trident_II_missile_image.jpg/220px-Trident_II_missile_image.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Trident_II_missile_image.jpg/330px-Trident_II_missile_image.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Trident_II_missile_image.jpg/440px-Trident_II_missile_image.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Trident_II_missile_image.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Test launch of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trident_missile" title="Trident missile">Trident II</a> nuclear missile by a <a href="/wiki/Vanguard-class_submarine" title="Vanguard-class submarine"><i>Vanguard</i>-class submarine</a></div></div></div>
<p><i><a href="/wiki/British_Armed_Forces" title="British Armed Forces">His Majesty's Armed Forces</a></i> consist of three professional service branches: the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Royal_Marines" title="Royal Marines">Royal Marines</a> (forming the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Naval_Service_(United_Kingdom)" title="Naval Service (United Kingdom)">Naval Service</a>), the <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">British Army</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Air_Force" title="Royal Air Force">Royal Air Force</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[276]</a></sup> The armed forces of the United Kingdom are managed by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(United_Kingdom)" title="Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)">Ministry of Defence</a> and controlled by the <a href="/wiki/Defence_Council_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Defence Council of the United Kingdom">Defence Council</a>, chaired by the <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Defence" title="Secretary of State for Defence">Secretary of State for Defence</a>. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commander-in-Chief" title="Commander-in-Chief">Commander-in-Chief</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">British monarch</a>, to whom members of the forces swear an oath of allegiance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Speaker_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-Speaker-291">[277]</a></sup> The Armed Forces are charged with protecting the UK and its overseas territories, promoting the UK's global security interests and supporting international peacekeeping efforts. They are active and regular participants in <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Allied_Rapid_Reaction_Corps" title="Allied Rapid Reaction Corps">Allied Rapid Reaction Corps</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Five_Power_Defence_Arrangements" title="Five Power Defence Arrangements">Five Power Defence Arrangements</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RIMPAC" title="RIMPAC">RIMPAC</a> and other worldwide coalition operations. <a href="/wiki/Overseas_military_bases_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Overseas military bases of the United Kingdom">Overseas garrisons</a> and facilities are maintained in <a href="/wiki/RAF_Ascension_Island" title="RAF Ascension Island">Ascension Island</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mina_Salman" title="Mina Salman">Bahrain</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_of_Belize" title="Military of Belize">Belize</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Military_Forces_based_in_Brunei" title="Military Forces based in Brunei">Brunei</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Army_Training_Unit_Suffield" title="British Army Training Unit Suffield">Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Forces_Cyprus" title="British Forces Cyprus">Cyprus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diego_Garcia" title="Diego Garcia">Diego Garcia</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Military_of_the_Falkland_Islands" title="Military of the Falkland Islands">Falkland Islands</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Forces_Germany" title="British Forces Germany">Germany</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Forces_Gibraltar" title="British Forces Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Army_Training_Unit_Kenya" title="British Army Training Unit Kenya">Kenya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oman" title="Oman">Oman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Al_Udeid_Air_Base" title="Al Udeid Air Base">Qatar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Singapore" title="Singapore">Singapore</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Facilities_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-Facilities-292">[278]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[279]</a></sup>
</p><p>The British armed forces played a key role in establishing the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Superpower" title="Superpower">dominant world power</a> in the 18th, 19th and early 20th centuries. By emerging victorious from conflicts, Britain has often been able to decisively <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_relations_of_the_Great_Powers_(1814%E2%80%931919)" title="International relations of the Great Powers (1814–1919)">influence world events</a>. Since the end of the British Empire, the UK has remained a major military power. Following the end of the <a href="/wiki/Cold_War" title="Cold War">Cold War</a>, defence policy has a stated assumption that "the most demanding operations" will be undertaken as part of a coalition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[280]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to sources which include the <a href="/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute" title="Stockholm International Peace Research Institute">Stockholm International Peace Research Institute</a> and the <a href="/wiki/International_Institute_for_Strategic_Studies" title="International Institute for Strategic Studies">International Institute for Strategic Studies</a>, the UK has either the fourth- or the fifth-highest <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_military_expenditures" title="List of countries by military expenditures">military expenditure</a>. Total defence spending amounts to 2.0 per cent of national GDP.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SIPRI_295-0"><a href="#cite_note-SIPRI-295">[281]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Economy of the United Kingdom">Economy of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Overview">Overview</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Banco_de_Inglaterra,_Londres,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-11,_DD_141.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3548" data-file-width="4978" decoding="async" height="157" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Banco_de_Inglaterra%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_141.JPG/220px-Banco_de_Inglaterra%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_141.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Banco_de_Inglaterra%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_141.JPG/330px-Banco_de_Inglaterra%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_141.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Banco_de_Inglaterra%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_141.JPG/440px-Banco_de_Inglaterra%2C_Londres%2C_Inglaterra%2C_2014-08-11%2C_DD_141.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Banco_de_Inglaterra,_Londres,_Inglaterra,_2014-08-11,_DD_141.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Central_bank" title="Central bank">central bank</a> of the United Kingdom and the model on which most modern central banks have been based</div></div></div>
<p>The UK has a partially regulated <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[282]</a></sup> Based on market <a href="/wiki/Exchange_rate" title="Exchange rate">exchange rates</a>, the UK is today the fifth-largest economy in the world and the second-largest in Europe after Germany. <a href="/wiki/HM_Treasury" title="HM Treasury">HM Treasury</a>, led by the <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_of_the_Exchequer" title="Chancellor of the Exchequer">Chancellor of the Exchequer</a>, is responsible for developing and executing the government's <a href="/wiki/Public_finance" title="Public finance">public finance</a> policy and <a href="/wiki/Economic_policy" title="Economic policy">economic policy</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_England" title="Bank of England">Bank of England</a> is the UK's <a href="/wiki/Central_bank" title="Central bank">central bank</a> and is responsible for issuing notes and coins in the nation's currency, the <a href="/wiki/Pound_sterling" title="Pound sterling">pound sterling</a>. Banks in Scotland and Northern Ireland retain the right to issue their own notes, subject to retaining enough Bank of England notes in reserve to cover their issue. The pound sterling is the world's fourth-largest <a href="/wiki/Reserve_currency" title="Reserve currency">reserve currency</a> (after the US dollar, euro, and Japanese Yen).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[283]</a></sup> Since 1997 the Bank of England's <a href="/wiki/Monetary_Policy_Committee_(United_Kingdom)" title="Monetary Policy Committee (United Kingdom)">Monetary Policy Committee</a>, headed by the <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_the_Bank_of_England" title="Governor of the Bank of England">Governor of the Bank of England</a>, has been responsible for setting <a href="/wiki/Official_bank_rate" title="Official bank rate">interest rates</a> at the level necessary to achieve the overall inflation target for the economy that is set by the Chancellor each year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[284]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_sector_of_the_economy" title="Tertiary sector of the economy">service sector</a> makes up around 79 per cent of <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[285]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/London" title="London">London</a> is one of the world's largest financial centres, ranking second in the world, behind <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Financial_Centres_Index" title="Global Financial Centres Index">Global Financial Centres Index</a> in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GFCI_27_Rank_-_Long_Finance_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-GFCI_27_Rank_-_Long_Finance-300">[286]</a></sup> London also has the <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_by_GDP" title="List of cities by GDP">largest city GDP</a> in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_city_GDP_rankings_2008-2025_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-Global_city_GDP_rankings_2008-2025-301">[287]</a></sup> Edinburgh ranks 17th in the world, and sixth in Western Europe in the Global Financial Centres Index in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GFCI_27_Rank_-_Long_Finance_300-1"><a href="#cite_note-GFCI_27_Rank_-_Long_Finance-300">[286]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Tourism in the United Kingdom">Tourism</a> is very important to the British economy; with over 27 million tourists arriving in 2004, the United Kingdom is ranked as the sixth major tourist destination in the world and London has the most international visitors of any city in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[288]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[289]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Creative_industries" title="Creative industries">creative industries</a> accounted for 7 per cent GVA in 2005 and grew at an average of 6 per cent per annum between 1997 and 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[290]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the United Kingdom's withdrawal from the European Union, the functioning of the UK internal economic market is enshrined by the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_Internal_Market_Act_2020" title="United Kingdom Internal Market Act 2020">United Kingdom Internal Market Act 2020</a> which ensures trade in goods and services continues without internal barriers across the four countries of the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[291]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[292]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> started in Britain with an initial concentration on the textile industry,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Europa_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-Europa-307">[293]</a></sup> followed by other heavy industries such as <a href="/wiki/Shipbuilding" title="Shipbuilding">shipbuilding</a>, coal mining and <a href="/wiki/Steelmaking" title="Steelmaking">steelmaking</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[294]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[295]</a></sup> British merchants, shippers and bankers developed overwhelming advantage over those of other nations allowing the UK to dominate international trade in the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[296]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[297]</a></sup> As other nations industrialised, coupled with economic decline after two world wars, the United Kingdom began to lose its competitive advantage and heavy industry declined, by degrees, throughout the 20th century. Manufacturing remains a significant part of the economy but accounted for only 16.7 per cent of national output in 2003.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[298]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mini_Hatch_(F56)_Electric_IMG_2679.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2683" data-file-width="5008" decoding="async" height="118" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Mini_Hatch_%28F56%29_Electric_IMG_2679.jpg/220px-Mini_Hatch_%28F56%29_Electric_IMG_2679.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Mini_Hatch_%28F56%29_Electric_IMG_2679.jpg/330px-Mini_Hatch_%28F56%29_Electric_IMG_2679.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Mini_Hatch_%28F56%29_Electric_IMG_2679.jpg/440px-Mini_Hatch_%28F56%29_Electric_IMG_2679.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mini_Hatch_(F56)_Electric_IMG_2679.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Mini_Electric" title="Mini Electric">Mini Electric</a> is manufactured in the UK.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Automotive industry in the United Kingdom">automotive industry</a> employs around 800,000 people, with a turnover in 2015 of £70 billion, generating £34.6 billion of exports (11.8 per cent of the UK's total export goods). In 2015, the UK produced around 1.6 million passenger vehicles and 94,500 commercial vehicles. The UK is a major centre for engine manufacturing: in 2015 around 2.4 million engines were produced. The UK <a href="/wiki/Auto_racing" title="Auto racing">motorsport</a> industry employs around 41,000 people, comprises around 4,500 companies and has an annual turnover of around £6 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[299]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Aerospace_industry_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Aerospace industry in the United Kingdom">aerospace industry of the UK</a> is the second- or third-largest national aerospace industry in the world depending upon the method of measurement and has an annual turnover of around £30 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[300]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_(16948377692).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2198" data-file-width="4421" decoding="async" height="109" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_%2816948377692%29.jpg/220px-British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_%2816948377692%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_%2816948377692%29.jpg/330px-British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_%2816948377692%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_%2816948377692%29.jpg/440px-British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_%2816948377692%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:British_Airways_A380-841_G-XLEA_(16948377692).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Engines and wings for the <a href="/wiki/Airbus_A380" title="Airbus A380">Airbus A380</a> are manufactured in the UK.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/BAE_Systems" title="BAE Systems">BAE Systems</a> plays a critical role in some of the world's biggest defence aerospace projects. In the UK, the company makes large sections of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Typhoon_Eurofighter" title="Typhoon Eurofighter">Typhoon Eurofighter</a> and assembles the aircraft for the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Air_Force" title="Royal Air Force">Royal Air Force</a>. It is also a principal subcontractor on the <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_Martin_F-35_Lightning_II" title="Lockheed Martin F-35 Lightning II">F35</a> Joint Strike Fighter – the world's largest single defence project – for which it designs and manufactures a range of components. It also manufactures the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BAE_Hawk" title="BAE Hawk">Hawk</a>, the world's most successful<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="successful in what way? (November 2021)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> jet training aircraft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-theengineer.co.uk_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-theengineer.co.uk-315">[301]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Airbus_UK" title="Airbus UK">Airbus UK</a> also manufactures the wings for the <a href="/wiki/Airbus_A400M_Atlas" title="Airbus A400M Atlas">A400 m</a> military transporter. Rolls-Royce is the world's second-largest aero-engine manufacturer. Its engines power more than 30 types of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commercial_aircraft" title="Commercial aircraft">commercial aircraft</a> and it has more than 30,000 engines in service in the civil and defence sectors.
</p><p>The UK space industry was worth £9.1bn in 2011 and employed 29,000 people. It is growing at a rate of 7.5 per cent annually, according to its umbrella organisation, the <a href="/wiki/UK_Space_Agency" title="UK Space Agency">UK Space Agency</a>. In 2013, the British Government pledged £60 m to the <a href="/wiki/Skylon_(spacecraft)" title="Skylon (spacecraft)">Skylon</a> project: this investment will provide support at a "crucial stage" to allow a full-scale prototype of the <a href="/wiki/SABRE_(rocket_engine)" title="SABRE (rocket engine)">SABRE</a> engine to be built.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical_industry_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Pharmaceutical industry in the United Kingdom">pharmaceutical industry</a> plays an important role in the UK economy and the country has the third-highest share of global pharmaceutical R&amp;D expenditures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pharmsectorbis_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-pharmsectorbis-316">[302]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-317"><a href="#cite_note-317">[303]</a></sup>
</p><p>Agriculture is intensive, highly mechanised and efficient by European standards, producing about 60 per cent of food needs with less than 1.6 per cent of the labour force (535,000 workers).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[304]</a></sup> Around two-thirds of production is devoted to livestock, one-third to arable crops. The UK retains a significant, though much reduced fishing industry. It is also rich in a number of natural resources including coal, petroleum, natural gas, tin, limestone, iron ore, salt, clay, chalk, gypsum, lead, silica and an abundance of arable land.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[305]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" href="/wiki/International_financial_centre" title="International financial centre">financial centres</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Global_Financial_Centres_7_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Financial_Centres_7-320">[306]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mastercard_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mastercard-321">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-forbes.com_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-forbes.com-322">[308]</a></sup></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:239px;max-width:239px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Canary_Wharf_July_2019.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2254" data-file-width="4001" decoding="async" height="134" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Canary_Wharf_July_2019.jpg/237px-Canary_Wharf_July_2019.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Canary_Wharf_July_2019.jpg/356px-Canary_Wharf_July_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/79/Canary_Wharf_July_2019.jpg/474px-Canary_Wharf_July_2019.jpg 2x" width="237"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Canary_Wharf" title="Canary Wharf">Canary Wharf</a> is one of two main financial centres of the United Kingdom.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>In 2020, coronavirus lockdown measures caused the UK economy to suffer its biggest slump on record, shrinking by 20.4 per cent between April and June compared to the first three months of the year, to push it officially into recession for the first time in 11 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[309]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_external_debt" title="List of countries by external debt">The UK has an external debt</a> of $9.6 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Trillion_(short_scale)" title="Trillion (short scale)">trillion</a> dollars,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (November 2021)">when?</span></a></i>]</sup> which is the second-highest in the world after the US. As a percentage of GDP, external debt is 408 per cent, which is the third-highest in the world after Luxembourg and Iceland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[312]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[313]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[314]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Science and technology in the United Kingdom">Science and technology in the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stephen_Hawking.StarChild.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="359" data-file-width="250" decoding="async" height="244" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Stephen_Hawking.StarChild.jpg/170px-Stephen_Hawking.StarChild.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/e/eb/Stephen_Hawking.StarChild.jpg 1.5x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stephen_Hawking.StarChild.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Stephen_Hawking" title="Stephen Hawking">Stephen Hawking</a> (1942–2018) advanced theories in <a href="/wiki/Cosmology" title="Cosmology">cosmology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quantum_gravity" title="Quantum gravity">quantum gravity</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_holes" title="Black holes">black holes</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>England and Scotland were leading centres of the <a href="/wiki/Scientific_Revolution" title="Scientific Revolution">Scientific Revolution</a> from the 17th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[315]</a></sup> The United Kingdom led the Industrial Revolution from the 18th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Europa_307-1"><a href="#cite_note-Europa-307">[293]</a></sup> and has continued to produce scientists and engineers credited with important advances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[316]</a></sup> Major theorists from the 17th and 18th centuries include <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Newton" title="Isaac Newton">Isaac Newton</a>, whose <a href="/wiki/Newton%27s_laws_of_motion" title="Newton's laws of motion">laws of motion</a> and illumination of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gravitation" title="Gravitation">gravity</a> have been seen as a keystone of modern science;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[317]</a></sup> from the 19th century <a href="/wiki/Charles_Darwin" title="Charles Darwin">Charles Darwin</a>, whose theory of <a href="/wiki/Evolution" title="Evolution">evolution</a> by <a href="/wiki/Natural_selection" title="Natural selection">natural selection</a> was fundamental to the development of modern biology, and <a href="/wiki/James_Clerk_Maxwell" title="James Clerk Maxwell">James Clerk Maxwell</a>, who formulated classical <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Electromagnetic_theory" title="Electromagnetic theory">electromagnetic theory</a>; and more recently <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Hawking" title="Stephen Hawking">Stephen Hawking</a>, who advanced major theories in the fields of <a href="/wiki/Cosmology" title="Cosmology">cosmology</a>, <a href="/wiki/Quantum_gravity" title="Quantum gravity">quantum gravity</a> and the investigation of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Black_holes" title="Black holes">black holes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[318]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Maquina_vapor_Watt_ETSIIM.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="760" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="163" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Maquina_vapor_Watt_ETSIIM.jpg/220px-Maquina_vapor_Watt_ETSIIM.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Maquina_vapor_Watt_ETSIIM.jpg/330px-Maquina_vapor_Watt_ETSIIM.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Maquina_vapor_Watt_ETSIIM.jpg/440px-Maquina_vapor_Watt_ETSIIM.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Maquina_vapor_Watt_ETSIIM.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Watt_steam_engine" title="Watt steam engine">Watt steam engine</a>, which was fundamental in driving the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a></div></div></div>
<p>Major scientific discoveries from the 18th century include <a href="/wiki/Hydrogen" title="Hydrogen">hydrogen</a> by <a href="/wiki/Henry_Cavendish" title="Henry Cavendish">Henry Cavendish</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[319]</a></sup> from the 20th century <a href="/wiki/Penicillin" title="Penicillin">penicillin</a> by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Fleming" title="Alexander Fleming">Alexander Fleming</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[320]</a></sup> and the structure of <a href="/wiki/DNA" title="DNA">DNA</a>, by <a href="/wiki/Francis_Crick" title="Francis Crick">Francis Crick</a> and others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[321]</a></sup> Famous British engineers and inventors of the Industrial Revolution include <a href="/wiki/James_Watt" title="James Watt">James Watt</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Stephenson" title="George Stephenson">George Stephenson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Arkwright" title="Richard Arkwright">Richard Arkwright</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Stephenson" title="Robert Stephenson">Robert Stephenson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Isambard_Kingdom_Brunel" title="Isambard Kingdom Brunel">Isambard Kingdom Brunel</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[322]</a></sup> Other major engineering projects and applications by people from the UK include the <a href="/wiki/Steam_locomotive" title="Steam locomotive">steam locomotive</a>, developed by <a href="/wiki/Richard_Trevithick" title="Richard Trevithick">Richard Trevithick</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Vivian" title="Andrew Vivian">Andrew Vivian</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[323]</a></sup> from the 19th century the <a href="/wiki/Electric_motor" title="Electric motor">electric motor</a> by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Faraday" title="Michael Faraday">Michael Faraday</a>, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Analytical_engine" title="Analytical engine">first computer</a> designed by <a href="/wiki/Charles_Babbage" title="Charles Babbage">Charles Babbage</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[324]</a></sup> the first commercial <a href="/wiki/Electrical_telegraph" title="Electrical telegraph">electrical telegraph</a> by <a href="/wiki/William_Fothergill_Cooke" title="William Fothergill Cooke">William Fothergill Cooke</a> and <a href="/wiki/Charles_Wheatstone" title="Charles Wheatstone">Charles Wheatstone</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[325]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Incandescent_light_bulb" title="Incandescent light bulb">incandescent light bulb</a> by <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Swan" title="Joseph Swan">Joseph Swan</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[326]</a></sup> and the first practical telephone, patented by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Graham_Bell" title="Alexander Graham Bell">Alexander Graham Bell</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[327]</a></sup> and in the 20th century the world's first working television system by <a href="/wiki/John_Logie_Baird" title="John Logie Baird">John Logie Baird</a> and others,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[328]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Jet_engine" title="Jet engine">jet engine</a> by <a href="/wiki/Frank_Whittle" title="Frank Whittle">Frank Whittle</a>, the basis of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modern_computer" title="Modern computer">modern computer</a> by <a href="/wiki/Alan_Turing" title="Alan Turing">Alan Turing</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/World_Wide_Web" title="World Wide Web">World Wide Web</a> by <a href="/wiki/Tim_Berners-Lee" title="Tim Berners-Lee">Tim Berners-Lee</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[329]</a></sup>
</p><p>Scientific research and development remains important in British universities, with many establishing <a href="/wiki/Science_park" title="Science park">science parks</a> to facilitate production and co-operation with industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[330]</a></sup> Between 2004 and 2008 the UK produced 7 per cent of the world's scientific research papers and had an 8 per cent share of scientific citations, the third and second-highest in the world (after the United States and China, respectively).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[331]</a></sup> Scientific journals produced in the UK include <i><a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)">Nature</a></i>, the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BMJ" title="BMJ">British Medical Journal</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Lancet" title="The Lancet">The Lancet</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[332]</a></sup> The United Kingdom was ranked fourth in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> 2020 and 2021, up from fifth in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[333]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[334]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[335]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[336]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-351"><a href="#cite_note-351">[337]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Transport in the United Kingdom">Transport in the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="7140" data-file-width="8466" decoding="async" height="143" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/170px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/255px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg/340px-St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:St_Pancras_Railway_Station_2012-06-23.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/St_Pancras_railway_station" title="St Pancras railway station">London St Pancras International</a> is one of London's main domestic and international transport hubs, providing commuter and high-speed rail services across the UK and to Paris, <a href="/wiki/Lille" title="Lille">Lille</a> and <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">Brussels</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>A radial road network totals 29,145 miles (46,904 km) of main roads, 2,173 miles (3,497 km) of motorways and 213,750 miles (344,000 km) of paved roads.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-factbook_176-4"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-176">[162]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/M25_motorway" title="M25 motorway">M25</a>, encircling London, is the largest and busiest bypass in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[338]</a></sup> In 2009 there were a total of 34 million licensed vehicles in Great Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[339]</a></sup>
</p><p>The rail network in the UK is the oldest such network in the world. The system consists of five high-speed main lines (the <a href="/wiki/West_Coast_Main_Line" title="West Coast Main Line">West Coast</a>, <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_Main_Line" title="East Coast Main Line">East Coast</a>, <a href="/wiki/Midland_Main_Line" title="Midland Main Line">Midland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Great_Western_Main_Line" title="Great Western Main Line">Great Western</a> and <a href="/wiki/Great_Eastern_Main_Line" title="Great Eastern Main Line">Great Eastern</a>), which radiate from London to the rest of the country, augmented by regional rail lines and dense commuter networks within the major cities. <a href="/wiki/High_Speed_1" title="High Speed 1">High Speed 1</a> is operationally separate from the rest of the network. The world's first passenger railway running on steam was the <a href="/wiki/Stockton_and_Darlington_Railway" title="Stockton and Darlington Railway">Stockton and Darlington Railway</a>, opened in 1825. Just under five years later the world's first intercity railway was the <a href="/wiki/Liverpool_and_Manchester_Railway" title="Liverpool and Manchester Railway">Liverpool and Manchester Railway</a>, designed by <a href="/wiki/George_Stephenson" title="George Stephenson">George Stephenson</a>. The network grew rapidly as a patchwork of hundreds of separate companies during the <a href="/wiki/Victorian_era" title="Victorian era">Victorian era</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-354"><a href="#cite_note-354">[340]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[341]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[342]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK has a railway network of 10,072 miles (16,209 km) in <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Great_Britain" title="Rail transport in Great Britain">Great Britain</a> and 189 miles (304 km) in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Railways" title="Northern Ireland Railways">Northern Ireland</a>. Railways in Northern Ireland are operated by <a href="/wiki/NI_Railways" title="NI Railways">NI Railways</a>, a subsidiary of state-owned <a href="/wiki/Translink_(Northern_Ireland)" title="Translink (Northern Ireland)">Translink</a>. In Great Britain, the <a href="/wiki/British_Rail" title="British Rail">British Rail</a> network was <a href="/wiki/Privatisation_of_British_Rail" title="Privatisation of British Rail">privatised</a> between 1994 and 1997, which was followed by a rapid rise in passenger numbers. The UK was ranked eighth among national European rail systems in the 2017 European Railway Performance Index assessing intensity of use, quality of service and safety.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[343]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/High_Speed_2" title="High Speed 2">HS2</a> is a new high speed railway under construction linking up London, the Midlands, the North and Scotland serving over 25 stations, including eight of Britain's 10 largest cities and connecting around 30 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[344]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Crossrail" title="Crossrail">Crossrail</a>, opened in 2022, was Europe's largest construction project with a £15 billion projected cost.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-360"><a href="#cite_note-360">[346]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Great_British_Railways" title="Great British Railways">Great British Railways</a> is a planned <a href="/wiki/State_ownership" title="State ownership">state-owned</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Public_body" title="Public body">public body</a> that will oversee <a href="/wiki/Rail_transport_in_Great_Britain" title="Rail transport in Great Britain">rail transport in Great Britain</a> from 2023. In 2014, there were 5.2 billion bus journeys in the UK, 2.4 billion of which were in London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-govbusstats_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-govbusstats-361">[347]</a></sup> The red <a href="/wiki/Double-decker_bus" title="Double-decker bus">double-decker</a> bus has entered popular culture as an internationally recognised icon of England.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-England2_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-England2-362">[348]</a></sup> The London bus network is extensive, with over 6,800 scheduled services every weekday carrying about six million passengers on over 700 different routes making it one of the most extensive bus systems in the world and the largest in Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-363"><a href="#cite_note-363">[349]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the year from October 2009 to September 2010 UK airports handled a total of 211.4 million passengers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-caastats_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-caastats-364">[350]</a></sup> In that period the three largest airports were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/London_Heathrow_Airport" title="London Heathrow Airport">London Heathrow Airport</a> (65.6 million passengers), <a href="/wiki/Gatwick_Airport" title="Gatwick Airport">Gatwick Airport</a> (31.5 million passengers) and <a href="/wiki/London_Stansted_Airport" title="London Stansted Airport">London Stansted Airport</a> (18.9 million passengers).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-caastats_364-1"><a href="#cite_note-caastats-364">[350]</a></sup> London Heathrow Airport, located 15 miles (24 km) west of the capital, has the most international passenger traffic of any airport in the world<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc1_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc1-365">[351]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-airport_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-airport-366">[352]</a></sup> and is the hub for the UK flag carrier <a href="/wiki/British_Airways" title="British Airways">British Airways</a>, as well as <a href="/wiki/Virgin_Atlantic" title="Virgin Atlantic">Virgin Atlantic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[353]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Energy_mix_of_UK.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="850" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Energy_mix_of_UK.svg/220px-Energy_mix_of_UK.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Energy_mix_of_UK.svg/330px-Energy_mix_of_UK.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Energy_mix_of_UK.svg/440px-Energy_mix_of_UK.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Energy_mix_of_UK.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Energy mix of the United Kingdom over time</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Energy in the United Kingdom">Energy in the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ardrossan,_Scotland,_United_Kingdom.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="997" data-file-width="1501" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Ardrossan%2C_Scotland%2C_United_Kingdom.JPG/220px-Ardrossan%2C_Scotland%2C_United_Kingdom.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Ardrossan%2C_Scotland%2C_United_Kingdom.JPG/330px-Ardrossan%2C_Scotland%2C_United_Kingdom.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Ardrossan%2C_Scotland%2C_United_Kingdom.JPG/440px-Ardrossan%2C_Scotland%2C_United_Kingdom.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ardrossan,_Scotland,_United_Kingdom.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Wind turbines overlooking Ardrossan, Scotland. The UK is <a href="/wiki/Wind_power_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Wind power in the United Kingdom">one of the best sites in Europe for wind energy</a>, and wind power production is its fastest-growing supply.</div></div></div>
<p>In 2006, the UK was the world's ninth-largest consumer of energy and the 15th-largest producer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[354]</a></sup> The UK is home to a number of large energy companies, including two of the six oil and gas "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Supermajor" title="Supermajor">supermajors</a>" – <a href="/wiki/BP" title="BP">BP</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shell_plc" title="Shell plc">Shell</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[356]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, the UK produced 914 thousand barrels per day (bbl/d) of oil and consumed 1,507 thousand bbl/d.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[357]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-372"><a href="#cite_note-372">[358]</a></sup> Production is now in decline and the UK has been a net importer of oil since 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eiaoil_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoil-373">[359]</a></sup> In 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the UK had around 3.1 billion barrels of proven <a href="/wiki/North_Sea_oil" title="North Sea oil">crude oil reserves</a>, the largest of any EU member state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eiaoil_373-1"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoil-373">[359]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009, the UK was the 13th-largest producer of natural gas in the world and the largest producer in the EU.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eiagas_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-eiagas-374">[360]</a></sup> Production is now in decline and the UK has been a net importer of natural gas since 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eiagas_374-1"><a href="#cite_note-eiagas-374">[360]</a></sup>
</p><p>Coal production played a key role in the UK economy in the 19th and 20th centuries. In the mid-1970s, 130 million tonnes of coal were produced annually, not falling below 100 million tonnes until the early 1980s. During the 1980s and 1990s the industry was scaled back considerably. In 2011, the UK produced 18.3 million tonnes of coal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eiaoverview_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoverview-375">[361]</a></sup> In 2005 it had proven recoverable coal reserves of 171 million tons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eiaoverview_375-1"><a href="#cite_note-eiaoverview-375">[361]</a></sup> The UK <a href="/wiki/Coal_Authority" title="Coal Authority">Coal Authority</a> has stated there is a potential to produce between 7 billion tonnes and 16 billion tonnes of coal through <a href="/wiki/Underground_coal_gasification" title="Underground coal gasification">underground coal gasification (UCG)</a> or '<a href="/wiki/Hydraulic_fracturing" title="Hydraulic fracturing">fracking'</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coal_2_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coal_2-376">[362]</a></sup> and that, based on current UK coal consumption, such reserves could last between 200 and 400 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coal_3_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coal_3-377">[363]</a></sup> Environmental and social concerns have been raised over chemicals getting into the water table and minor earthquakes damaging homes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[365]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the late 1990s, nuclear power plants contributed around 25 per cent of total annual electricity generation in the UK, but this has gradually declined as old plants have been shut down and ageing-related problems affect plant availability. In 2012, the UK had 16 reactors normally generating about 19 per cent of its electricity. All but one of the reactors will be retired by 2023. Unlike Germany and Japan, the UK intends to build a new generation of nuclear plants from about 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-world-nuclear.org_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-world-nuclear.org-380">[366]</a></sup>
</p><p>The total of all renewable electricity sources provided for 38.9 per cent of the electricity generated in the United Kingdom in the third quarter of 2019, producing 28.8TWh of electricity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UKGOVRenewables_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-UKGOVRenewables-381">[367]</a></sup> The UK is <a href="/wiki/Wind_power_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Wind power in the United Kingdom">one of the best sites in Europe for wind energy</a>, and wind power production is its fastest-growing supply, in 2019 it generated almost 20 per cent of the UK's total electricity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-IndWind20_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-IndWind20-382">[368]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Water supply and sanitation in the United Kingdom">Water supply and sanitation in the United Kingdom</a></div>
<p>Access to improved water supply and sanitation in the UK is universal. It is estimated that 96.7 per cent of households are connected to the sewer network.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[369]</a></sup> According to the Environment Agency, total water abstraction for public water supply in the UK was 16,406 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Megalitre" title="Megalitre">megalitres</a> per day in 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[370]</a></sup>
</p><p>In England and Wales water and sewerage services are provided by 10 private regional water and sewerage companies and 13 mostly smaller private "water only" companies. In Scotland, water and sewerage services are provided by a single public company, <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Water" title="Scottish Water">Scottish Water</a>. In Northern Ireland water and sewerage services are also provided by a single public entity, <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Water" title="Northern Ireland Water">Northern Ireland Water</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[371]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demography_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Demography of the United Kingdom">Demography of the United Kingdom</a> and <a href="/wiki/British_people" title="British people">British people</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Population_density_UK_2011_census.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="16686" data-file-width="9413" decoding="async" height="390" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Population_density_UK_2011_census.png/220px-Population_density_UK_2011_census.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Population_density_UK_2011_census.png/330px-Population_density_UK_2011_census.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Population_density_UK_2011_census.png/440px-Population_density_UK_2011_census.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Population_density_UK_2011_census.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of population density in the UK as at the 2011 census</div></div></div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Census_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Census in the United Kingdom">census</a> is taken simultaneously in all parts of the UK every 10 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[372]</a></sup> In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2011" title="United Kingdom Census 2011">2011 census</a> the total population of the United Kingdom was 63,181,775.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011census_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-2011census-387">[373]</a></sup> It is the fourth-largest in Europe (after Russia, Germany and France), the fifth-largest in the Commonwealth and the 22nd-largest in the world. In mid-2014 and mid-2015 net long-term international migration contributed more to population growth. In mid-2012 and mid-2013 natural change contributed the most to population growth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop2015_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-pop2015-388">[374]</a></sup> Between 2001 and 2011 the population increased by an average annual rate of approximately 0.7 per cent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011census_387-1"><a href="#cite_note-2011census-387">[373]</a></sup> This compares to 0.3 per cent per year in the period 1991 to 2001 and 0.2 per cent in the decade 1981 to 1991.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop2010_389-0"><a href="#cite_note-pop2010-389">[375]</a></sup> The 2011 census also showed that, over the previous 100 years, the proportion of the population aged 0–14 fell from 31 per cent to 18 per cent, and the proportion of people aged 65 and over rose from 5 to 16 per cent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011census_387-2"><a href="#cite_note-2011census-387">[373]</a></sup> In 2018 the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Median_age" title="Median age">median age</a> of the UK population was 41.7 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[376]</a></sup>
</p><p>England's population in 2011 was 53 million, representing some 84 per cent of the UK total.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011_UK_censuses_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-2011_UK_censuses-391">[377]</a></sup> It is one of the most densely populated countries in the world, with 420 people resident per square kilometre in mid-2015,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pop2015_388-1"><a href="#cite_note-pop2015-388">[374]</a></sup> with a particular concentration in London and the south-east.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-392"><a href="#cite_note-392">[378]</a></sup> The 2011 census put Scotland's population at 5.3 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-393"><a href="#cite_note-393">[379]</a></sup> Wales at 3.06 million and Northern Ireland at 1.81 million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2011_UK_censuses_391-1"><a href="#cite_note-2011_UK_censuses-391">[377]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2017 the average <a href="/wiki/Total_fertility_rate" title="Total fertility rate">total fertility rate</a> (TFR) across the UK was 1.74 children born per woman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[380]</a></sup> While a rising birth rate is contributing to population growth, it remains considerably below the <a href="/wiki/Baby_boom" title="Baby boom">baby boom</a> peak of 2.95 children per woman in 1964,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Boseley_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-Boseley-395">[381]</a></sup> or the high of 6.02 children born per woman in 1815,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[382]</a></sup> below the replacement rate of 2.1, but higher than the 2001 record low of 1.63.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TFR_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-TFR-397">[383]</a></sup> In 2011, 47.3 per cent of births in the UK were to unmarried women.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[384]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Office_for_National_Statistics" title="Office for National Statistics">Office for National Statistics</a> published a bulletin in 2015 showing that, out of the UK population aged 16 and over, 1.7 per cent identify as gay, lesbian, or bisexual (2.0 per cent of males and 1.5 per cent of females); 4.5 per cent of respondents responded with "other", "I don't know", or did not respond.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[385]</a></sup> The number of <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="LGBT rights in the United Kingdom">transgender people in the UK</a> was estimated to be between 65,000 and 300,000 by research between 2001 and 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TransReport_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-TransReport-400">[386]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>
