<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_groups_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Ethnic groups in the United Kingdom">Ethnic groups in the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="16576" data-file-width="9352" decoding="async" height="390" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png/220px-Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png/330px-Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png/440px-Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Non-white_in_the_2011_census.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Percentage of the population not white according to the 2011 census</div></div></div>
<p>Historically, indigenous British people were thought to be <a href="/wiki/Genetic_history_of_the_British_Isles" title="Genetic history of the British Isles">descended from the various ethnic groups</a> that settled there before the 12th century: the <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a>, Romans, Anglo-Saxons, Norse and the <a href="/wiki/Normans" title="Normans">Normans</a>. <a href="/wiki/Welsh_people" title="Welsh people">Welsh people</a> could be the oldest ethnic group in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[391]</a></sup> A 2006 genetic study shows that more than 50 per cent of England's gene pool contains <a href="/wiki/Germanic_peoples" title="Germanic peoples">Germanic</a> Y chromosomes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[392]</a></sup> Another 2005 genetic analysis indicates that "about 75 per cent of the traceable ancestors of the modern British population had arrived in the British isles by about 6,200 years ago, at the start of the British Neolithic or Stone Age", and that the British broadly share a common ancestry with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Basque_people" title="Basque people">Basque people</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[393]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Henderson_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-Henderson-409">[395]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="These findings have been challenged and likely don't represent current thinking; see Genetic history of the British Isles#History of research (August 2021)">needs update</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The UK has a history of non-white immigration with <a href="/wiki/Liverpool" title="Liverpool">Liverpool</a> having the oldest Black population in the country dating back to at least the 1730s during the period of the African slave trade. During this period it is estimated the Afro-Caribbean population of Great Britain was 10,000 to 15,000<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-410"><a href="#cite_note-410">[396]</a></sup> which later declined due to the abolition of slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[397]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Costello_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-Costello-412">[398]</a></sup> The UK also has the oldest <a href="/wiki/British_Chinese" title="British Chinese">Chinese</a> community in Europe, dating to the arrival of Chinese seamen in the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chinese_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chinese-413">[399]</a></sup> In 1950 there were probably fewer than 20,000 non-white residents in Britain, almost all born overseas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[400]</a></sup> In 1951 there were an estimated 94,500 people living in Britain who had been born in South Asia, China, Africa and the Caribbean, just under 0.2 per cent of the UK population. By 1961 this number had more than quadrupled to 384,000, just over 0.7 per cent of the United Kingdom population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[401]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 1948 substantial immigration from Africa, the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> and South Asia has been a legacy of ties forged by the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-416"><a href="#cite_note-416">[402]</a></sup> Migration from new EU member states in <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central</a> and Eastern Europe since 2004 has resulted in growth in these population groups, although some of this migration has been temporary.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vargas_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vargas-417">[403]</a></sup> Since the 1990s, there has been substantial diversification of the immigrant population, with migrants to the UK coming from a much wider range of countries than previous waves, which tended to involve larger numbers of migrants coming from a relatively small number of countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[404]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[405]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[406]</a></sup>
Academics have argued that the <a href="/wiki/Classification_of_ethnicity_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Classification of ethnicity in the United Kingdom">ethnicity categories</a> employed in British national statistics, which were first introduced in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1991_UK_census" title="1991 UK census">1991 census</a>, involve confusion between the concepts of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethnicity" title="Ethnicity">ethnicity</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Race_(human_classification)" title="Race (human classification)">race</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[407]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kertzer_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kertzer-422">[408]</a></sup> In <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_Census_2011" title="United Kingdom Census 2011">2011</a><sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 87.2 per cent of the UK population identified themselves as white, meaning 12.8 per cent of the UK population identify themselves as of one of number of <a href="/wiki/Minority_group" title="Minority group">ethnic minority</a> groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnicity2011_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicity2011-423">[409]</a></sup> In the 2001 census, this figure was 7.9 per cent of the UK population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnicity2001_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicity2001-424">[410]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of differences in the wording of the census forms used in England and Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland, data on the <a href="/wiki/Other_White" title="Other White">Other White</a> group is not available for the UK as a whole, but in England and Wales this was the fastest-growing group between the 2001 and 2011 censuses, increasing by 1.1 million (1.8 percentage points).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[411]</a></sup> Amongst groups for which comparable data is available for all parts of the UK level, the Other Asian category increased from 0.4 per cent to 1.4 per cent of the population between 2001 and 2011, while the <a href="/wiki/Mixed_(United_Kingdom_ethnicity_category)" title="Mixed (United Kingdom ethnicity category)">Mixed</a> category rose from 1.2 per cent to 2 per cent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ethnicity2011_423-1"><a href="#cite_note-ethnicity2011-423">[409]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097763485">.mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .mbox-text-span{margin-left:23px!important}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}</style><table class="box-Prose plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style ambox-Prose" <p>Ethnic diversity varies significantly across the UK. 30.4 per cent of London's population and 37.4 per cent of <a href="/wiki/Leicester" title="Leicester">Leicester</a>'s was estimated to be non-white in 2005<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[415]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[416]</a></sup> whereas less than 5 per cent of the populations of <a href="/wiki/North_East_England" title="North East England">North East England</a>, Wales and the <a href="/wiki/South_West_England" title="South West England">South West</a> were from ethnic minorities, according to the 2001 census.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[417]</a></sup> In 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, 31.4 per cent of primary and 27.9 per cent of secondary pupils at <a href="/wiki/State_school" title="State school">state schools</a> in England were members of an ethnic minority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[418]</a></sup> The 1991 census was the first UK census to have a question on <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_group" title="Ethnic group">ethnic group</a>. In the 1991 UK census 94.1 per cent of people reported themselves as being White British, White Irish or White Other with 5.9 per cent of people reporting themselves as coming from other minority groups.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[419]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Languages of the United Kingdom">Languages of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<p>The UK's <i>de facto</i> official language is English.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-direct.gov.uk_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-direct.gov.uk-436">[420]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-thecommonwealth.org_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-thecommonwealth.org-437">[421]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (October 2021)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup> It is estimated that 95 per cent of the UK's population are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monolingual" title="Monolingual">monolingual</a> English speakers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_languages_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_languages-438">[422]</a></sup> 5.5 per cent of the population are estimated to speak languages brought to the UK as a result of relatively recent immigration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_languages_438-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_languages-438">[422]</a></sup> South Asian languages are the largest grouping which includes <a href="/wiki/Punjabi_language" title="Punjabi language">Punjabi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Urdu" title="Urdu">Urdu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sylheti_language" title="Sylheti language">Sylheti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindi" title="Hindi">Hindi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gujarati_language" title="Gujarati language">Gujarati</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-439"><a href="#cite_note-439">[423]</a></sup> According to the 2011 census, <a href="/wiki/Polish_language" title="Polish language">Polish</a> has become the second-largest language spoken in England and has 546,000 speakers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-440"><a href="#cite_note-440">[424]</a></sup> In 2019, some three quarters of a million people spoke little or no English.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-translate_441-0"><a href="#cite_note-translate-441">[425]</a></sup>
</p><p>Three indigenous <a href="/wiki/Celtic_languages" title="Celtic languages">Celtic languages</a> are spoken in the UK: <a href="/wiki/Welsh_language" title="Welsh language">Welsh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Irish_language" title="Irish language">Irish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Gaelic" title="Scottish Gaelic">Scottish Gaelic</a>. <a href="/wiki/Cornish_language" title="Cornish language">Cornish</a>, which became extinct as a first language in the late 18th century, is subject to revival efforts and has a small group of second language speakers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[426]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[427]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reglang_3-1"><a href="#cite_note-reglang-3">[2]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[428]</a></sup> In the 2011 Census, approximately one-fifth (19 per cent) of the population of Wales said they could speak Welsh,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-445"><a href="#cite_note-445">[429]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[430]</a></sup> an increase from the 1991 Census (18 per cent).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[431]</a></sup> In addition, it is estimated that about 200,000 Welsh speakers live in England.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[432]</a></sup> In the same census in Northern Ireland 167,487 people (10.4 per cent) stated that they had "some knowledge of Irish" (see <a href="/wiki/Irish_language_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Irish language in Northern Ireland">Irish language in Northern Ireland</a>), almost exclusively in the <a href="/wiki/Irish_nationalism" title="Irish nationalism">nationalist</a> (mainly Catholic) population. Over 92,000 people in Scotland (just under 2 per cent of the population) had some Gaelic language ability, including 72 per cent of those living in the <a href="/wiki/Outer_Hebrides" title="Outer Hebrides">Outer Hebrides</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[433]</a></sup> The number of children being taught either Welsh or Scottish Gaelic is increasing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[434]</a></sup> Among emigrant-descended populations some Scottish Gaelic is still <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Gaelic" title="Canadian Gaelic">spoken in Canada</a> (principally <a href="/wiki/Nova_Scotia" title="Nova Scotia">Nova Scotia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cape_Breton_Island" title="Cape Breton Island">Cape Breton Island</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Edwards2010_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-Edwards2010-451">[435]</a></sup> and Welsh in <a href="/wiki/Patagonia" title="Patagonia">Patagonia</a>, Argentina.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Koch2006_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-Koch2006-452">[436]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Scots_language" title="Scots language">Scots</a>, a language descended from early northern <a href="/wiki/Middle_English" title="Middle English">Middle English</a>, has limited <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">recognition</a> alongside its regional variant, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ulster_Scots_dialects" title="Ulster Scots dialects">Ulster Scots</a> in Northern Ireland, without specific commitments to protection and promotion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reglang_3-2"><a href="#cite_note-reglang-3">[2]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[437]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of April 2020, there are said to be around 151,000 users of <a href="/wiki/British_Sign_Language" title="British Sign Language">British Sign Language</a> (BSL), a <a href="/wiki/Sign_language" title="Sign language">sign language</a> used by deaf people, in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[438]</a></sup> BSL was recognised as a language of England, Scotland and Wales in law in 2022.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-455"><a href="#cite_note-455">[439]</a></sup> It is compulsory for pupils to study a second language from the age of seven in England.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-456"><a href="#cite_note-456">[440]</a></sup> French and Spanish are the two most commonly taught second languages in the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[441]</a></sup> All pupils in Wales are either taught Welsh as a second language up to age 16, or are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Welsh_medium_education" title="Welsh medium education">taught in Welsh</a> as a <a href="/wiki/First_language" title="First language">first language</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[442]</a></sup> Welsh was recognised as having official status in Wales in 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[443]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Religion in the United Kingdom">Religion in the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey,_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="640" data-file-width="481" decoding="async" height="226" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey%2C_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg/170px-West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey%2C_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey%2C_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg/255px-West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey%2C_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey%2C_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg/340px-West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey%2C_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:West_Side_of_Westminster_Abbey,_London_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1406999.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Westminster_Abbey" title="Westminster Abbey">Westminster Abbey</a></div></div></div>
<p>Forms of Christianity have dominated religious life in what is now the United Kingdom for over 1,400 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[444]</a></sup> Although a majority of citizens still identify with Christianity in many surveys, regular church attendance has fallen dramatically since the middle of the 20th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[445]</a></sup> while immigration and demographic change have contributed to the growth of other faiths, most notably Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[446]</a></sup> This has led some commentators to variously describe the UK as a multi-faith,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[447]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secularised</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[448]</a></sup> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Post-Christian" title="Post-Christian">post-Christian</a> society.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[449]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 2001 census, 71.6 per cent of all respondents indicated that they were Christians, with the next largest faiths being <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> (2.8 per cent), <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> (1.0 per cent), <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a> (0.6 per cent), <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a> (0.5 per cent), <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a> (0.3 per cent) and all other religions (0.3 per cent).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[450]</a></sup> 15 per cent of respondents stated that they had <a href="/wiki/Irreligion" title="Irreligion">no religion</a>, with a further 7 per cent not stating a religious preference.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-467"><a href="#cite_note-467">[451]</a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/Tearfund" title="Tearfund">Tearfund</a> survey in 2007 showed only one in 10 Britons actually attend church weekly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-468"><a href="#cite_note-468">[452]</a></sup> Between the 2001 and 2011 census there was a decrease in the number of people who identified as Christian by 12 per cent, whilst the percentage of those reporting no religious affiliation doubled. This contrasted with growth in the other main religious group categories, with the number of Muslims increasing by the most substantial margin to a total of about 5 per cent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Philby_469-0"><a href="#cite_note-Philby-469">[453]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Islam in the United Kingdom">Muslim population</a> has increased from 1.6 million in 2001 to 2.7 million in 2011, making it the second-largest religious group in the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-470"><a href="#cite_note-470">[454]</a></sup>
</p><p>In a 2016 survey conducted by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Social_Attitudes" title="British Social Attitudes">BSA (British Social Attitudes)</a> on religious affiliation; 53 per cent of respondents indicated '<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irreligious" title="Irreligious">no religion'</a>, while 41 per cent indicated they were Christians, followed by 6 per cent who affiliated with other religions (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>, etc.).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bsa2017_471-0"><a href="#cite_note-bsa2017-471">[455]</a></sup> Among Christians, adherents to the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_England" title="Church of England">Church of England</a> constituted 15 per cent, <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a> 9 per cent, and other Christians (including <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presbyterians" title="Presbyterians">Presbyterians</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Methodists" title="Methodists">Methodists</a>, other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Protestants" title="Protestants">Protestants</a>, as well as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox" title="Eastern Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a>), 17 per cent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bsa2017_471-1"><a href="#cite_note-bsa2017-471">[455]</a></sup> 71 per cent of young people aged 18––24 said they had no religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bsa2017_471-2"><a href="#cite_note-bsa2017-471">[455]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Church_of_England" title="Church of England">Church of England</a> is the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">established church</a> in England.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[456]</a></sup> It retains a <a href="/wiki/Lords_Spiritual" title="Lords Spiritual">representation</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Parliament of the United Kingdom">UK Parliament</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Monarchy_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Monarchy of the United Kingdom">British monarch</a> is its <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Governor_of_the_Church_of_England" title="Supreme Governor of the Church of England">Supreme Governor</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-473"><a href="#cite_note-473">[457]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Scotland" title="Religion in Scotland">Scotland</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Scotland" title="Church of Scotland">Church of Scotland</a> is recognised as the <a href="/wiki/National_church" title="National church">national church</a>. It is not <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">subject to state control</a>, and the British monarch is an ordinary member, required to swear an oath to "maintain and preserve the <a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestant Religion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Presbyterian_polity" title="Presbyterian polity">Presbyterian Church Government</a>" upon his or her accession.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[458]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-475"><a href="#cite_note-475">[459]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Church_in_Wales" title="Church in Wales">Church in Wales</a> was disestablished in 1920 and, as the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Ireland" title="Church of Ireland">Church of Ireland</a> was disestablished in 1870 before the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_Ireland" title="Partition of Ireland">partition of Ireland</a>, there is no established church in Northern Ireland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[460]</a></sup> Although there are no UK-wide data in the 2001 census on adherence to individual Christian denominations, it has been estimated that 62 per cent of Christians are Anglican, 13.5 per cent <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic</a>, 6 per cent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Presbyterian" title="Presbyterian">Presbyterian</a>, and 3.4 per cent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Methodist" title="Methodist">Methodist</a>, with small numbers of other Protestant denominations such as <a href="/wiki/Plymouth_Brethren" title="Plymouth Brethren">Plymouth Brethren</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Orthodox</a> churches.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-peach_477-0"><a href="#cite_note-peach-477">[461]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Migration">Migration</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Modern_immigration_to_the_United_Kingdom" title="Modern immigration to the United Kingdom">Modern immigration to the United Kingdom</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Foreign-born_population_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Foreign-born population of the United Kingdom">Foreign-born population of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="415" data-file-width="940" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png/300px-United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png/450px-United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/24/United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png/600px-United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:United_Kingdom_foreign_born_population_by_country_of_birth.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Estimated foreign-born population by country of birth from April 2007 to March 2008</div></div></div>

<p>The United Kingdom has experienced successive waves of migration. The <a href="/wiki/Great_Famine_(Ireland)" title="Great Famine (Ireland)">Great Famine</a> in Ireland, then part of the United Kingdom, resulted in perhaps a million people migrating to Great Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[468]</a></sup> Throughout the 19th century a small population of 28,644 German immigrants built up in England and Wales. London held around half of this population, and other small communities existed in Manchester, Bradford and elsewhere. The <a href="/wiki/Germans_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Germans in the United Kingdom">German</a> immigrant community was the largest group until 1891, when it became second to <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Russia" title="History of the Jews in Russia">Russian Jews</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[469]</a></sup> After 1881, Russian Jews suffered bitter persecutions and 2,000,000 left the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russian Empire</a> by 1914. Around 120,000 settled permanently in Britain, becoming the largest ethnic minority from outside the British Isles;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[470]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-487"><a href="#cite_note-487">[471]</a></sup> this population had increased to 370,000 by 1938.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-488"><a href="#cite_note-488">[472]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[473]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[474]</a></sup> Unable to return to Poland at the end of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, over 120,000 <a href="/wiki/Polish_Armed_Forces_in_the_West" title="Polish Armed Forces in the West">Polish veterans</a> remained in the UK permanently.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-491"><a href="#cite_note-491">[475]</a></sup> After the Second World War, many people immigrated from colonies and former-colonies in the <a href="/wiki/Caribbean" title="Caribbean">Caribbean</a> and <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>, as a legacy of empire or driven by labour shortages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[476]</a></sup> In 1841, 0.25 per cent of the population of <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales" title="England and Wales">England and Wales</a> was born in a foreign country, increasing to 1.5 per cent by 1901,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Green_480-1"><a href="#cite_note-Green-480">[464]</a></sup> 2.6 per cent by 1931 and 4.4 per cent in 1951.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coleman2013_478-1"><a href="#cite_note-Coleman2013-478">[462]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2014 the immigration <a href="/wiki/Net_migration_rate" title="Net migration rate">net increase</a> was 318,000: Immigration was at 641,000, up from 526,000 in 2013, while the number of emigrants leaving for over a year was 323,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[477]</a></sup> A recent migration trend has been the arrival of workers from the new EU member states in Eastern Europe, known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A8_countries" title="A8 countries">A8 countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vargas_417-1"><a href="#cite_note-Vargas-417">[403]</a></sup> In 2011, citizens of new EU member states made up 13 per cent of immigrants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[478]</a></sup> The UK applied temporary restrictions to citizens of Romania and Bulgaria, which joined the EU in January 2007.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[479]</a></sup> Research conducted by the <a href="/wiki/Migration_Policy_Institute" title="Migration Policy Institute">Migration Policy Institute</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Equality_and_Human_Rights_Commission" title="Equality and Human Rights Commission">Equality and Human Rights Commission</a> suggests that, between May 2004 and September 2009, 1.5 million workers migrated from the new EU member states to the UK, most of them Polish. Many subsequently returned home, resulting in a net increase in the number of nationals of the new member states in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MPI_496-0"><a href="#cite_note-MPI-496">[480]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[481]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Late-2000s_recession" title="Late-2000s recession">late-2000s recession</a> in the UK reduced economic incentive for Poles to migrate to the UK,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[482]</a></sup> making migration temporary and circular.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-499"><a href="#cite_note-499">[483]</a></sup> The proportion of foreign-born people in the UK remains slightly below that of many other European countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-500"><a href="#cite_note-500">[484]</a></sup>
</p><p>Immigration is now contributing to a rising population,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-501"><a href="#cite_note-501">[485]</a></sup> with arrivals and UK-born children of migrants accounting for about half of the population increase between 1991 and 2001. 27 per cent of UK live births in 2014 were to mothers born outside the UK, according to official statistics released in 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[486]</a></sup> The ONS reported that net migration rose from 2009 to 2010 by 21 per cent to 239,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-503"><a href="#cite_note-503">[487]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, approximately 208,000 foreign nationals were naturalised as British citizens, the highest number since 1962. This figure fell to around 125,800 in 2014. Between 2009 and 2013, the average British citizenships granted annually was 195,800. The most common previous nationalities of those naturalised in 2014 were India, Pakistan, the Philippines, Nigeria, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, China, South Africa, Poland and <a href="/wiki/Somalia" title="Somalia">Somalia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blinder2015_504-0"><a href="#cite_note-Blinder2015-504">[488]</a></sup> The total number of grants of settlement, which confer <a href="/wiki/Permanent_residency" title="Permanent residency">permanent residence</a> in the UK but not citizenship,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-505"><a href="#cite_note-505">[489]</a></sup> was approximately 154,700 in 2013, higher than the previous two years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blinder2015_504-1"><a href="#cite_note-Blinder2015-504">[488]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:British_expats_countrymap.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="415" data-file-width="940" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/British_expats_countrymap.svg/300px-British_expats_countrymap.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/British_expats_countrymap.svg/450px-British_expats_countrymap.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/88/British_expats_countrymap.svg/600px-British_expats_countrymap.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:British_expats_countrymap.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Estimated number of British citizens living overseas by country in 2006</div></div></div>
<p>In 2008, the British Government introduced a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Points-based_immigration_system_(United_Kingdom)" title="Points-based immigration system (United Kingdom)">points-based immigration system</a> for immigration from outside the <a href="/wiki/European_Economic_Area" title="European Economic Area">European Economic Area</a> to replace former schemes, including the Scottish Government's <a href="/wiki/Fresh_Talent_Initiative" title="Fresh Talent Initiative">Fresh Talent Initiative</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-506"><a href="#cite_note-506">[490]</a></sup> In June 2010 a temporary limit on immigration from outside the EU was introduced, aiming to discourage applications before a permanent cap was imposed in April 2011.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[491]</a></sup>
</p><p>Emigration was an important feature of British society in the 19th century. Between 1815 and 1930, around 11.4 million people emigrated from Britain and 7.3 million from Ireland. Estimates show that by the end of the 20th century, some 300 million people of British and Irish descent were permanently settled around the globe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-508"><a href="#cite_note-508">[492]</a></sup> Today, at least 5.5 million UK-born people live abroad,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BritsAbroad_509-0"><a href="#cite_note-BritsAbroad-509">[493]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-510"><a href="#cite_note-510">[494]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[495]</a></sup> mainly in Australia, Spain, the United States and Canada.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BritsAbroad_509-1"><a href="#cite_note-BritsAbroad-509">[493]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[496]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Education in the United Kingdom">Education in the United Kingdom</a></div>
<p>Education in the United Kingdom is a <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolved</a> matter, with each country having a separate education system.
</p><p>Considering the four systems together, about 38 per cent of the United Kingdom population has a university or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/College_degree" title="College degree">college degree</a>, which is the highest percentage in Europe, and among the highest percentages in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[497]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-514"><a href="#cite_note-514">[498]</a></sup> The United Kingdom trails only the United States in terms of representation on lists of top 100 universities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[499]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[500]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-517"><a href="#cite_note-517">[501]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-518"><a href="#cite_note-518">[502]</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Social_Mobility_and_Child_Poverty_Commission" title="Social Mobility and Child Poverty Commission">government commission</a>'s report in 2014 found that privately educated people comprise 7 per cent of the general population of the UK but much larger percentages of the top professions, the most extreme case quoted being 71 per cent of senior judges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SMCPC20140828_519-0"><a href="#cite_note-SMCPC20140828-519">[503]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guardian20140828_520-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guardian20140828-520">[504]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="England">England</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_England" title="Education in England">Education in England</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tom_Quad,_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1011" data-file-width="1819" decoding="async" height="122" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Tom_Quad%2C_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg/220px-Tom_Quad%2C_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Tom_Quad%2C_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg/330px-Tom_Quad%2C_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Tom_Quad%2C_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg/440px-Tom_Quad%2C_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tom_Quad,_Christ_Church_2004-01-21.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Christ_Church,_Oxford" title="Christ Church, Oxford">Christ Church, Oxford</a>, is part of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oxford" title="University of Oxford">University of Oxford</a>, which traces its foundations back to c. 1096.</div></div></div>
<p>Whilst education in England is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Secretary_of_State_for_Education" title="Secretary of State for Education">Secretary of State for Education</a>, the day-to-day administration and funding of state schools is the responsibility of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Local_education_authority" title="Local education authority">local authorities</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-521"><a href="#cite_note-521">[505]</a></sup> Universally free of charge state education was introduced piecemeal between 1870 and 1944.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[506]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-523"><a href="#cite_note-523">[507]</a></sup> Education is now mandatory from ages 5 to 16, and in England youngsters must stay in education or training until they are 18.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[508]</a></sup> In 2011, the <a href="/wiki/Trends_in_International_Mathematics_and_Science_Study" title="Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study">Trends in International Mathematics and Science Study</a> (TIMSS) rated 13–14-year-old pupils in England and Wales tenth in the world for maths and ninth for science.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[509]</a></sup> The majority of children are educated in state-sector schools, a small proportion of which select on the grounds of academic ability. Two of the top 10 performing schools in terms of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/GCSE" title="GCSE">GCSE</a> results in 2006 were state-run <a href="/wiki/Grammar_school" title="Grammar school">grammar schools</a>. In 2010, over half of places at the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oxford" title="University of Oxford">University of Oxford</a> and the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Cambridge" title="University of Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a> were taken by students from state schools,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[510]</a></sup> while the proportion of children in England attending private schools is around 7 per cent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[511]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-528"><a href="#cite_note-528">[512]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1025" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg/220px-KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg/330px-KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg/440px-KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KingsCollegeChapelWest.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/King%27s_College,_Cambridge" title="King's College, Cambridge">King's College</a> (right) and <a href="/wiki/Clare_College,_Cambridge" title="Clare College, Cambridge">Clare College</a> (left), both part of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Cambridge" title="University of Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a>, which was founded in 1209</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Scotland">Scotland</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Scotland" title="Education in Scotland">Education in Scotland</a></div>
<p>Education in Scotland is the responsibility of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cabinet_Secretary_for_Education_and_Lifelong_Learning" title="Cabinet Secretary for Education and Lifelong Learning">Cabinet Secretary for Education and Lifelong Learning</a>, with day-to-day administration and funding of state schools the responsibility of Local Authorities. Two <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_public_bodies" title="Scottish public bodies">non-departmental public bodies</a> have key roles in Scottish education. The <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Qualifications_Authority" title="Scottish Qualifications Authority">Scottish Qualifications Authority</a> is responsible for the development, accreditation, assessment and certification of qualifications other than degrees which are delivered at secondary schools, <a href="/wiki/Tertiary_education" title="Tertiary education">post-secondary</a> colleges of <a href="/wiki/Further_education" title="Further education">further education</a> and other centres.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529"><a href="#cite_note-529">[513]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Learning_and_Teaching_Scotland" title="Learning and Teaching Scotland">Learning and Teaching Scotland</a> provides advice, resources and staff development to education professionals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[514]</a></sup> Scotland first legislated for compulsory education in 1496.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[515]</a></sup> The proportion of children in Scotland attending private schools is just over 4 per cent in 2016, but it has been falling slowly in recent years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[516]</a></sup> Scottish students who attend <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_universities" title="Scottish universities">Scottish universities</a> pay neither <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tuition_fees" title="Tuition fees">tuition fees</a> nor graduate endowment charges, as fees were abolished in 2001 and the graduate endowment scheme was abolished in 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[517]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Wales">Wales</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Wales" title="Education in Wales">Education in Wales</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Government" title="Welsh Government">Welsh Government</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Miles" title="Jeremy Miles">Minister for Education</a> has responsibility for education in Wales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534"><a href="#cite_note-534">[518]</a></sup> State funded education is available to children from the age of three whilst the legal obligation for parents to have their children educated, usually at school, begins at age five.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-535"><a href="#cite_note-535">[519]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536"><a href="#cite_note-536">[520]</a></sup> A sizeable minority of pupils are educated in Welsh whilst the rest are obliged to study the language until the age of 16.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[521]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_538-0"><a href="#cite_note-:4-538">[522]</a></sup> Wales' performance in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pisa_test" title="Pisa test">Pisa testing</a>, which compares the academic performance of adolescents around the world, has improved in recent years but remains lower than other parts of the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-539"><a href="#cite_note-539">[523]</a></sup> In 2019, just under 60% of entrants passed their main English and math GCSEs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-540"><a href="#cite_note-540">[524]</a></sup> The obligation to receive education in Wales ends at the age of 16. In 2017 and 2018, just under 80% of 16 to 18 and just under 40% of 19 to 24-year-olds were in some kind of education or training.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[525]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Northern_Ireland">Northern Ireland</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Education in Northern Ireland">Education in Northern Ireland</a></div>
<p>Education in Northern Ireland is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Department_of_Education_(Northern_Ireland)" title="Department of Education (Northern Ireland)">Minister of Education</a>, although responsibility at a local level is administered by the <a href="/wiki/Education_Authority" title="Education Authority">Education Authority</a> which is further sub-divided into five geographical areas. The <a href="/wiki/Council_for_the_Curriculum,_Examinations_%26_Assessment" title="Council for the Curriculum, Examinations &amp; Assessment">Council for the Curriculum, Examinations &amp; Assessment</a> (CCEA) is the body responsible for advising the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Executive" title="Northern Ireland Executive">government</a> on what should be taught in Northern Ireland's schools, monitoring standards and awarding qualifications.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-542"><a href="#cite_note-542">[526]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">Healthcare</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Healthcare in the United Kingdom">Healthcare in the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3216" data-file-width="4288" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG/220px-15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG/330px-15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG/440px-15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:15th_Sep_2012-Abdn_Children%27s_Hosp_%26_Emergency_Care_Centre_10.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Aberdeen_Children%27s_Hospital" title="Royal Aberdeen Children's Hospital">Royal Aberdeen Children's Hospital</a>, an <a href="/wiki/NHS_Scotland" title="NHS Scotland">NHS Scotland</a> specialist <a href="/wiki/Children%27s_hospital" title="Children's hospital">children's hospital</a></div></div></div>
<p>Healthcare in the United Kingdom is a <a href="/wiki/Devolution" title="Devolution">devolved matter</a> and each country has its own system of private and <a href="/wiki/Publicly_funded_health_care" title="Publicly funded health care">publicly funded healthcare</a>. Public healthcare is provided to all <a href="/wiki/British_nationality_law" title="British nationality law">UK permanent residents</a> and is mostly free at the point of need, being paid for from <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Taxation in the United Kingdom">general taxation</a>. The <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a>, in 2000, ranked the provision of healthcare in the United Kingdom as fifteenth best in Europe and eighteenth in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Who2000_543-0"><a href="#cite_note-Who2000-543">[527]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-544"><a href="#cite_note-544">[528]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since 1979 expenditure on healthcare has been increased significantly.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-545"><a href="#cite_note-545">[529]</a></sup> The 2018 <a href="/wiki/OECD" title="OECD">OECD</a> data, which incorporates in health a chunk of what in the UK is classified as social care, has the UK spending £3,121 per head.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:02_546-0"><a href="#cite_note-:02-546">[530]</a></sup> In 2017 the UK spent £2,989 per person on healthcare, around the median for members of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organisation_for_Economic_Co-operation_and_Development" title="Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development">Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-547"><a href="#cite_note-547">[531]</a></sup>
</p><p>Regulatory bodies are organised on a UK-wide basis such as the <a href="/wiki/General_Medical_Council" title="General Medical Council">General Medical Council</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Nursing_and_Midwifery_Council" title="Nursing and Midwifery Council">Nursing and Midwifery Council</a> and non-governmental-based, such as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_College" title="Royal College">Royal Colleges</a>. Political and operational responsibility for healthcare lies with four national <a href="/wiki/Executive_(government)" title="Executive (government)">executives</a>; <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_England" title="Healthcare in England">healthcare in England</a> is the responsibility of the UK Government; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Northern_Ireland" title="Healthcare in Northern Ireland">healthcare in Northern Ireland</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_Executive" title="Northern Ireland Executive">Northern Ireland Executive</a>; <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Scotland" title="Healthcare in Scotland">healthcare in Scotland</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">Scottish Government</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Wales" title="Healthcare in Wales">healthcare in Wales</a> is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Government" title="Welsh Government">Welsh Government</a>. Each <a href="/wiki/National_Health_Service" title="National Health Service">National Health Service</a> has different policies and priorities, resulting in contrasts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548"><a href="#cite_note-548">[532]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-549"><a href="#cite_note-549">[533]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Culture of the United Kingdom">Culture of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<p>The culture of the United Kingdom has been influenced by many factors including: the nation's island status; its <a href="/wiki/History_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="History of the United Kingdom">history</a> as a western liberal democracy and a major power; as well as being a <a href="/wiki/Political_union" title="Political union">political union</a> of four countries with each preserving elements of distinctive traditions, customs and symbolism. As a result of the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a>, British influence can be observed in the <a href="/wiki/English_language" title="English language">language</a>, <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Culture of the United Kingdom">culture</a> and <a href="/wiki/Common_law" title="Common law">legal systems</a> of many of its <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_that_have_gained_independence_from_the_United_Kingdom" title="List of countries that have gained independence from the United Kingdom">former colonies</a> including Australia, Canada, India, Ireland, New Zealand, Pakistan, South Africa and the United States; a common culture coined today as the <a href="/wiki/Anglosphere" title="Anglosphere">Anglosphere</a>. The substantial cultural influence of the United Kingdom has led it to be described as a "cultural superpower".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-culture_156-1"><a href="#cite_note-culture-156">[142]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sheridan_157-1"><a href="#cite_note-sheridan-157">[143]</a></sup> A global opinion poll for the BBC saw the United Kingdom ranked the third most positively viewed nation in the world (behind Germany and Canada) in 2013 and 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-550"><a href="#cite_note-550">[534]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-551"><a href="#cite_note-551">[535]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/British_literature" title="British literature">British literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shakespeare.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2489" data-file-width="1943" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Shakespeare.jpg/170px-Shakespeare.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Shakespeare.jpg/255px-Shakespeare.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Shakespeare.jpg/340px-Shakespeare.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shakespeare.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Chandos_portrait" title="Chandos portrait">Chandos portrait</a>, believed to depict <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a></div></div></div>
<p>"British literature" refers to literature associated with the United Kingdom, the <a href="/wiki/Isle_of_Man" title="Isle of Man">Isle of Man</a> and the Channel Islands. Most British literature is in the English language. In 2005, some 206,000 books were published in the United Kingdom and in 2006 it was the <a href="/wiki/Books_published_per_country_per_year" title="Books published per country per year">largest publisher of books</a> in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reuters_552-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters-552">[536]</a></sup>
</p><p>The English playwright and poet <a href="/wiki/William_Shakespeare" title="William Shakespeare">William Shakespeare</a> is widely regarded as the greatest dramatist of all time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-553"><a href="#cite_note-553">[537]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554"><a href="#cite_note-554">[538]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555"><a href="#cite_note-555">[539]</a></sup> The 20th-century English crime writer <a href="/wiki/Agatha_Christie" title="Agatha Christie">Agatha Christie</a> is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_fiction_authors" title="List of best-selling fiction authors">best-selling novelist</a> of all time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[540]</a></sup>
</p><p>Twelve of the top 25 of 100 novels by British writers chosen by a BBC poll of global critics were written by women; these included works by <a href="/wiki/George_Eliot" title="George Eliot">George Eliot</a>, <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Woolf" title="Virginia Woolf">Virginia Woolf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charlotte_Bront%C3%AB" title="Charlotte Brontë">Charlotte</a> and <a href="/wiki/Emily_Bront%C3%AB" title="Emily Brontë">Emily Brontë</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mary_Shelley" title="Mary Shelley">Mary Shelley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jane_Austen" title="Jane Austen">Jane Austen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Doris_Lessing" title="Doris Lessing">Doris Lessing</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zadie_Smith" title="Zadie Smith">Zadie Smith</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25greatest_557-0"><a href="#cite_note-25greatest-557">[541]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="786" data-file-width="626" decoding="async" height="213" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png/170px-Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png/255px-Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png/340px-Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Dickens_by_Watkins_1858.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A photograph of <a href="/wiki/Victorian_era" title="Victorian era">Victorian-era</a> novelist <a href="/wiki/Charles_Dickens" title="Charles Dickens">Charles Dickens</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Scottish_literature" title="Scottish literature">Scotland's contributions</a> include <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Conan_Doyle" title="Arthur Conan Doyle">Arthur Conan Doyle</a> (the creator of <a href="/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes" title="Sherlock Holmes">Sherlock Holmes</a>), <a href="/wiki/Walter_Scott" title="Walter Scott">Sir Walter Scott</a>, <a href="/wiki/J._M._Barrie" title="J. M. Barrie">J. M. Barrie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Louis_Stevenson" title="Robert Louis Stevenson">Robert Louis Stevenson</a> and the poet <a href="/wiki/Robert_Burns" title="Robert Burns">Robert Burns</a>. More recently <a href="/wiki/Hugh_MacDiarmid" title="Hugh MacDiarmid">Hugh MacDiarmid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neil_M._Gunn" title="Neil M. Gunn">Neil M. Gunn</a> contributed to the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Renaissance" title="Scottish Renaissance">Scottish Renaissance</a>, with grimmer works from <a href="/wiki/Ian_Rankin" title="Ian Rankin">Ian Rankin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Iain_Banks" title="Iain Banks">Iain Banks</a>. Scotland's capital, Edinburgh, was UNESCO's first worldwide <a href="/wiki/City_of_Literature" title="City of Literature">City of Literature</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-558"><a href="#cite_note-558">[542]</a></sup>
</p><p>Britain's oldest known poem, <i><a href="/wiki/Y_Gododdin" title="Y Gododdin">Y Gododdin</a></i>, was composed most likely in the late 6th century. It was written in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cumbric_language" title="Cumbric language">Cumbric</a> or <a href="/wiki/Old_Welsh" title="Old Welsh">Old Welsh</a> and contains the earliest known reference to <a href="/wiki/King_Arthur" title="King Arthur">King Arthur</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-559"><a href="#cite_note-559">[543]</a></sup> The Arthurian legend was further developed by <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_of_Monmouth" title="Geoffrey of Monmouth">Geoffrey of Monmouth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-560"><a href="#cite_note-560">[544]</a></sup> Poet <a href="/wiki/Dafydd_ap_Gwilym" title="Dafydd ap Gwilym">Dafydd ap Gwilym</a> (<i>fl.</i> 1320–1370) is regarded as one of the greatest European poets of his age.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-561"><a href="#cite_note-561">[545]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Owen" title="Daniel Owen">Daniel Owen</a> is credited as the first Welsh-language novelist, publishing <i><a href="/wiki/Rhys_Lewis_(novel)" title="Rhys Lewis (novel)">Rhys Lewis</a></i> in 1885. The best-known of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglo-Welsh_poetry" title="Anglo-Welsh poetry">Anglo-Welsh poets</a> are <a href="/wiki/Dylan_Thomas" title="Dylan Thomas">Dylan Thomas</a> and <a href="/wiki/R._S._Thomas" title="R. S. Thomas">R. S. Thomas</a>, the latter nominated for the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a> in 1996. Leading Welsh novelists of the twentieth century include <a href="/wiki/Richard_Llewellyn" title="Richard Llewellyn">Richard Llewellyn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kate_Roberts_(author)" title="Kate Roberts (author)">Kate Roberts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-562"><a href="#cite_note-562">[546]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-563"><a href="#cite_note-563">[547]</a></sup>
</p><p>Irish writers, living at a time when all of Ireland was part of the United Kingdom, include <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Wilde" title="Oscar Wilde">Oscar Wilde</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Varty2014_564-0"><a href="#cite_note-Varty2014-564">[548]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-565"><a href="#cite_note-565">[549]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bram_Stoker" title="Bram Stoker">Bram Stoker</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Moss2001_566-0"><a href="#cite_note-Moss2001-566">[550]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/George_Bernard_Shaw" title="George Bernard Shaw">George Bernard Shaw</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-567"><a href="#cite_note-567">[551]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-568"><a href="#cite_note-568">[552]</a></sup>
</p><p>There have been a number of authors whose origins were from outside the United Kingdom but who moved to the UK. These include <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Conrad" title="Joseph Conrad">Joseph Conrad</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Middleton2006_569-0"><a href="#cite_note-Middleton2006-569">[553]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/T._S._Eliot" title="T. S. Eliot">T. S. Eliot</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cooper2006_570-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cooper2006-570">[554]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Kazuo_Ishiguro" title="Kazuo Ishiguro">Kazuo Ishiguro</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sim2009_571-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sim2009-571">[555]</a></sup> Sir <a href="/wiki/Salman_Rushdie" title="Salman Rushdie">Salman Rushdie</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-572"><a href="#cite_note-572">[556]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Ezra_Pound" title="Ezra Pound">Ezra Pound</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-573"><a href="#cite_note-573">[557]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nadel2004_574-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nadel2004-574">[558]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Music of the United Kingdom">Music of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rock_music_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Rock music in the United Kingdom">Rock music in the United Kingdom</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1097763485" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><table class="box-Overly_detailed plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-style ambox-overly_detailed" role="presentation"><tbody><tr><td class="mbox-image"><div class="mbox-image-div"><img alt="" data-file-height="48" data-file-width="48" decoding="async" height="40" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/40px-Edit-clear.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/60px-Edit-clear.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/f/f2/Edit-clear.svg/80px-Edit-clear.svg.png 2x" width="40"/></div></td><td class="mbox-text"><div class="mbox-text-span">This section <b>may contain an excessive amount of intricate detail that may interest only a particular audience</b>. <b>Specifically, overlong lists</b>.<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help by  removing excessive detail that may be against <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:What_Wikipedia_is_not" title="Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not">Wikipedia's inclusion policy</a>.</span> <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">April 2022</span>)</i></span><span class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<small><a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a></small>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1097025294">.mw-parser-output .side-box{margin:4px 0;box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #aaa;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em;background-color:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .side-box-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{padding:0.25em 0.9em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-image{padding:2px 0 2px 0.9em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-imageright{padding:2px 0.9em 2px 0;text-align:center}@media(min-width:500px){.mw-parser-output .side-box-flex{display:flex;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .side-box-text{flex:1}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .side-box{width:238px}.mw-parser-output .side-box-right{clear:right;float:right;margin-left:1em}.mw-parser-output .side-box-left{margin-right:1em}}</style><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096940132">.mw-parser-output .listen .side-box-text{line-height:1.1em}.mw-parser-output .listen-plain{border:none;background:transparent}.mw-parser-output .listen-embedded{width:100%;margin:0;border-width:1px 0 0 0;background:transparent}.mw-parser-output .listen-header{padding:2px}.mw-parser-output .listen-embedded .listen-header{padding:2px 0}.mw-parser-output .listen-file-header{padding:4px 0}.mw-parser-output .listen .description{padding-top:2px}.mw-parser-output .listen .mw-tmh-player{max-width:100%}@media(max-width:719px){.mw-parser-output .listen{clear:both}}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .listen:not(.listen-noimage){width:320px}.mw-parser-output .listen-left{overflow:visible;float:left}.mw-parser-output .listen-center{float:none;margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto}}</style><div class="side-box side-box-right listen noprint">
<div class="side-box-flex">
<div class="side-box-image"><div class="center"><div class="floatnone"><img alt="" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="160" decoding="async" height="50" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Gnome-mime-audio-openclipart.svg/50px-Gnome-mime-audio-openclipart.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Gnome-mime-audio-openclipart.svg/75px-Gnome-mime-audio-openclipart.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Gnome-mime-audio-openclipart.svg/100px-Gnome-mime-audio-openclipart.svg.png 2x" width="50"/></div></div></div>
<div class="side-box-text plainlist"><div class="haudio">
<div class="listen-file-header"><a href="/wiki/File:Handel_-_Zadok_the_Priest,_HWV_258_(St_Matthew%27s_Concert_Choir).oga" title="File:Handel - Zadok the Priest, HWV 258 (St Matthew's Concert Choir).oga">Handel's "Zadok the Priest", HWV 258, coronation anthem for George II</a></div>
<div><audio controls="" data-durationhint="363" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Handel_-_Zadok_the_Priest,_HWV_258_(St_Matthew's_Concert_Choir).oga" id="mwe_player_1" preload="none" style="width:232px;" width="232"><source data-bandwidth="99764" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="Ogg source" data-title="Original Ogg file (100 kbps)" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b8/Handel_-_Zadok_the_Priest%2C_HWV_258_%28St_Matthew%27s_Concert_Choir%29.oga" type='audio/ogg; codecs="vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="199032" data-height="0" data-shorttitle="MP3" data-title="MP3" data-transcodekey="mp3" data-width="0" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/b/b8/Handel_-_Zadok_the_Priest%2C_HWV_258_%28St_Matthew%27s_Concert_Choir%29.oga/Handel_-_Zadok_the_Priest%2C_HWV_258_%28St_Matthew%27s_Concert_Choir%29.oga.mp3" type="audio/mpeg"/></audio></div>
<div class="description">St Matthew's Concert Choir and Orchestra, Damien Giromella, 2013</div></div></div></div>
</div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Edward_Elgar_1917.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="711" data-file-width="477" decoding="async" height="224" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/02/Edward_Elgar_1917.jpg/150px-Edward_Elgar_1917.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/02/Edward_Elgar_1917.jpg/225px-Edward_Elgar_1917.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/02/Edward_Elgar_1917.jpg/300px-Edward_Elgar_1917.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Edward_Elgar_1917.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Elgar aged about 60</div></div></div>
<p>Various styles of music have become popular in the UK, including the indigenous <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_music_of_England" title="Folk music of England">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Wales#Folk_music" title="Music of Wales">Wales</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_music_of_Scotland" title="Folk music of Scotland">Scotland</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_music_of_Northern_Ireland" title="Folk music of Northern Ireland">Northern Ireland</a>. Historically, there has been exceptional Renaissance music from the <a href="/wiki/Tudor_period" title="Tudor period">Tudor period</a>, with masses, madrigals and lute music by <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Tallis" title="Thomas Tallis">Thomas Tallis</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Taverner" title="John Taverner">John Taverner</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Byrd" title="William Byrd">William Byrd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Orlando_Gibbons" title="Orlando Gibbons">Orlando Gibbons</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Dowland" title="John Dowland">John Dowland</a>. After the <a href="/wiki/Stuart_Restoration" title="Stuart Restoration">Stuart Restoration</a>, an English tradition of dramatic masques, anthems and airs became established, led by <a href="/wiki/Henry_Purcell" title="Henry Purcell">Henry Purcell</a>, followed by <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Arne" title="Thomas Arne">Thomas Arne</a> and others. The German-born composer <a href="/wiki/George_Frideric_Handel" title="George Frideric Handel">George Frideric Handel</a> became a <a href="/wiki/Naturalization" title="Naturalization">naturalised</a> <a href="/wiki/British_nationality_law" title="British nationality law">British citizen</a> in 1727, when he composed the anthem <i><a href="/wiki/Zadok_the_Priest" title="Zadok the Priest">Zadok the Priest</a></i> for the coronation of <a href="/wiki/George_II_of_Great_Britain" title="George II of Great Britain">George II</a>; it became the traditional ceremonial music for anointing all future monarchs. Handel's many oratorios, such as his famous <i><a href="/wiki/Messiah_(Handel)" title="Messiah (Handel)">Messiah</a></i>, were written in the English language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Handel_575-0"><a href="#cite_note-Handel-575">[559]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-576"><a href="#cite_note-576">[560]</a></sup> Ceremonial music is also performed to mark <a href="/wiki/Remembrance_Sunday" title="Remembrance Sunday">Remembrance Sunday</a> across the UK, including the <a href="/wiki/National_Service_of_Remembrance#Traditional_music" title="National Service of Remembrance">Traditional Music</a> played at <a href="/wiki/The_Cenotaph" title="The Cenotaph">the Cenotaph</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-577"><a href="#cite_note-577">[561]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-578"><a href="#cite_note-578">[562]</a></sup> In the second half of the 19th century, as <a href="/wiki/Arthur_Sullivan" title="Arthur Sullivan">Arthur Sullivan</a> and his librettist <a href="/wiki/W._S._Gilbert" title="W. S. Gilbert">W. S. Gilbert</a> wrote their popular <a href="/wiki/Savoy_opera" title="Savoy opera">Savoy operas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Edward_Elgar" title="Edward Elgar">Edward Elgar</a>'s wide range of music rivalled that of his contemporaries on the continent. Increasingly, however, composers became inspired by the English countryside and its <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a>, notably <a href="/wiki/Gustav_Holst" title="Gustav Holst">Gustav Holst</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ralph_Vaughan_Williams" title="Ralph Vaughan Williams">Ralph Vaughan Williams</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Britten" title="Benjamin Britten">Benjamin Britten</a>, a pioneer of modern British opera. Among the many post-war composers, some of the most notable have made their own personal choice of musical identity: <a href="/wiki/Peter_Maxwell_Davies" title="Peter Maxwell Davies">Peter Maxwell Davies</a> (Orkney), <a href="/wiki/Harrison_Birtwistle" title="Harrison Birtwistle">Harrison Birtwistle</a> (mythological), and <a href="/wiki/John_Tavener" title="John Tavener">John Tavener</a> (religious).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-579"><a href="#cite_note-579">[563]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-580"><a href="#cite_note-580">[564]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-581"><a href="#cite_note-581">[565]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-582"><a href="#cite_note-582">[566]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-583"><a href="#cite_note-583">[567]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-584"><a href="#cite_note-584">[568]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK is also home to world-renowned symphonic orchestras and choruses such as the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Symphony_Orchestra" title="BBC Symphony Orchestra">BBC Symphony Orchestra</a> and the <a href="/wiki/London_Symphony_Chorus" title="London Symphony Chorus">London Symphony Chorus</a>.
