Notable British conductors include <a href="/wiki/Henry_Wood" title="Henry Wood">Sir Henry Wood</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Barbirolli" title="John Barbirolli">Sir John Barbirolli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_Sargent" title="Malcolm Sargent">Sir Malcolm Sargent</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Groves" title="Charles Groves">Sir Charles Groves</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Mackerras" title="Charles Mackerras">Sir Charles Mackerras</a> and <a href="/wiki/Simon_Rattle" title="Simon Rattle">Sir Simon Rattle</a>; at the same time international conductors, not British-born, like <a href="/wiki/Georg_Solti" title="Georg Solti">Georg Solti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bernard_Haitink" title="Bernard Haitink">Bernard Haitink</a>, have become at the forefront in Britain for performances of symphonic music and opera.
</p><p>Some of the notable <a href="/wiki/Film_score" title="Film score">film score</a> composers include <a href="/wiki/William_Walton" title="William Walton">William Walton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eric_Coates" title="Eric Coates">Eric Coates</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Barry_(composer)" title="John Barry (composer)">John Barry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clint_Mansell" title="Clint Mansell">Clint Mansell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mike_Oldfield" title="Mike Oldfield">Mike Oldfield</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/John_Powell_(composer)" title="John Powell (composer)">John Powell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Craig_Armstrong_(composer)" title="Craig Armstrong (composer)">Craig Armstrong</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Arnold" title="David Arnold">David Arnold</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Murphy_(composer)" title="John Murphy (composer)">John Murphy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monty_Norman" title="Monty Norman">Monty Norman</a> and <a href="/wiki/Harry_Gregson-Williams" title="Harry Gregson-Williams">Harry Gregson-Williams</a>. <a href="/wiki/Andrew_Lloyd_Webber" title="Andrew Lloyd Webber">Andrew Lloyd Webber</a> is a prolific composer of musical theatre. His works have dominated London's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_End_Theatre" title="West End Theatre">West End</a> since the late 20th century and have also been a commercial success worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-585"><a href="#cite_note-585">[569]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the website of <i><a href="/wiki/The_New_Grove_Dictionary_of_Music_and_Musicians" title="The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians">The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians</a></i>, the term "<a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop music</a>" originated in Britain in the mid-1950s to describe <a href="/wiki/Rock_and_roll" title="Rock and roll">rock and roll</a>'s fusion with the "new youth music".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Grove_586-0"><a href="#cite_note-Grove-586">[570]</a></sup> <i>The Oxford Dictionary of Music</i> states that artists such as <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones" title="The Rolling Stones">The Rolling Stones</a> drove pop music to the forefront of popular music in the early 1960s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-587"><a href="#cite_note-587">[571]</a></sup> In the following years, Britain widely occupied a part in the development of <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">rock music</a>, with British acts pioneering <a href="/wiki/Hard_rock" title="Hard rock">hard rock</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-588"><a href="#cite_note-588">[572]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Raga_rock" title="Raga rock">raga rock</a>; <a href="/wiki/Art_rock" title="Art rock">art rock</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELindberg_et_al.2005104–06_589-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELindberg_et_al.2005104–06-589">[573]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:CITESHORT" title="Wikipedia:CITESHORT"><span title="More information is required to link this short citation to its long citation. (July 2021)">incomplete short citation</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">heavy metal</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Larson2004a_590-0"><a href="#cite_note-Larson2004a-590">[574]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Space_rock" title="Space rock">space rock</a>; <a href="/wiki/Glam_rock" title="Glam rock">glam rock</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Encarta_591-0"><a href="#cite_note-Encarta-591">[575]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/New_wave_music" title="New wave music">new wave</a>;<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/Gothic_rock" title="Gothic rock">Gothic rock</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NME2_592-0"><a href="#cite_note-NME2-592">[576]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Ska_punk" title="Ska punk">ska punk</a>. In addition, British acts developed <a href="/wiki/Progressive_rock" title="Progressive rock">progressive rock</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPrownNewquist199778_593-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPrownNewquist199778-593">[577]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wikipedia:CITESHORT" title="Wikipedia:CITESHORT"><span title="More information is required to link this short citation to its long citation. (July 2021)">incomplete short citation</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/Psychedelic_rock" title="Psychedelic rock">psychedelic rock</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-allmusic_594-0"><a href="#cite_note-allmusic-594">[578]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Punk_rock" title="Punk rock">punk rock</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RSE_595-0"><a href="#cite_note-RSE-595">[579]</a></sup> Besides rock music, British acts also developed <a href="/wiki/Neo_soul" title="Neo soul">neo soul</a> and created <a href="/wiki/Dubstep" title="Dubstep">dubstep</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Henderson2_596-0"><a href="#cite_note-Henderson2-596">[580]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-597"><a href="#cite_note-597">[581]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-598"><a href="#cite_note-598">[582]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Fabs.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1110" data-file-width="1110" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/The_Fabs.JPG/170px-The_Fabs.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/The_Fabs.JPG/255px-The_Fabs.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/The_Fabs.JPG/340px-The_Fabs.JPG 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Fabs.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> are the most commercially successful and critically acclaimed band in popular music, selling over a billion records.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beatles_sales_599-0"><a href="#cite_note-Beatles_sales-599">[583]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McCartney_600-0"><a href="#cite_note-McCartney-600">[584]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guinness_601-0"><a href="#cite_note-Guinness-601">[585]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> have international sales of over 1 billion units and are the <a href="/wiki/List_of_best-selling_music_artists" title="List of best-selling music artists">biggest-selling</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cultural_impact_of_the_Beatles" title="Cultural impact of the Beatles">most influential band in the history of popular music</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Beatles_sales_599-1"><a href="#cite_note-Beatles_sales-599">[583]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McCartney_600-1"><a href="#cite_note-McCartney-600">[584]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Guinness_601-1"><a href="#cite_note-Guinness-601">[585]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-602"><a href="#cite_note-602">[586]</a></sup> Other prominent British contributors to have influenced popular music over the last 50 years include <a href="/wiki/The_Rolling_Stones" title="The Rolling Stones">The Rolling Stones</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pink_Floyd" title="Pink Floyd">Pink Floyd</a>, <a href="/wiki/Queen_(band)" title="Queen (band)">Queen</a>, <a href="/wiki/Led_Zeppelin" title="Led Zeppelin">Led Zeppelin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Bee_Gees" title="Bee Gees">Bee Gees</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Elton_John" title="Elton John">Elton John</a>, all of whom have worldwide record sales of 200 million or more.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-603"><a href="#cite_note-603">[587]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-604"><a href="#cite_note-604">[588]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-605"><a href="#cite_note-605">[589]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-606"><a href="#cite_note-606">[590]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-607"><a href="#cite_note-607">[591]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-608"><a href="#cite_note-608">[592]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Brit_Awards" title="Brit Awards">Brit Awards</a> are the <a href="/wiki/British_Phonographic_Industry" title="British Phonographic Industry">BPI's</a> annual music awards, and some of the British recipients of the <a href="/wiki/Brit_Award_for_Outstanding_Contribution_to_Music" title="Brit Award for Outstanding Contribution to Music">Outstanding Contribution to Music</a> award include; <a href="/wiki/The_Who" title="The Who">The Who</a>, <a href="/wiki/David_Bowie" title="David Bowie">David Bowie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eric_Clapton" title="Eric Clapton">Eric Clapton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rod_Stewart" title="Rod Stewart">Rod Stewart</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Police" title="The Police">The Police</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fleetwood_Mac" title="Fleetwood Mac">Fleetwood Mac</a> (who are a British-American band).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-609"><a href="#cite_note-609">[593]</a></sup> More recent UK music acts that have had international success include <a href="/wiki/George_Michael" title="George Michael">George Michael</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oasis_(band)" title="Oasis (band)">Oasis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Spice_Girls" title="Spice Girls">Spice Girls</a>, <a href="/wiki/Radiohead" title="Radiohead">Radiohead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coldplay" title="Coldplay">Coldplay</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arctic_Monkeys" title="Arctic Monkeys">Arctic Monkeys</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robbie_Williams" title="Robbie Williams">Robbie Williams</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amy_Winehouse" title="Amy Winehouse">Amy Winehouse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Adele" title="Adele">Adele</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ed_Sheeran" title="Ed Sheeran">Ed Sheeran</a>, <a href="/wiki/One_Direction" title="One Direction">One Direction</a> and <a href="/wiki/Harry_Styles" title="Harry Styles">Harry Styles</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-610"><a href="#cite_note-610">[594]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-611"><a href="#cite_note-611">[595]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-612"><a href="#cite_note-612">[596]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-613"><a href="#cite_note-613">[597]</a></sup>
</p><p>A number of UK cities are known for their music. Acts from Liverpool have had 54 UK chart number 1 hit singles, more per capita than any other city worldwide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Liverpool_vs_Stavanger_614-0"><a href="#cite_note-Liverpool_vs_Stavanger-614">[598]</a></sup> Glasgow's contribution to music was recognised in 2008 when it was named a <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="/wiki/City_of_Music_(UNESCO)" title="City of Music (UNESCO)">City of Music</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-615"><a href="#cite_note-615">[599]</a></sup> Manchester played a role in the spread of dance music such as <a href="/wiki/Acid_house" title="Acid house">acid house</a>, and from the mid-1990s, <a href="/wiki/Britpop" title="Britpop">Britpop</a>. London and Bristol are closely associated with the origins of <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">electronic music</a> sub-genres such as <a href="/wiki/Drum_and_bass" title="Drum and bass">drum and bass</a> and <a href="/wiki/Trip_hop" title="Trip hop">trip hop</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dnb_616-0"><a href="#cite_note-dnb-616">[600]</a></sup> Birmingham became known as the birthplace of <a href="/wiki/Heavy_metal_music" title="Heavy metal music">heavy metal</a>, with the band <a href="/wiki/Black_Sabbath" title="Black Sabbath">Black Sabbath</a> starting there in the 1960s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-617"><a href="#cite_note-617">[601]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-618"><a href="#cite_note-618">[602]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">Pop</a> remains the most popular music genre by sales and streams of <a href="/wiki/Single_(music)" title="Single (music)">singles</a>, with 33.4 per cent of that market in 2016, followed by <a href="/wiki/Hip_hop_music" title="Hip hop music">hip-hop</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rhythm_and_blues" title="Rhythm and blues">R&amp;B</a> at 24.5 per cent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_619-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-619">[603]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">Rock</a> is not far behind, at 22.6 per cent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_619-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-619">[603]</a></sup> The modern UK is known to produce some of the most prominent English-speaking rappers along with the United States, including <a href="/wiki/Stormzy" title="Stormzy">Stormzy</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kano_(rapper)" title="Kano (rapper)">Kano</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yxng_Bane" title="Yxng Bane">Yxng Bane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ramz_(rapper)" title="Ramz (rapper)">Ramz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Skepta" title="Skepta">Skepta</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-620"><a href="#cite_note-620">[604]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Visual_art">Visual art</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Art_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Art of the United Kingdom">Art of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Turner_selfportrait.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4622" data-file-width="3601" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Turner_selfportrait.jpg/170px-Turner_selfportrait.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Turner_selfportrait.jpg/255px-Turner_selfportrait.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/Turner_selfportrait.jpg/340px-Turner_selfportrait.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Turner_selfportrait.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/J._M._W._Turner" title="J. M. W. Turner">J. M. W. Turner</a> self-portrait, oil on canvas, c. 1799</div></div></div>
<p>The history of British visual art forms part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_art_history" title="Western art history">western art history</a>. Major British artists include: the <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romantics</a> <a href="/wiki/William_Blake" title="William Blake">William Blake</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Constable" title="John Constable">John Constable</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Palmer" title="Samuel Palmer">Samuel Palmer</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/J.M.W._Turner" title="J.M.W. Turner">J.M.W. Turner</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Portrait" title="Portrait">portrait</a> painters <a href="/wiki/Joshua_Reynolds" title="Joshua Reynolds">Sir Joshua Reynolds</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lucian_Freud" title="Lucian Freud">Lucian Freud</a>; the landscape artists <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Gainsborough" title="Thomas Gainsborough">Thomas Gainsborough</a> and <a href="/wiki/L._S._Lowry" title="L. S. Lowry">L. S. Lowry</a>; the pioneer of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arts_and_Crafts_Movement" title="Arts and Crafts Movement">Arts and Crafts Movement</a> <a href="/wiki/William_Morris" title="William Morris">William Morris</a>; the figurative painter <a href="/wiki/Francis_Bacon_(artist)" title="Francis Bacon (artist)">Francis Bacon</a>; the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pop_artist" title="Pop artist">Pop artists</a> <a href="/wiki/Peter_Blake_(artist)" title="Peter Blake (artist)">Peter Blake</a>, <a href="/wiki/Richard_Hamilton_(artist)" title="Richard Hamilton (artist)">Richard Hamilton</a> and <a href="/wiki/David_Hockney" title="David Hockney">David Hockney</a>; the pioneers of <a href="/wiki/Conceptual_art" title="Conceptual art">Conceptual art</a> movement <a href="/wiki/Art_%26_Language" title="Art &amp; Language">Art &amp; Language</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-621"><a href="#cite_note-621">[605]</a></sup> the collaborative duo <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gilbert_and_George" title="Gilbert and George">Gilbert and George</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Abstract_art" title="Abstract art">abstract</a> artist <a href="/wiki/Howard_Hodgkin" title="Howard Hodgkin">Howard Hodgkin</a>; and the sculptors <a href="/wiki/Antony_Gormley" title="Antony Gormley">Antony Gormley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anish_Kapoor" title="Anish Kapoor">Anish Kapoor</a> and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Moore" title="Henry Moore">Henry Moore</a>. During the late 1980s and 1990s the <a href="/wiki/Saatchi_Gallery" title="Saatchi Gallery">Saatchi Gallery</a> in London helped to bring to public attention a group of multi-genre artists who would become known as the "<a href="/wiki/Young_British_Artists" title="Young British Artists">Young British Artists</a>": <a href="/wiki/Damien_Hirst" title="Damien Hirst">Damien Hirst</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chris_Ofili" title="Chris Ofili">Chris Ofili</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rachel_Whiteread" title="Rachel Whiteread">Rachel Whiteread</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tracey_Emin" title="Tracey Emin">Tracey Emin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mark_Wallinger" title="Mark Wallinger">Mark Wallinger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steve_McQueen_(director)" title="Steve McQueen (director)">Steve McQueen</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sam_Taylor-Wood" title="Sam Taylor-Wood">Sam Taylor-Wood</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Jake_and_Dinos_Chapman" title="Jake and Dinos Chapman">Chapman Brothers</a> are among the better-known members of this loosely affiliated movement.
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Royal_Academy" title="Royal Academy">Royal Academy</a> in London is a key organisation for the promotion of the visual arts in the United Kingdom. Major schools of art in the UK include: the six-school <a href="/wiki/University_of_the_Arts_London" title="University of the Arts London">University of the Arts London</a>, which includes the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Central_Saint_Martins_College_of_Art_and_Design" title="Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design">Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Chelsea_College_of_Art_and_Design" title="Chelsea College of Art and Design">Chelsea College of Art and Design</a>; <a href="/wiki/Goldsmiths,_University_of_London" title="Goldsmiths, University of London">Goldsmiths, University of London</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Slade_School_of_Fine_Art" title="Slade School of Fine Art">Slade School of Fine Art</a> (part of <a href="/wiki/University_College_London" title="University College London">University College London</a>); the <a href="/wiki/Glasgow_School_of_Art" title="Glasgow School of Art">Glasgow School of Art</a>; the <a href="/wiki/Royal_College_of_Art" title="Royal College of Art">Royal College of Art</a>; and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Ruskin_School_of_Drawing_and_Fine_Art" title="The Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Art">The Ruskin School of Drawing and Fine Art</a> (part of the University of Oxford). The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Courtauld_Institute_of_Art" title="Courtauld Institute of Art">Courtauld Institute of Art</a> is a leading centre for the teaching of the <a href="/wiki/History_of_art" title="History of art">history of art</a>. Important art galleries in the United Kingdom include the <a href="/wiki/National_Gallery" title="National Gallery">National Gallery</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Portrait_Gallery_(London)" title="National Portrait Gallery (London)">National Portrait Gallery</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tate_Britain" title="Tate Britain">Tate Britain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tate_Modern" title="Tate Modern">Tate Modern</a> (the most-visited modern art gallery in the world, with around 4.7 million visitors per year).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-622"><a href="#cite_note-622">[606]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Cinema of the United Kingdom">Cinema of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hitchcock,_Alfred_02.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="973" data-file-width="808" decoding="async" height="205" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg/170px-Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg/255px-Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg/340px-Hitchcock%2C_Alfred_02.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hitchcock,_Alfred_02.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock" title="Alfred Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a> has been ranked as one of the greatest and most influential British filmmakers of all time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-623"><a href="#cite_note-623">[607]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The United Kingdom has had a considerable influence on the history of the cinema. The British directors <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Hitchcock" title="Alfred Hitchcock">Alfred Hitchcock</a>, whose film <i><a href="/wiki/Vertigo_(film)" title="Vertigo (film)">Vertigo</a></i> is considered by some critics as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_films_considered_the_best" title="List of films considered the best">best film of all time</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbc_624-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-624">[608]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/David_Lean" title="David Lean">David Lean</a> are among the most critically acclaimed of all time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-625"><a href="#cite_note-625">[609]</a></sup> Many British actors have achieved international fame and critical success. Some of the most commercially successful films of all time have been produced in the United Kingdom, including two of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_highest-grossing_film_series" title="List of highest-grossing film series">highest-grossing film franchises</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Harry_Potter_(film_series)" title="Harry Potter (film series)">Harry Potter</a></i> and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_Bond_(film_series)" title="James Bond (film series)">James Bond</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-626"><a href="#cite_note-626">[610]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ealing_Studios" title="Ealing Studios">Ealing Studios</a> has a claim to being the oldest continuously working film studio in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-627"><a href="#cite_note-627">[611]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009, British films grossed around $2 billion worldwide and achieved a market share of around 7 per cent globally and 17 per cent in the United Kingdom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statistics_628-0"><a href="#cite_note-statistics-628">[612]</a></sup> UK box-office takings totalled £944 million in 2009, with around 173 million admissions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statistics_628-1"><a href="#cite_note-statistics-628">[612]</a></sup> The annual <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_Film_Awards" title="British Academy Film Awards">British Academy Film Awards</a> are hosted by the <a href="/wiki/British_Academy_of_Film_and_Television_Arts" title="British Academy of Film and Television Arts">British Academy of Film and Television Arts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-629"><a href="#cite_note-629">[613]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/British_cuisine" title="British cuisine">British cuisine</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/British_cuisine" title="British cuisine">British cuisine</a> developed from various influences reflective of its land, settlements, arrivals of new settlers and immigrants, trade and colonialism. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Celtic_fields" title="Celtic fields">Celtic agriculture</a> and animal breeding produced a wide variety of foodstuffs for indigenous <a href="/wiki/Celts" title="Celts">Celts</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Britons_(historic)" title="Britons (historic)">Britons</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglo-Saxon_England" title="Anglo-Saxon England">Anglo-Saxon England</a> developed meat and savoury herb stewing techniques before the practice became common in Europe. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Norman_conquest" title="Norman conquest">Norman conquest</a> introduced exotic spices into <a href="/wiki/England_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="England in the Middle Ages">England in the Middle Ages</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-630"><a href="#cite_note-630">[614]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> facilitated a knowledge of <a href="/wiki/Indian_cuisine" title="Indian cuisine">Indian cuisine</a> with its "strong, penetrating spices and herbs". British cuisine has absorbed the cultural influence of those who have <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_Kingdom_since_1922" title="Immigration to the United Kingdom since 1922">settled in Britain</a>, producing hybrid dishes, such as <a href="/wiki/Chicken_tikka_masala" title="Chicken tikka masala">chicken tikka masala</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GuardianMasala_631-0"><a href="#cite_note-GuardianMasala-631">[615]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bbcenc_632-0"><a href="#cite_note-bbcenc-632">[616]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Veganism" title="Veganism">Vegan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vegetarianism" title="Vegetarianism">vegetarian</a> diets have increased in Britain in recent years. In 2021, a survey found that 8% of British respondents eat a plant-based diet and 36% of respondents have a favourable view of plant-based diets.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-633"><a href="#cite_note-633">[617]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Media of the United Kingdom">Media of the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1076" data-file-width="774" decoding="async" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg/170px-Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg/255px-Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg/340px-Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bbc_broadcasting_house_front.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Art_Deco" title="Art Deco">Art Deco</a> facade of <a href="/wiki/Broadcasting_House" title="Broadcasting House">Broadcasting House</a> in London, headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a>, the oldest and largest broadcaster in the world<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MediaNewsline_634-0"><a href="#cite_note-MediaNewsline-634">[618]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProspectMag_635-0"><a href="#cite_note-ProspectMag-635">[619]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AboutBBC_636-0"><a href="#cite_note-AboutBBC-636">[620]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a>, founded in 1922, is the UK's publicly funded radio, television and Internet broadcasting corporation, and is the oldest and largest broadcaster in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MediaNewsline_634-1"><a href="#cite_note-MediaNewsline-634">[618]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ProspectMag_635-1"><a href="#cite_note-ProspectMag-635">[619]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AboutBBC_636-1"><a href="#cite_note-AboutBBC-636">[620]</a></sup> It operates numerous television and radio stations in the UK and abroad and its domestic services are funded by the <a href="/wiki/Television_licensing_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Television licensing in the United Kingdom">television licence</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_637-0"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-637">[621]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-638"><a href="#cite_note-638">[622]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/BBC_World_Service" title="BBC World Service">BBC World Service</a> is an <a href="/wiki/International_broadcasting" title="International broadcasting">international broadcaster</a> owned and operated by the <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a>. It is the world's largest of any kind.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-639"><a href="#cite_note-639">[623]</a></sup> It broadcasts radio news, speech and discussions in more than 40 languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-640"><a href="#cite_note-640">[624]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-641"><a href="#cite_note-641">[625]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other major players in the UK media include <a href="/wiki/ITV_plc" title="ITV plc">ITV plc</a>, which operates 11 of the 15 regional television broadcasters that make up the <a href="/wiki/ITV_(TV_network)" title="ITV (TV network)">ITV Network</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-642"><a href="#cite_note-642">[626]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Sky_UK" title="Sky UK">Sky</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-643"><a href="#cite_note-643">[627]</a></sup> Newspapers produced in the United Kingdom include <i><a href="/wiki/The_Times" title="The Times">The Times</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Guardian" title="The Guardian">The Guardian</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Observer" title="The Observer">The Observer</a>,</i> <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i>, and the <i><a href="/wiki/Financial_Times" title="Financial Times">Financial Times</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-paper2_644-0"><a href="#cite_note-paper2-644">[628]</a></sup> Magazines and journals published in the United Kingdom that have achieved worldwide circulation include <i><a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)">Nature</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/New_Scientist" title="New Scientist">New Scientist</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Spectator" title="The Spectator">The Spectator</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Prospect_(magazine)" title="Prospect (magazine)">Prospect</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/NME" title="NME">NME</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Radio_Times" title="Radio Times">Radio Times</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Economist" title="The Economist">The Economist</a></i>.
</p><p>London dominates the media sector in the UK: national newspapers and television and radio are largely based there, although Manchester is also a significant national media centre. Edinburgh and Glasgow, and Cardiff, are important centres of newspaper and broadcasting production in Scotland and Wales, respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-645"><a href="#cite_note-645">[629]</a></sup> The UK publishing sector, including books, directories and databases, journals, magazines and business media, newspapers and news agencies, has a combined turnover of around £20 billion and employs around 167,000 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-646"><a href="#cite_note-646">[630]</a></sup> In 2015, the UK published 2,710 book titles per million inhabitants, more than any other country, much of this being exported to other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anglophone" title="Anglophone">Anglophone</a> countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-647"><a href="#cite_note-647">[631]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009, it was estimated that individuals viewed a mean of 3.75 hours of television per day and 2.81 hours of radio. In that year the main BBC <a href="/wiki/Public_service_broadcasting_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Public service broadcasting in the United Kingdom">public service broadcasting</a> channels accounted for an estimated 28.4 per cent of all television viewing; the three main independent channels accounted for 29.5 per cent and the increasingly important other satellite and digital channels for the remaining 42.1 per cent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-648"><a href="#cite_note-648">[632]</a></sup> Sales of newspapers have fallen since the 1970s and in 2010 41 per cent of people reported reading a daily national newspaper.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-649"><a href="#cite_note-649">[633]</a></sup> In 2010, 82.5 per cent of the UK population were Internet users, the highest proportion amongst the 20 countries with the largest total number of users in that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-650"><a href="#cite_note-650">[634]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Philosophy">Philosophy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/British_philosophy" title="British philosophy">British philosophy</a></div>
<p>The United Kingdom is famous for the tradition of '<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_Empiricism" title="British Empiricism">British Empiricism</a>', a branch of the philosophy of knowledge that states that only knowledge verified by experience is valid, and 'Scottish Philosophy', sometimes referred to as the '<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scottish_School_of_Common_Sense" title="Scottish School of Common Sense">Scottish School of Common Sense</a>'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-651"><a href="#cite_note-651">[635]</a></sup> The most famous philosophers of British Empiricism are <a href="/wiki/John_Locke" title="John Locke">John Locke</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Berkeley" title="George Berkeley">George Berkeley</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-652"><a href="#cite_note-652">[note 7]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/David_Hume" title="David Hume">David Hume</a>; while <a href="/wiki/Dugald_Stewart" title="Dugald Stewart">Dugald Stewart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Reid" title="Thomas Reid">Thomas Reid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sir_William_Hamilton,_9th_Baronet" title="Sir William Hamilton, 9th Baronet">William Hamilton</a> were major exponents of the Scottish "common sense" school. Two Britons are also notable for the ethical theory of <a href="/wiki/Utilitarianism" title="Utilitarianism">utilitarianism</a>, a moral philosophy first used by <a href="/wiki/Jeremy_Bentham" title="Jeremy Bentham">Jeremy Bentham</a> and later by <a href="/wiki/John_Stuart_Mill" title="John Stuart Mill">John Stuart Mill</a> in his short work <i><a href="/wiki/Utilitarianism_(book)" title="Utilitarianism (book)">Utilitarianism</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-653"><a href="#cite_note-653">[636]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-654"><a href="#cite_note-654">[637]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Sport in the United Kingdom">Sport in the United Kingdom</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3377" data-file-width="4502" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG/220px-Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG/330px-Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG/440px-Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wembley-STadion_2013.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Wembley_Stadium" title="Wembley Stadium">Wembley Stadium</a>, London, home of the <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">England national football team</a>, is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_most_expensive_stadiums" title="List of most expensive stadiums">fifth most expensive stadium ever built</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CNN-NFLStad_655-0"><a href="#cite_note-CNN-NFLStad-655">[638]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Association football</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Table_tennis" title="Table tennis">table tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Badminton" title="Badminton">badminton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">rugby league</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_sevens" title="Rugby sevens">rugby sevens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">golf</a>, <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Netball" title="Netball">netball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_polo" title="Water polo">water polo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Field_hockey" title="Field hockey">field hockey</a>, <a href="/wiki/English_billiards" title="English billiards">billiards</a>, <a href="/wiki/Darts" title="Darts">darts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rowing_(sport)" title="Rowing (sport)">rowing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rounders" title="Rounders">rounders</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cricket" title="Cricket">cricket</a> originated or were substantially developed in the UK, with the rules and codes of many modern sports invented and codified in the late 19th century <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Victorian_Britain" title="Victorian Britain">Victorian Britain</a>. In 2012, the President of the IOC, <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Rogge" title="Jacques Rogge">Jacques Rogge</a>, stated, "This great, sports-loving country is widely recognised as the birthplace of modern sport. It was here that the concepts of sportsmanship and fair play were first codified into clear rules and regulations. It was here that sport was included as an educational tool in the school curriculum".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-656"><a href="#cite_note-656">[639]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-657"><a href="#cite_note-657">[640]</a></sup>
</p><p>A 2003 poll found that football is the most popular <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Sport in the United Kingdom">sport in the United Kingdom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sports_poll_658-0"><a href="#cite_note-sports_poll-658">[641]</a></sup> England is recognised by <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">FIFA</a> as the birthplace of club football, and <a href="/wiki/The_Football_Association" title="The Football Association">The Football Association</a> is the oldest of its kind, with the <a href="/wiki/Laws_of_the_Game_(association_football)" title="Laws of the Game (association football)">rules of football</a> first drafted in 1863 by <a href="/wiki/Ebenezer_Cobb_Morley" title="Ebenezer Cobb Morley">Ebenezer Cobb Morley</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-659"><a href="#cite_note-659">[642]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-660"><a href="#cite_note-660">[643]</a></sup> Each of the Home Nations has its own football association, national team and <a href="/wiki/League_system" title="League system">league system</a> and individually are the governing members of the <a href="/wiki/International_Football_Association_Board" title="International Football Association Board">International Football Association Board</a> alongside <a href="/wiki/FIFA" title="FIFA">FIFA</a>. The English top division, the <a href="/wiki/Premier_League" title="Premier League">Premier League</a>, is the most watched football league in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-661"><a href="#cite_note-661">[644]</a></sup> The first international football match was contested by <a href="/wiki/England_national_football_team" title="England national football team">England</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_football_team" title="Scotland national football team">Scotland</a> on 30 November 1872.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_article_662-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_article-662">[645]</a></sup> England, Scotland, <a href="/wiki/Wales_national_football_team" title="Wales national football team">Wales</a> and <a href="/wiki/Northern_Ireland_national_football_team" title="Northern Ireland national football team">Northern Ireland</a> usually compete as separate countries in international competitions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-663"><a href="#cite_note-663">[646]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium,_Cardiff.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2560" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg/220px-Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg/330px-Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg/440px-Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium%2C_Cardiff.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Inside_the_Millennium_Stadium,_Cardiff.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Stadium" title="Millennium Stadium">Millennium Stadium</a> of <a href="/wiki/Cardiff" title="Cardiff">Cardiff</a> opened for the <a href="/wiki/1999_Rugby_World_Cup" title="1999 Rugby World Cup">1999 Rugby World Cup</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>In 2003, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union" title="Rugby union">rugby union</a> was ranked the second most popular sport in the UK.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sports_poll_658-1"><a href="#cite_note-sports_poll-658">[641]</a></sup> The sport was created in <a href="/wiki/Rugby_School" title="Rugby School">Rugby School</a>, Warwickshire, and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1871_England_versus_Scotland_rugby_union_match" title="1871 England versus Scotland rugby union match">first rugby international</a> took place on 27 March 1871 between <a href="/wiki/England_national_rugby_union_team" title="England national rugby union team">England</a> and <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_rugby_union_team" title="Scotland national rugby union team">Scotland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-664"><a href="#cite_note-664">[647]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-665"><a href="#cite_note-665">[648]</a></sup> England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland, France and Italy compete in the <a href="/wiki/Six_Nations_Championship" title="Six Nations Championship">Six Nations Championship</a>; the premier international tournament in the northern hemisphere. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sport_governing_body" title="Sport governing body">Sport governing bodies</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union_in_England" title="Rugby union in England">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union_in_Scotland" title="Rugby union in Scotland">Scotland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union_in_Wales" title="Rugby union in Wales">Wales</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rugby_union_in_Ireland" title="Rugby union in Ireland">Ireland</a> organise and regulate the game separately.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-666"><a href="#cite_note-666">[649]</a></sup> Every four years, England, Ireland, Scotland and Wales make a combined team known as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_and_Irish_Lions" title="British and Irish Lions">British and Irish Lions</a>. The team tours Australia, New Zealand and South Africa.
</p><p>Cricket was invented in England, and its <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Laws_of_cricket" title="Laws of cricket">laws</a> were established by the <a href="/wiki/Marylebone_Cricket_Club" title="Marylebone Cricket Club">Marylebone Cricket Club</a> in 1788.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-667"><a href="#cite_note-667">[650]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/England_cricket_team" title="England cricket team">England cricket team</a>, controlled by the <a href="/wiki/England_and_Wales_Cricket_Board" title="England and Wales Cricket Board">England and Wales Cricket Board</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-668"><a href="#cite_note-668">[651]</a></sup> and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Irish_cricket_team" title="Irish cricket team">Irish cricket team</a>, controlled by <a href="/wiki/Cricket_Ireland" title="Cricket Ireland">Cricket Ireland</a> are the only national teams in the UK with <a href="/wiki/Test_cricket" title="Test cricket">Test status</a>. Team members are drawn from the main county sides, and include both English and Welsh players. Cricket is distinct from football and rugby where Wales and England field separate national teams, although Wales had fielded its own team in the past. <a href="/wiki/Cricket_in_Scotland" title="Cricket in Scotland">Scottish</a> players have played for England because <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_cricket_team" title="Scotland national cricket team">Scotland</a> does not have Test status and has only recently started to play in <a href="/wiki/One_Day_International" title="One Day International">One Day Internationals</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-669"><a href="#cite_note-669">[652]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-670"><a href="#cite_note-670">[653]</a></sup> Scotland, England (and Wales), and Ireland (including Northern Ireland) have competed at the <a href="/wiki/Cricket_World_Cup" title="Cricket World Cup">Cricket World Cup</a>, with England winning the tournament in 2019. There is a professional <a href="/wiki/County_Championship" title="County Championship">league championship</a> in which clubs representing 17 English counties and 1 Welsh county compete.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-671"><a href="#cite_note-671">[654]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg/220px-Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg/330px-Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg/440px-Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Saville_vs_Broady_%E2%80%93_Wimbledon_Boys_Singles_Final_2011.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a>, the oldest <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> tennis tournament, is held in <a href="/wiki/Wimbledon,_London" title="Wimbledon, London">Wimbledon</a>, London every June and July.</div></div></div>
<p>The modern game of <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a> originated in Birmingham, England, in the 1860s, before spreading around the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-672"><a href="#cite_note-672">[655]</a></sup> The world's oldest tennis tournament, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wimbledon_championships" title="Wimbledon championships">Wimbledon championships</a>, first occurred in 1877, and today the event takes place over two weeks in late June and early July.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-673"><a href="#cite_note-673">[656]</a></sup>
</p><p>The UK is closely associated with <a href="/wiki/Motorsport" title="Motorsport">motorsport</a>. Many teams and drivers in <a href="/wiki/Formula_One" title="Formula One">Formula One</a> (F1) are based in the UK, and the country has won more <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Drivers%27_Champions" title="List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions">drivers'</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Constructors%27_Champions" title="List of Formula One World Constructors' Champions">constructors'</a> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Formula_One_World_Championship" title="Formula One World Championship">titles</a> than any other. The UK hosted the first F1 Grand Prix in 1950 at <a href="/wiki/Silverstone_Circuit" title="Silverstone Circuit">Silverstone</a>, the location of the <a href="/wiki/British_Grand_Prix" title="British Grand Prix">British Grand Prix</a> held each year in July.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-674"><a href="#cite_note-674">[657]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:R%26A_Clubhouse,_Old_Course,_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2709" data-file-width="4059" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/R%26A_Clubhouse%2C_Old_Course%2C_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg/220px-R%26A_Clubhouse%2C_Old_Course%2C_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/R%26A_Clubhouse%2C_Old_Course%2C_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg/330px-R%26A_Clubhouse%2C_Old_Course%2C_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/R%26A_Clubhouse%2C_Old_Course%2C_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg/440px-R%26A_Clubhouse%2C_Old_Course%2C_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:R%26A_Clubhouse,_Old_Course,_Swilcan_Burn_bridge.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/The_Royal_and_Ancient_Golf_Club_of_St_Andrews" title="The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews">St Andrews</a>, Scotland, the home of golf. The standard 18 hole golf course was created at St Andrews in 1764.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forrest_675-0"><a href="#cite_note-Forrest-675">[658]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Golf" title="Golf">Golf</a> is the sixth most popular sport, by participation, in the UK. Although <a href="/wiki/The_Royal_and_Ancient_Golf_Club_of_St_Andrews" title="The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews">The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews</a> in Scotland is the sport's home course,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-676"><a href="#cite_note-676">[659]</a></sup> the world's oldest golf course is actually Musselburgh Links' Old Golf Course.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-677"><a href="#cite_note-677">[660]</a></sup> In 1764, the standard 18-hole golf course was created at St Andrews when members modified the course from 22 to 18 holes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Forrest_675-1"><a href="#cite_note-Forrest-675">[658]</a></sup> The oldest golf tournament in the world, and the first major championship in golf, <a href="/wiki/The_Open_Championship" title="The Open Championship">The Open Championship</a>, is played annually on the weekend of the third Friday in July.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-678"><a href="#cite_note-678">[661]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Rugby_league" title="Rugby league">Rugby league</a> originated in Huddersfield, West Yorkshire in 1895 and is generally played in <a href="/wiki/Northern_England" title="Northern England">Northern England</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-679"><a href="#cite_note-679">[662]</a></sup> A single 'Great Britain Lions' team had competed in the <a href="/wiki/Rugby_League_World_Cup" title="Rugby League World Cup">Rugby League World Cup</a> and Test match games, but this changed in 2008 when <a href="/wiki/England_national_rugby_league_team" title="England national rugby league team">England</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scotland_national_rugby_league_team" title="Scotland national rugby league team">Scotland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ireland_national_rugby_league_team" title="Ireland national rugby league team">Ireland</a> competed as separate nations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-680"><a href="#cite_note-680">[663]</a></sup> Great Britain is still retained as the full national team. <a href="/wiki/Super_League" title="Super League">Super League</a> is the highest level of professional rugby league in the UK and Europe. It consists of 11 teams from Northern England, and one each from London, Wales and France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-681"><a href="#cite_note-681">[664]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marquess_of_Queensberry_rules" title="Marquess of Queensberry rules">'Queensberry rules'</a>, the code of general rules in <a href="/wiki/Boxing" title="Boxing">boxing</a>, was named after <a href="/wiki/John_Douglas,_9th_Marquess_of_Queensberry" title="John Douglas, 9th Marquess of Queensberry">John Douglas, 9th Marquess of Queensberry</a> in 1867, and formed the basis of modern boxing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-682"><a href="#cite_note-682">[665]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Snooker" title="Snooker">Snooker</a> is another of the UK's popular sporting exports, with the world championships held annually in <a href="/wiki/Sheffield" title="Sheffield">Sheffield</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-683"><a href="#cite_note-683">[666]</a></sup> In Northern Ireland, <a href="/wiki/Gaelic_football" title="Gaelic football">Gaelic football</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hurling" title="Hurling">hurling</a> are popular team sports, both in terms of participation and spectating. Irish expatriates in the UK and the US also play them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CJSHurl_684-0"><a href="#cite_note-CJSHurl-684">[667]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Shinty" title="Shinty">Shinty</a> (or <i>camanachd</i>) is popular in the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Highlands" title="Scottish Highlands">Scottish Highlands</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-685"><a href="#cite_note-685">[668]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Highland_games" title="Highland games">Highland games</a> are held in spring and summer in Scotland, celebrating Scottish and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Celt" title="Celt">celtic</a> culture and heritage, especially that of the Scottish Highlands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-686"><a href="#cite_note-686">[669]</a></sup>
</p><p>The United Kingdom has hosted the <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympic Games</a> on three occasions in <a href="/wiki/1908_Summer_Olympics" title="1908 Summer Olympics">1908</a>, <a href="/wiki/1948_Summer_Olympics" title="1948 Summer Olympics">1948</a> and <a href="/wiki/2012_Summer_Olympics" title="2012 Summer Olympics">2012</a>, with London acting as the host city for all three games respectively. The upcoming <a href="/wiki/2022_Commonwealth_Games" title="2022 Commonwealth Games">2022 Commonwealth Games</a>, scheduled to be hosted in Birmingham, will mark the seventh time the UK has hosted the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_Games" title="Commonwealth Games">Commonwealth Games</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Symbols">Symbols</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Symbols_of_the_United_Kingdom,_the_Channel_Islands_and_the_Isle_of_Man" title="Symbols of the United Kingdom, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man">Symbols of the United Kingdom, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Britannia-Statue.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="2736" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Britannia-Statue.jpg/170px-Britannia-Statue.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Britannia-Statue.jpg/255px-Britannia-Statue.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Britannia-Statue.jpg/340px-Britannia-Statue.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Britannia-Statue.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Statue of <a href="/wiki/Britannia" title="Britannia">Britannia</a> in <a href="/wiki/Plymouth" title="Plymouth">Plymouth</a>. Britannia is a <a href="/wiki/National_personification" title="National personification">national personification</a> of the UK.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Flag of the United Kingdom">flag of the United Kingdom</a> is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Union_Flag" title="Union Flag">Union Flag</a> (also referred to as the Union Jack).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-687"><a href="#cite_note-687">[670]</a></sup> It was created in 1606 by the superimposition of the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_England" title="Flag of England">Flag of England</a>, representing <a href="/wiki/Saint_George" title="Saint George">Saint George</a>, on the <a href="/wiki/Flag_of_Scotland" title="Flag of Scotland">Flag of Scotland</a>, representing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Andrew" title="Saint Andrew">Saint Andrew</a>, and was updated in 1801 with the addition of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saint_Patrick%27s_Flag" title="Saint Patrick's Flag">Saint Patrick's Flag</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-688"><a href="#cite_note-688">[671]</a></sup> Wales is not represented in the Union Flag, as Wales had been conquered and annexed to England prior to the formation of the United Kingdom. The possibility of redesigning the Union Flag to include representation of Wales has not been completely ruled out.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-689"><a href="#cite_note-689">[672]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/National_anthem" title="National anthem">national anthem</a> of the United Kingdom is "<a href="/wiki/God_Save_the_King" title="God Save the King">God Save the King</a>", with "King" replaced with "Queen" in the lyrics whenever the monarch is a woman.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Britannia" title="Britannia">Britannia</a> is a <a href="/wiki/National_personification" title="National personification">national personification</a> of the United Kingdom, originating from <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">Roman Britain</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-690"><a href="#cite_note-690">[673]</a></sup> Britannia is symbolised as a young woman with brown or golden hair, wearing a <a href="/wiki/Corinthian_helmet" title="Corinthian helmet">Corinthian helmet</a> and white robes. She holds <a href="/wiki/Poseidon" title="Poseidon">Poseidon</a>'s three-pronged trident and a shield, bearing the Union Flag.
</p><p>Beside <a href="/wiki/The_Lion_and_the_Unicorn" title="The Lion and the Unicorn">the lion and the unicorn</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Welsh_Dragon" title="Welsh Dragon">dragon</a> of heraldry, the <a href="/wiki/Bulldog" title="Bulldog">bulldog</a> is an iconic animal and commonly represented with the Union Jack. It has been associated with Winston Churchill's defiance of <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-691"><a href="#cite_note-691">[674]</a></sup> A now rare personification is a character originating in the 18th century, <a href="/wiki/John_Bull" title="John Bull">John Bull</a>, a portly country gentleman dressed in a <a href="/wiki/Top_hat" title="Top hat">top hat</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tailcoat" title="Tailcoat">tailcoat</a> with a Union Jack <a href="/wiki/Waistcoat" title="Waistcoat">waistcoat</a>, often accompanied by a bulldog.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-692"><a href="#cite_note-692">[675]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Floral_emblem" title="Floral emblem">floral emblems</a> of the three kingdoms are the <a href="/wiki/Tudor_rose" title="Tudor rose">Tudor rose</a> for England, the <a href="/wiki/Thistle" title="Thistle">thistle</a> for Scotland and the <a href="/wiki/Shamrock" title="Shamrock">shamrock</a> for Northern Ireland; they are sometimes shown intertwined to represent unity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VanWie_693-0"><a href="#cite_note-VanWie-693">[676]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Daffodil" title="Daffodil">daffodil</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Leek" title="Leek">leek</a> are the symbols of Wales.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-694"><a href="#cite_note-694">[677]</a></sup> Alternatives include the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Oak" title="Royal Oak">Royal Oak</a> for England and the <a href="/wiki/Flax" title="Flax">flax</a> flower for Northern Ireland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-VanWie_693-1"><a href="#cite_note-VanWie-693">[676]</a></sup>
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">There is no authorised version of the national anthem as the words are a matter of tradition; only the first verse is usually sung.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> No statute has been enacted designating "God Save the King" as the official anthem. In the English tradition, such laws are not necessary; <a href="/wiki/Proclamation" title="Proclamation">proclamation</a> and usage are sufficient to make it the national anthem. "God Save the King" also serves as the <a href="/wiki/Honors_music" title="Honors music">Royal anthem</a> for certain <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Commonwealth_realms" title="Commonwealth realms">Commonwealth realms</a>. The words <i>King, he, him, his</i>, used at present, are replaced by <i>Queen, she, her</i> when the monarch is female.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-7">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Scots, Ulster Scots, Welsh, Cornish, Scottish Gaelic and Irish are classed as <a href="/wiki/Regional_language" title="Regional language">regional</a> or <a href="/wiki/Minority_language" title="Minority language">minority</a> languages under the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">Council of Europe</a>'s <a href="/wiki/European_Charter_for_Regional_or_Minority_Languages" title="European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages">European Charter for Regional or Minority Languages</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reglang_3-0"><a href="#cite_note-reglang-3">[2]</a></sup> These include defined obligations to promote those languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[3]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-6"><a href="#cite_note-6">[5]</a></sup> See also <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_the_United_Kingdom" title="Languages of the United Kingdom">Languages of the United Kingdom</a>. Welsh has limited <i><a href="/wiki/De_jure" title="De jure">de jure</a></i> official status in Wales, as well as in the provision of national government services provided for Wales.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-8"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-8">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">"This category could include Polish responses from the country specific question for Scotland which would have been outputted to 'Other White' and then included under 'White' for UK. 'White Africans' may also have been recorded under 'Other White' and then included under 'White' for UK."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-9"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-9">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">83.6% are <a href="/wiki/White_British" title="White British">White British</a>/<a href="/wiki/White_Irish" title="White Irish">Irish</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-15">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Although the United Kingdom has traditionally been seen as a unitary state, an alternative description of the UK as a "union state", put forward by, among others, <a href="/wiki/Vernon_Bogdanor" title="Vernon Bogdanor">Vernon Bogdanor</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-11"><a href="#cite_note-11">[7]</a></sup> has become increasingly influential since the adoption of devolution in the 1990s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[8]</a></sup> A union state is considered to differ from a unitary state in that while it maintains a central authority it also recognises the authority of historic rights and infrastructures of its component parts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[10]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-23"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-23">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Some of the devolved countries, Crown Dependencies and British Overseas Territories issue their own sterling banknotes or currencies, or use another nation's currency. See <a href="/wiki/List_of_British_currencies" title="List of British currencies">List of British currencies</a> for more information.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-24">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Also in observed by the <a href="/wiki/Crown_Dependencies" title="Crown Dependencies">Crown Dependencies</a>, and in the two British Overseas Territories of <a href="/wiki/Gibraltar" title="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saint_Helena,_Ascension_and_Tristan_da_Cunha" title="Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha">Saint Helena, Ascension and Tristan da Cunha</a> (though in the latter, without daylight saving time). For further information, see <a href="/wiki/Time_in_the_United_Kingdom#British_territories" title="Time in the United Kingdom">Time in the United Kingdom#British territories</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-25">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Except two overseas territories: <a href="/wiki/Gibraltar" title="Gibraltar">Gibraltar</a> and the <a href="/wiki/British_Indian_Ocean_Territory" title="British Indian Ocean Territory">British Indian Ocean Territory</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Telephone_numbers_in_the_United_Kingdom#Telephone_numbers_in_Overseas_Territories" title="Telephone numbers in the United Kingdom">Excludes most overseas territories</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-27"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-27">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The <a href="/wiki/.gb" title=".gb">.gb</a> domain is also reserved for the UK, but has been little used.</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1011085734" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="reflist">
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-28"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-28">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Usage is mixed. The <i><a class="external text" href="https://www.theguardian.com/guardian-observer-style-guide-u" rel="nofollow">Guardian</a></i> and <i><a class="external text" href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/style-book/places-and-people/" rel="nofollow">Telegraph</a></i> use Britain as a synonym for the United Kingdom. Some prefer to use Britain as shorthand for <a href="/wiki/Great_Britain" title="Great Britain">Great Britain</a>.

The British <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_Office" title="Cabinet Office">Cabinet Office</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Government_Digital_Service" title="Government Digital Service">Government Digital Service</a> <a class="external text" href="https://www.gov.uk/guidance/style-guide/a-to-z-of-gov-uk-style#great-britain" rel="nofollow">style guide</a> for use on <a href="/wiki/Gov.uk" title="Gov.uk">gov.uk</a> recommends: "Use UK and United Kingdom in preference to Britain and British (UK business, UK foreign policy, ambassador and high commissioner). But British embassy, not UK embassy."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-35"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-35">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The United Kingdom does not have a codified constitution but an unwritten one formed of Acts of Parliament, court judgments, traditions, and conventions. <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1067248974">.mw-parser-output cite.citation{font-style:inherit;word-wrap:break-word}.mw-parser-output .citation q{quotes:"\"""\"""'""'"}.mw-parser-output .citation:target{background-color:rgba(0,127,255,0.133)}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-free a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-free a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/65/Lock-green.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .id-lock-registration a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-limited a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-registration a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Lock-gray-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .id-lock-subscription a,.mw-parser-output .citation .cs1-lock-subscription a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/aa/Lock-red-alt-2.svg")right 0.1em center/9px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-ws-icon a{background:linear-gradient(transparent,transparent),url("//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Wikisource-logo.svg")right 0.1em center/12px no-repeat}.mw-parser-output .cs1-code{color:inherit;background:inherit;border:none;padding:inherit}.mw-parser-output .cs1-hidden-error{display:none;color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-visible-error{color:#d33}.mw-parser-output .cs1-maint{display:none;color:#3a3;margin-left:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-format{font-size:95%}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-left{padding-left:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .cs1-kern-right{padding-right:0.2em}.mw-parser-output .citation .mw-selflink{font-weight:inherit}</style><cite class="citation cs2"><a class="external text" href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/constitution-unit/what-uk-constitution/what-uk-constitution" rel="nofollow"><i>What is the UK Constitution?</i></a>, The Constitution Unit of UCL, 9 August 2018<span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">6 February</span> 2020</span></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=What+is+the+UK+Constitution%3F&amp;rft.pub=The+Constitution+Unit+of+UCL&amp;rft.date=2018-08-09&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ucl.ac.uk%2Fconstitution-unit%2Fwhat-uk-constitution%2Fwhat-uk-constitution&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AUnited+Kingdom"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-41"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-41">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The 1921 <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Irish_Treaty" title="Anglo-Irish Treaty">Anglo-Irish Treaty</a> resolved the <a href="/wiki/Irish_War_of_Independence" title="Irish War of Independence">Irish War of Independence</a>. When it took effect one year later, it established the <a href="/wiki/Irish_Free_State" title="Irish Free State">Irish Free State</a> as a separate <a href="/wiki/Dominion" title="Dominion">dominion</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations" title="Commonwealth of Nations">Commonwealth of Nations</a>. In 1927 the <a href="/wiki/Royal_and_Parliamentary_Titles_Act_1927" title="Royal and Parliamentary Titles Act 1927">Royal and Parliamentary Titles Act 1927</a> changed the name of the UK to reflect this.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-58"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-58">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Compare to section 1 of both of the 1800 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_(1800)" title="Acts of Union (1800)">Acts of Union</a> which reads: the <i>Kingdoms of Great Britain and Ireland shall...be united into one Kingdom, by the Name of "The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland"</i>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-427"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-427">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The 2011 Census recorded Gypsies and Travellers as a separate ethnic group for the first time.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-430"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-430">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In the 2011 Census, for the purpose of harmonising results to make them comparable across the UK, the ONS includes individuals in Scotland who classified themselves in the "African" category (29,638 people), which in the Scottish version of the census is separate from "Caribbean or Black" (6,540 people),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[413]</a></sup> in this "Black or Black British" category. The ONS note that "the African categories used in Scotland could potentially capture White/Asian/Other African in addition to Black identities".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[414]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-652"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-652">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Berkeley is in fact Irish but was called a 'British empiricist' due to the territory of what is now known as the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland" title="Republic of Ireland">Republic of Ireland</a> being in the UK at the time.</span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>

<li id="cite_note-ferguson-43"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ferguson_43-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFFerguson2004">Ferguson, Niall (2004). <span class="cs1-lock-registration" title="Free registration required"><a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/empire00nial" rel="nofollow"><i>Empire: The rise and demise of the British world order and the lessons for global power</i></a></span>.
